PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House our strongest support for the existing National Flag.
The Australian National Flag is the most important symbol of the Australian nation and our national unity, and has evoked deep feelings of honour and respect from many generations of Australians.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to preserve our current Australian National Flag and to ensure that its design is not changed without the support of a referendum carried by the majority of Australians in the majority of States.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Anderson (from 703 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 15 citizens), Mr Lloyd (from eight citizens) and Mr Truss (from 149 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 170 citizens), Mr Connolly (from 35 citizens) and Mr Jull (from 70 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Victoria draws to the attention of the House:

That about 28,000 unborn babies are being killed in Victoria annually, and that a total of about 750,000 have been killed in Australia since abortion item 6469 became part of the Medicare benefits schedule in 1975.
Most abortions are performed on healthy unborn babies for reasons of convenience and most of the procedures are funded by the Australian taxpayer through Medicare.
Your petitioners therefore ask the house to terminate Medicare funding of abortion in Australia by supporting the Abortion Funding Bill of 1990.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Lloyd (from 57 citizens), Mr McGauran (from 11 citizens) and Mr Reith (from 90 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
(1)We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag.
(2)We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Dobie (from 22 citizens) and Mr Ruddock (from 463 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Asia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that:
the Australian Broadcasting Corporation intends to transmit television programs into Asia.
apart from an initial grant from the Government it is intended to finance this venture by the introduction of corporate sponsorship.
the Government intends to alter existing broadcasting legislation to allow this to be done.

this course of action would set a precedent which, in our view, would introduce pressures of corporate funding into the ABC and endanger the independence of our national broadcaster in its vital role as Australia's main disseminator of news and information at a time of unprecedented concentration of media ownership in this country.
Your petitioners therefore ask the House either
to ensure that the proposed Asian service be wholly funded by Government
OR that the proposed Asian service not commence until Government funds are available.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Mack (from 324 citizens) and Mr Moore (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Earth Repair Charter
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

PETITION.PARA: World-wide, people are aware that important natural resources, such as trees, soil, pure air, water, and our Earth's protective ozone layer—all vital to life and human livelihood—have been dangerously depleted.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore urge that the Australian Parliament will:

PETITION.PARA: Let Australia lead the way and legislate to implement the Earth Repair Charter which is a practical solution-strategy to help rectify humanity's environmental, social and economic imbalances, towards achieving just, sustainable and peaceful, local and global communities.

PARA.TAB: The Earth Repair Charter's Objectives (In Summary):

PETITION.PARA: Implement an Earth Repair Action decade;
Cooperate in peace for the environment;
Protect our remaining natural heritage;
Support the world's indigenous people;
Recognise interconnectedness of all life;
Use permaculture to end world hunger;
Cultivate a `sense of humus' for soils;
Acquire vital immunity efficiency;
Educate for and practise healthy living;
Unite humanity in a common purpose.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr MacKellar (from seven citizens) and Mr Tickner (from 18 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia showeth:
The need for the Government to recognise that our Flag represents History, Heritage and Culture and should not be changed without a full referendum of the people.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives call upon the Government to retain our existing Australian Flag and to give Australians the opportunity to express that wish through a referendum.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Capital Punishment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House for the re-introduction of capital punishment.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

PETITION.PARA: Re-introduce capital punishment for brutal and serious crimes committed against innocent victims such as murders and or rape of children.

PETITION.TITLE: Civil Aviation Authority: Gliders
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the action of the Civil Aviation Authority requiring gliders in Australia to carry Mode C transponders without any consultation with the Gliding Federation of Australia. This decision breaches a 1989 agreement for ongoing consultation between the Civil Aviation Authority and the Gliding Federation of Australia.
We urge the House to require that the Civil Aviation Authority not be allowed to proceed with this mandatory action.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Access
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: 1.That we the undersigned citizens wish to signify our strong support for everyone in the community having access to quality healthcare services when they need them.
2.That we believe because people are being discouraged from providing for their own healthcare that not everyone has equal access to quality healthcare services.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request the House to:

PETITION.PARA: Ensure that the Federal Government provides tax credits or rebates to encourage people to have private healthcare funding where they can afford it, so that all Australians will have equal access to quality healthcare.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that certain persons wish to change the National Flag of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request that no change to the National Flag of Australia be made without a full referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That we call upon Honourable Members to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the Commonwealth of Australia draws to the attention of the House that we the undersigned affirm our absolute support for the Australian flag and express our sincere disappointment that the flag has recently been denegrated within and outside of Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly request the House to affirm its support for the Australian Flag and ensure that under no circumstance the Australian Flag be changed.

PETITION.TITLE: Collinsville: TV
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the following situation:

1.With the "aggregation" of regional commercial television services, Collinsville is now supposed to get three services—viz. Sunshine (7), WIN (9) and QTV (10). However, the Sunshine network is the only service that transmits to the Collinsville district.

2.Previously, residents of Collinsville received one commercial service which was a combination of the "best" programs from each channel e.g. cricket and rugby league from Channel 9, tennis from Channel 7, etc.
3.Subsequently, the quality of viewing available to Collinsville and surrounding districts has declined markedly since "aggregation".

4.Despite repeated approaches from various representatives of the community, the management of the WIN and QTV networks continually refuse to meet the conditions of their licence by failing to provide services to the area.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House brings this matter to the attention of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal for its immediate consideration so that the taxpayers of this area might receive the same standard of service as that enjoyed by the vast majority of Australians.
Furthermore, we request that if the management of the aforementioned networks persist in refusing to meet the conditions of their licence, that the licences shall be revoked.

PETITION.TITLE: Five-dollar Note
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that we, the undersigned, wish to lodge a protest over the introduction of the new plastic $5.00 note which is totally unacceptable to the public. We find it to be too small in size, too light of weight and of a composition that makes it very hard to handle as they stick together and will not lay flat once they have been folded or bent and remain in a crinkled state. As the plastic $10 note was found to be unsuccessful we protest the right of Government to changing the $5 to this highly inferior note. The paper $5 note was a far superior currency and should have been maintained.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to withdraw the plastic $5 note from circulation and replace it with a paper $5 note similar to the previous one.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of the undersigned residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House the precarious position of Australia's independent magazine publishers due to the recent decision by Australia Post to abolish the Registered Publications scheme and cause a rise of between 78.5% and 223.5% in postal charges (depending on weight and destination) for subscriber magazines over an 18 month period. For example, to mail a 300g magazine cost 47 cents in August 1990 under the Registered Publications scheme. It now costs up to $1.52.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners pray that the House, as a matter of urgency:

PETITION.PARA: (a)Takes action to ensure that the registered publications service is saved.
(b)Ensures that such discriminatory eligibility criteria for registered publications as cover price ceilings are forbidden, placing all Australian magazines on an equal footing.

(c)Removes the constant threat of crippling prices rises from the independent publishing industry by ensuring that postal rate increases for magazines are set at 50% of the consumer price index commencing retrospectively at January 1, 1990.
(d)Takes action to ban discriminatory price loadings for interstate and country subscribers, giving all Australians equal access to magazines.

(e)Protects diversity of media ownership in Australia as a mainstay of our democracy by legislating the maintenance of the registered publications service as a community service obligation of Australia Post.

(f)Ensures that all future decisions affecting the carriage of magazines by Australia Post are made in conjunction with a publishing industry committee representing both non-profit and independent publishers to ensure that the best features of both registered publications and print post are maintained.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Five-dollar Note
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House that after more than fifty days since the launching by The Royal Australian Mint, the new plastic five dollar ($5) note continues to be hated by small business.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House call for the Royal Australian Mint, in consultation with relative authorities, to review the new five dollar ($5) note launched on 7 July, 1992.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Funding of Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and seek to practice the teachings of Jesus Christ and His apostles, draws to your attention that the practice of abortion as generally carried out in Australia is:
1.Sin against God (Job 1 v.21, 22);
2.Sin against His word as contained in the Holy Bible (Exodus 20 v.13);
3.Against the welfare of this nation (Proverbs 14 v.34);
4.A contradiction of the Parliamentary Prayer (Matthew 6 v.10).

Abortion as generally performed is murder to destroy life, not to save it. No nation can usurp or defy God's rights with impunity. For the Government to continue supporting this wickedness is to invite God's righteous indignation and judgment upon our nation.
Abortion is not just a political, social, personal or health issue. It is a serious Moral issue and any denial that it is a moral issue is a Moral Decision itself.
Your petitioners therefore as in duty bound, pray and ask the Honourable House, that, as a matter of righteousness and urgency, Medicare funding of Abortion be terminated as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Plutonium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament of Australia assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, note that the Japanese Government is transporting 1.7 tonnes of plutonium, by the vessel Akatsuki Maru from France as part of its accumulation of over thirty tonnes of this highly toxic material for use in a fast breeder reactor. We express our deep concern that these shipments are a significant step in the development of international commerce in plutonium and request that the Federal Government:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Protest in the strongest possible terms at Japan's shipment of highly dangerous plutonium from France to Japan.
2.Call for a halt to this trade, along with other Asia-Pacific countries which have also opposed the transportation of plutonium.
3.Impose a ban on:

PARA.TAB: a) any transport of plutonium through Australian waters.
b) any use of our ports by the vessel for any purpose, including a nuclear emergency.

PETITION.PARA: 4.Express its strongest possible opposition to any nuclear weapons program by Japan.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National University Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of the following citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the Australian National University Amendment (Autonomy) Bill 1992 introduced by Senator Tierney passed unopposed through the Senate on 8 October 1992.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to debate this Bill at the earliest possible opportunity and ensure its passage through the House so that the autonomy of the Council of the Australian National University may be reinstated, together with full control over the funding of its Schools, including the John Curtin School of Medical Research.

PETITION.TITLE: Serbian Chetniks: Anzac Day Parades
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House:

PETITION.PARA: That Serbian Chetniks take Part in Anzac Day Parades but clearly do not represent the ideals that Australian Servicemen fought and died for;
That these same Serbian Chetniks are continuing their traditions of slaughter and destruction today in the Republics of Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina;
That the United Nations General Assembly Security Council Report (A/47/666 S/24809) paragraph 136 clearly states:

"The Serbian [Chetnik] authorities in de facto control of certain territories in Bosnia and Herzegovina and in the United Nations Protected Areas [in Croatia] bear primary responsibility for the policy of ethnic cleansing carried out there.".

PARA.TAB: Your Petitioners request the House to:

PETITION.PARA: Recognise that Australian Servicemen served their country with honour and distinction and that the memory of their sacrifice should not be dishonoured by the presence of Serbian Chetnik marchers;
Take appropriate action to ensure that Serbian Chetnik's do not take part in future Anzac Day marches.

PETITION.TITLE: Townsville: Roadworks
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the rapid increase and congestion of traffic to University Drive, Angus Smith Drive, Charles Barton Bridge and Nathan Street due to the continued growth of the James Cook University, the continued development of the suburbs of Annandale and Douglas and the continuing traffic flow from the Army's Lavarack Barracks located on University Drive.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will urgently accelerate the roadworks program to:
1.Build a new traffic bridge across the Ross River upstream from the Charles Barton Bridge joining Angus Smith Drive and Ross River Road;
2.Extend Angus Smith Drive to the new bridge;
3.Widen the present two lane Charles Barton Bridge to link up with the wider roadway of Nathan Street.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled

The undersigned, who are users of the services of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation, state our concern at the closure or partial closure of AOTC country and city offices for residential customers. Reduction in numbers of staff servicing residential customers can only lead to a reduction in the quality of service that we receive.
As Australian citizens and residents, we support the creation of new job opportunities in AOTC in both country and city areas.
Your Petitioners ask that the House of Representatives:
Keep existing AOTC residential customer service offices in the city and the country open;
Stop AOTC from cutting staff in the residential customer service area.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: This humble petition is from the undersigned citizens of Australia who are believers in the Lord Jesus Christ and persons whose fellowship together is based upon regard for the absolute authority and recognition of God's word as contained in the Holy Bible. We draw to your attention that the requirement of God's Law is disregarded entirely by the Family Law Act in that adultery is not allowed as a basis for divorce.

The Lord Jesus Christ himself said "Whosoever shall put away his wife except for fornication, and shall marry another, commits adultery, and whosoever marrieth her which is put away committeth adultery.". (Matthew 19 v 9)

The Government of this country is ordained of God (Romans 13 v 1) and as God's ministers for good and what is righteous your petitioners humbly appeal to you that the Family Law Act be amended to reintroduce adultery as a ground for divorce.

PETITION.TITLE: Farm Profitability
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House

PETITION.PARA: that with more than 10 per cent of Australians out of work, the concept of a level playing field and zero tariffs is rejected by Australian families who can see no evidence of benefit by substantial losses from the arguments put by economic rationalists.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request the House to

PETITION.PARA: act to ensure that Australia maintains a viable processing industry based on our rural industries and that tariffs remain in place as long as other nations use non-tariff measures, tariff protection, etc.;
stop imports of goods that are supported by subsidies and other non-tariff or dumping measures to Australia; and
restore profitability to our farms and factories, employment opportunities to our citizens and to provide a future for our youth.

PETITION.TITLE: ABC Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that funding for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation has already been reduced by some $120 million. Any further reduction would unacceptably compromise the quality of service and endanger the independence of our national broadcaster and we ask that no further reductions in funding be agreed to by the House of Representatives.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Federal Industrial Relations Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that we object to recently passed amendments to the Federal Industrial Relations Act which gives the Industrial Relations Commission the power to interfere in contracts between builders and sub-contractors.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House repeal the relevant legislation to ensure the ongoing efficiency of the housing industry.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in parliament:

PARA.TAB: This Petition of Citizens of Australia and Customers of Australia Post draws to the attention of the House the terrible consequences associated with adopting the Draft Recommendations of the Industry Commission on the Postal Industry, which if implemented will result in a poorer level of service to the community.

Increased competition in some areas of postal service whilst requiring Australia Post to continue to serve the nation by providing a universal service at a uniform price can only mean increases in prices and poorer services to outer suburban and country areas.
Payments to offset the cost of competition from the Budget are unacceptable as the uncertainty of funding provides no long term basis for planning a National Postal Network.

We respectfully urge the House to support the current mechanisms for price constraints which have proved effective in providing productivity gains within Australia Post, which exceed those of the Private Sector.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House the blatant abuse of human rights that have occurred and continue to occur to the people of East Timor at the hands of the occupying forces of the Indonesian Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House uses all its power and influence to persuade the Indonesian Government to bring a speedy end to this suffering and to support any United Nations action to free the East Timorese people from this oppression, consistent with your response to the people of Kuwait.

PETITION.TITLE: Cuba
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia humbly showeth:
That we are profoundly concerned and opposed to the financial, commercial and economic blockade imposed by the United States government on the Republic of Cuba for a period of over 30 years.

That we call on all members of the United Nations, including Australia, to reject and demand an immediate end to this inhumane and illegal policy that has caused and continues to cause enormous damage and disadvantage to the economic and social development of the Cuban people.
And we, your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Farm Profitability
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House:

that with more than 11 per cent of Australians out of work, the concept of a level playing field and zero tariffs is rejected by Australian families who can see no evidence of benefit but substantial losses from the arguments put by economic rationalists.

PARA.TAB: You petitioners therefore request the House to:

PETITION.PARA: Restore profitability to our farms and factories, employment opportunities to our citizens and provide a future for our youth by reducing all forms of Taxation with a view of eliminating it altogether in the near future.

PARA.TAB: Stop imports of goods that are currently mined, grown or produced in Australia, or can be, or were in the past processed or produced in Australia and the production thereof later relocated offshore to put us out of work.

PETITION.PARA: Legislate for the Federal Government alone to create credit and money needed to satisfy its responsibilities and the needs of its people. This is to be done without borrowing or creating further debt for the residents of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Easson, for the committee appointed to prepare an Address-in-Reply to the speech of His Excellency the Governor-General, presented the proposed address, which was read by the Clerk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Lowe, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech, and I ask the House to extend to her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Easson Ms M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following Address-in-Reply to the speech of His Excellency the Governor-General be agreed to:

SPEECH.PARA: May it please Your Excellency:

PARA.TAB: We, the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled, express our loyalty to the Sovereign, and thank Your Excellency for the speech you have been pleased to address to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, allow me, sir, to congratulate you on your election to the speakership of this House. I would also like to thank the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) for their kind invitation to me to move the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's speech.

PARA.TAB: I am proud to sit in this House as a representative of the Australian Labor Party. I have had a long and enjoyable participation in politics in three States—Victoria, Queensland and New South Wales—over a period of 19 years, through the Labor Party, Young Labor, and the trade union movement. I worked for a former Deputy Prime Minister, Frank Crean, whose son, Simon, is a member of the Cabinet of the current Government. I also worked for a current member of this House, the Hon. Ben Humphreys.

Along my journey to this House, I worked with fine examples of major Australian corporations. I was with ACI—Australian Consolidated Industries—for four years, and Ansett Transport Industries for five years. Naturally, I have a keen interest in the manufacturing and tourism industries in this country. Australia's tourist potential is something that I believe is paramount to the Australian economy.

I come from a family who originally came from the land, and as a child I spent considerable time in the farming communities of north-eastern Victoria. So I also have an interest in the plight of farmers and rural communities. My family members are mostly all involved in small business, and for the last three years I have conducted my own business. I have also been involved in a number of community groups which have influenced me. I am the national secretary of UNICEF Australia, I am on the advisory board of the Volunteer Centre of New South Wales, and I am a member of the Communication Commission for the Sydney Olympic bid.

My political and personal travels reached a new stage with marriage, home ownership and parenthood, which found me in the Sydney suburbs of Drummoyne, Ashfield, and latterly Strathfield—all in the electorate of Lowe. At that time, Lowe was ably represented by an excellent local member, Mr Michael Maher MP, a true gentleman, a great Australian and a very dear friend.

Most people go into politics because they believe they have something to contribute to the life of the community. We believe that we have values that are worth fighting for, and those values and objectives reflect our background and our experience of life.

It is easy to be cynical about politics and cynicism is often understandable, but these things come in cycles. Despite the claims about the endemic cynicism among the young about public life, my experience is quite different. Just after my election, I was invited to address a gathering at the Sydney University Labor Club. There was, to my surprise, a very large and enthusiastic crowd of well over 200 people—idealistic and full of eagerness on issues such as the coming of the Australian republic.

This change of mood is also associated with a generational change of leadership: a new group of people with a new set of ideas, experiences and aspirations. One of the great achievements of Labor, both in government and as a party, is the way it has been able to make this generational change without having it forced upon us after electoral defeat and consignment to the political wilderness. My political views have been shaped by my family, my faith and my participation in the Labor Party.

I believe in the thoughts of the prophet Micah that one should act justly, love tenderly and walk humbly with one's God. I joined the Labor Party in the seat of Henty in Victoria in 1974 and had the pleasure to work on the campaign of Mrs Joan Child, who was also a Speaker of this House. She was certainly an excellent role model as a female member of Parliament.

Also Senator Robert Ray was in my local branch and he taught me a lot about the political culture of the Labor Party and also how to count. I was elected president of Victorian Young Labor at the age of 20 in 1976—a time of great turmoil—and it was the best training ground that I could ever have had. My colleagues there were amongst the brightest and the best and I hope that many of them make their way into this House during their lifetime. I recommend to all young people, irrespective of their political persuasion, that they get involved in the political youth groups: that is the best training ground for future politicians.

One of the major reasons I believe that the Government was re-elected was that the electorate believes that the Labor Party is more responsive to people's needs, not just economic ones. But the process of economic reform is critical to the future of all Australians. There are many small businesses in Lowe and it is these hardworking entrepreneurs who are providing the basis of our economic growth. Nearly all growth in employment is in the small business sector and this will continue. We have come a long way since the archaic practices that were seen in that marvellous Australian film Spotswood, but Australia must take management and workplace reform further. Small businesses, with innovative and hardworking principals and employees, are taking on and beating the giants of the last decades.

One of my abiding concerns will be to see that this process of stability in government policy towards business continues. Friends in business tell me that Ministers for industry have maintained a constant policy approach and this has enabled business to plan ahead and to rely upon government policy.

Another area where government can and will continue to play an important role is in supporting research and training. We have already seen over recent years that those companies, big and small, who address internal operations and skill levels, and who achieve standards which are world best practice, prosper greatly. It is up to this Government to help provide training facilities so that business can increase skills and adapt, to make sure that we are the match of the rest of the world.

With a more comfortable orientation towards our Asian neighbours and the opportunities afforded us by the rapid economic growth of our region, we will be able to build a better Australia. To build this better Australia, we must free business from unnecessary intervention and regulation. Small business is what makes our economy thrive. We must create a uniform national standard of fair and appropriate regulation across the country to help facilitate an export orientated focus.

We have seen a very successful program of micro-economic reform under this Government. It is a program which must continue. The current emphasis on enterprise and productivity based workplace agreements is correct. We must empower workers to negotiate for fair working conditions, grant industry and business the flexibility to operate in the most productive way possible, guarantee existing jobs and create more jobs.

I referred earlier to a trend in business towards small and innovative flexible business units which have the capacity to take on the market giants by identifying and exploring a niche. The industry above all others which fits this description is the tourism industry. The Australian tourism industry is our biggest export earner. In 1991-92 Australia earned $8.2 billion, 11 per cent of total export earnings, from tourism. We need to take tourism seriously as an industry and foster its great potential for further growth.

I have also been involved in the tourism industry through my work with Ansett Airlines and I believe that every member of this House has a tourism aspect to his or her electorate. Tourism is very much a bipartisan issue in this Parliament. This is an excellent development and one that I would always encourage.

The Government must also be applauded for its success in bringing down inflation. The temptation to escape from economic difficulty by taking the easy path of inflation has been rejected. With confidence in government policy, and steadiness in economic outlook, business is confident to invest. Business investment is the most important factor in our economic growth and leads to the creation of jobs to relieve the burden of unemployment. We must see a return to national savings and to capital investment in Australia by Australian business. Banks and superannuation funds can do more to encourage productive investment to create more jobs.

Over the past 20 years there have been important changes in the role of women in society. Women in this generation have more opportunities and choices than ever before. However, for many the stresses of combining work and family responsibilities are enormous. For me, one of the highlights of this year's election campaign was the Prime Minister's launch of the national agenda for women, appropriately entitled `Women—sharing and shaping the future'. I doubt that any political leader in our history has so ably focused on the social and economic needs of women in Australia.

During the campaign the Prime Minister announced, as part of his economic policy, a major improvement in government assistance on child care. Not only will the policy greatly assist many Australian families but the psychological importance of including child care as a feature of a major economic policy statement cannot be underestimated.

Our society often judges people by how much they earn and so many women who are at home rearing children in the unpaid part of the work force feel that society does not hold them in high esteem. It is very hard and very valuable work that they do and it should not be in any way underestimated. Therefore the home child-care allowance which is being forecast by our Government is a very important symbolic acknowledgment of the value of the work that is done by carers at home.

Also important is the need for more occasional child care facilities to assist mothers who are at home and who occasionally need to go to the dentist, go shopping or have whatever relaxation period that certainly is due to them. Also important is after school care. I have three places in my electorate which have been waiting for three years for any funding because the New South Wales Government refused to co-fund after school care. I am pleased to say that the Federal Government has released funds and I am hoping to be applying for funds to assist those people in my electorate.

I think this campaign has seen the emergence of women and our perspective and values on issues, including economic issues, as a permanent feature of Australian political life. Certainly I got the feeling in my electorate of Lowe that many people, male and female, were positive about the prospect of being represented by a women. Nonetheless, most people would recognise that we have a long way to go in adjusting our economic and social institutions to accommodate the changed role of women. I might say that many men are assuming far greater parental responsibilities than they did before. Our workplaces in particular need to be more flexible, especially with regard to working hours and more aware of the needs of workers with family responsibilities.

It is here that I would like to address the need for child care in Parliament. It seems to me that there has been much talk and speculation in the press about the need to have more women in this House, but we all know the hours that are worked here and we all know the difficulties that are involved in leaving the premises. Lack of child-care facilities on this site for women of child bearing age is a real disincentive to enter this House.

TALK.START.PARA: —And males.

—There are many males in this House who have young children—we had only to witness the opening day here—and I am sure that they also would use such a facility. It needs to have a couple of different natures. We need a child-care facility that can actually be a creche. I am not suggesting something elitist in this, because it should be open to all employees—they also work strange hours in this House—and it should be on a user-pays basis. Certainly for children from zero to five years of age it seems to be important, and particularly if a mother is to breastfeed her child there are problems in having it at another site, although I know that this has been done here in the past. I applaud those members for making some endeavours in that regard, but I believe that a child-care facility needs to be on site in this House if one is to properly attend to those duties as well.

PARA.TAB: With regard to older children from, say, five to 12 years, it is also important that there should be, probably in the same facility, some sort of leisure centre with videos or a few games or whatever. We have a spouses' lounge; we have a members' bar; we have a very well equipped gymnasium. It really comes down to a matter of priorities: why not child-care facilities for this House?

Medicare has now been operating for 10 years under a Labor government, and most people would accept that in a community they would like access to high quality, affordable care. Medicare is crucially important to families, to the elderly and to those living on fixed incomes. Women are at the coalface when it comes to the delivery of our health care and they are usually the ones who take the children to the doctor. Certainly in the electorate of Lowe they made a very clear statement that they did not want to see the abolition of bulk-billing.

As honourable members would be aware, I ran against the shadow Minister for health and I believe that Medicare was the issue in the electorate of Lowe that affected the women voters even more than their opposition to the GST. Certainly the argument that I used for people was that when I needed to take my daughter Louise to the hospital at 2 o'clock in the morning with an asthma attack I wanted to know that the hospital was worried about her and her condition and not about what sort of insurance I had.

My election slogan for the campaign in the seat of Lowe was `care and commitment'. This neatly summarises my approach to politics. Government has a responsibility to people. It is not good enough to leave everything to the market and to say to individuals, `You are on your own', and believe that things will work out for the best in the long run, because very often they do not. The campaign for the seat of Lowe was successful because of the contributions made by many people who did a lot of work because they believe in Australia, they want to play a role in the democratic process and to make a contribution to improving our national life. They were party members and the campaign workers of Lowe and I thank them sincerely.

I thank Gough and Margaret Whitlam and Bob and Hazel Hawke. One of the things that I learnt from these four marvellous people was the contribution that has been made to Australia by migrants since 1945. The electorate of Lowe is a microcosm of multicultural Australia, because 50 per cent of the people who live there, or their parents, have come from other lands. In my campaign I was invaluably assisted by the help and enthusiasm of the Italian, Greek, Lebanese, Chinese and Vietnamese communities. All of these people put their faith and trust in me and I would like to thank them, because I suspect I would not be here today without their support.

An event occurred after the election which demonstrates the feeling of these communities and their desire to be seen as part of the wider Australian community. On election night, I thanked them very much for their support and this was written up in one of the local papers, which then found that people were coming in and asking for multiple copies. When one of the journalists asked why they wanted the copies, the reply was, `Because this is the first time an Australian politician has publicly thanked us for our work as an ethnic group. Today I am an Australian; today I am not a wog'.

I take this opportunity of thanking my family. My mother, Mrs Aileen Alexander, is in the gallery; my father is deceased for over 25 years. I want to thank my four brothers, one of whom, Maurice, has driven up from Melbourne to be here today. I have to say that when you are brought up with four brothers it is a wonderful preparation for political life: I am sure the combination of teasing, competition and love suits me well for this environment. I want to thank my husband, Michael, to whom after eight years of marriage I can say I am still madly in love with him. I also thank him for being strong enough to allow his wife to follow her dreams. To my daughters, Louise, seven, and Amanda, five, my greatest supporters—they even letterboxed for me—I say that one day they will understand.
Mr Speaker, in thinking about politics and our national life, I am reminded of a famous quote from the German sociologist Max Weber:

SPEECH.PARA: Politics takes both passion and perspective. Certainly all historical experience confirms the truth—`that man would never have attained the possible unless, time and again, he had reached out for the impossible'. But to do that, a man must be a leader a hero as well, in a very sober sense of the meaning of that word. And even those who are neither leaders nor heroes must arm themselves with that steadfastness of heart which can brave even the crumbling of all hopes. This is necessary right now, or else men will not be able to attain even that which is possible today.

PARA.TAB: Only he has the calling for politics who is sure that he shall not crumble when the world, from his point of view, is too foolish or too base for what he has to offer. Only he who in the face of all this can still say, `In spite of all I will go on'—has a true calling for politics.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, as you would understand, Weber in the 19th century used `he' but I am sure he meant both he and she.I hope I can measure up to that ideal, and in our Prime Minister I know we have a leader whose recent experiences recall Weber's ideal. Mr Speaker, I thank you and the House for the courtesy shown me today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call the honourable member for Melbourne I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker. I rise to second the motion and in doing so I would thank the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) for the opportunity to second this motion, and congratulate you upon your election to your high office.

PARA.TAB: My presence in this place is naturally the outcome of contributions from a number of people and it is with great pleasure that I place on record my appreciation for the support, loyalty and guidance of my father, Joe Tanner; mother, Maree Stephenson; stepfather, Noel Stephenson; my wife, Nicki; and our respective families. I also express my thanks to Cindy Hogan, Senator Barney Cooney and Gerry Hand, my predecessor; to my friend Alan Griffin, whom I now have to call in this place, very fortunately, the honourable member for Corinella and with whom I share a loyalty to Essendon Football Club; and also to a very great former member of this House, Mr Gough Whitlam, who first inspired a young bloke from a small country town in East Gippsland over 20 years ago.

I would also like to thank the officials, staff and members of the Federated Clerks Union of Australia. I am intensely proud of my background as a trade union official and I am very grateful for the opportunity that I have had to represent office workers in the industrial arena. I give them my commitment that I certainly will not stop representing and being a voice for the interests of office workers and workers generally in my role in this place.

Office workers are the forgotten people of the Australian community. Too often, when policy is developed with respect to matters like industrial relations or training, focus is based unduly on the interests of particular groups of workers in particular industries, and many groups of workers, large in number but often weaker in voice or weaker in industrial strength, such as office workers, are neglected.

We tend to think of the typical Australian worker as a male with a hairy chest, a blue singlet and a hard hat, but the typical Australian worker today is just as much a female with high heels and a handbag. What I am committed to in debates and issues that are relevant to this dichotomy in this House is to make sure that we keep a true balance, because in this era of enterprise bargaining it is all too easy to lose the interests of many in the work force. What is appropriate and worthwhile for large numbers of metal workers in an individual factory may not necessarily be an appropriate approach for three typists working in a small real estate agent's office, and I am committed to making sure that government policy in these sorts of areas has balance.

I would like to thank the people of my electorate, the electorate of Melbourne, for bestowing their confidence in me, and also to thank those who have worked for me to get here. It is indeed a privilege to represent the electorate, which is rich in diversity, steeped in labour history and overflowing with ideas, energy and talent. It is also the site of many problems, many issues and many injustices, and I am conscious of the fact that I will be judged in my role as the member for Melbourne in this House according to how I represent the interests of the local community. My predecessor, Mr Gerry Hand, to whom I pay tribute, has set an extremely high standard in this regard and I am very conscious of the fact that I will have to maintain that standard, and I am committed very strongly to doing so.

I would like to thank my campaign committee, my staff—Mary Day, Alex Gaspi and Barbara Andrews—and my two lower house State MPs and good friends, Demetri Dollis and Neil Cole. I give them my commitment that I will work as hard for the electorate as they have worked for me.

The people in my electorate are under sustained assault at the moment, like many in the State of Victoria, from the actions of the Kennett Government. Ministry of housing high-rise estate tenants have had rent increases of up to $25 per week imposed upon them. Their cleaning and maintenance services have been slashed. Schools have been closed. Industrial rights have been attacked. Community health centres have had their funding slashed by up to half, and a whole variety of social safety net programs have been substantially reduced.

I recognise that there are significant constitutional and funding problems but, in spite of those, I give my undertaking to the people of my electorate that I will do everything within my power to put forward their interests in this House and to do everything possible to ensure that the impact of these actions of the Kennett Government is minimised.

I am a socialist. I am committed to the values of humanity, tolerance and democracy. In an era when the repressive regimes of eastern Europe have thankfully crumbled, and when socialist certainties are under challenge, I regard it as very much a daunting task to reinvigorate the socialist ideal in this country and across the world. However, there is a great deal within our country that can inspire us. There is a great deal that is worth while about our country, in spite of our many problems—economic and other. I refer to things such as our entrenched democratic tradition; our still defiantly egalitarian spirit; our multicultural society and our extraordinary ability to absorb people of many different races and nationalities without serious violence; our commitment to individual freedom and our entrenched resistance and dislike of authoritarianism, pomp—although recent events might tend to suggest that I am not all that accurate in that comment—and fanaticism. We would do well to recall these very worthwhile achievements of our society when we are next wringing our hands about the latest set of economic statistics, because these are the true, great features of Australian society.

I turn now to focus on several themes, which I intend to make prominent in my contribution in this place and which, hopefully, will occur over a substantial period of time. These themes are, firstly, the need for greater employment and initiatives in industry policy to ensure that we have a more competitive and more vibrant manufacturing sector to deliver that employment; secondly, the need to develop environmentally sensitive economic decision-making processes, both within companies and also at a government decision-making level; and, thirdly, the need to reform our structure of government.

The first of these is the search for solutions to our unemployment problem, which, I believe, is going to lead us into many new areas—in particular, structural unemployment. For example, there is a need to redefine the concept of work—but that is a matter for another day.

I wish to focus, here and now, on our industry policy. Although we are taking down our tariff wall, in my view, we are still relatively unsophisticated in how we deal with industry assistance in this country. Our assistance to industry is still too indiscriminate. It is not targeted and it is insufficiently proactive. We have learnt that picking winners can be fairly dangerous, but we still give a bit of money to losers and sometimes we give it to people who are not even in the game.

I submit that there is plenty of experience, here and overseas, to put us on the right track. We have only to look at our assistance to rural industries over many decades—through bodies such as the CSIRO, through agricultural extension services and the like—to see how effectively interventionist industry policy can work to the benefit of the community. That assistance has been cost-effective. It has been a relatively low burden on the taxpayer. It has helped to make our rural industries amongst the most efficient in the world. It has been proactive and financially sound and, when an individual farm goes down the drain, a lot of government money does not go down the drain with it. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for some industry assistance that has occurred in the past in other areas.

An analysis of countries that have been recently successful in export manufacturing reveals not only the importance of government assistance but also the importance of the nature of the government assistance. In my view, what is critical is that strategic government assistance occurs directly in areas such as research and development, market development forecasting and planning and the development of new technology.

A couple of examples illustrate this point. The Japanese Government pays half the cost of about 185 testing and research centres across the country. Small companies go to these centres, use the equipment and get specialist consultation with specialised staff in a national network of technology extension services. The thriving Emilia-Romagna region of Italy, which is a manufacturing centre of quite extraordinary vibrancy, has similar centres which are partly government funded. They engage in forecasting, research and development, and provide access to new technology for smaller firms that otherwise would be unable to obtain it. Even in the United States, with bodies such as the Michigan Modernisation Service and the National Institute of Standards and Technologies, the same type of thing is occurring. This sort of approach in general is supported by people such as Professor Michael Porter in his tremendous book The Competitive Advantage of Nations, and in the Global challenge: Australian manufacturing in the 1990s, the Australian Manufacturing Council report.

I suggest that this type of approach to industry policy has many advantages. It is more cost effective than indiscriminate assistance such as tax breaks. It guarantees that jobs are created in key areas such as science and technology. It ensures that large sums are not lost when an individual business fails. It allows the government to influence, but not to direct, business policy and approach. It provides enormous potential for regional development through clustering of businesses in strategic locations. It is not indefinite: some of the overseas centres that I have referred to have in fact already left the government funded area and are self-funding. It offers a method for better articulation between our research institutions and business. It offers small and medium sized businesses access to economies of scale. It is a little more subtle than tariff walls—an issue that I think we need to keep in mind.

The issue of size and scale is critical because, since 1970 in Western economies, the long-term trend for the relative size of economic activity to increase has turned around, and more and more activity is occurring within smaller and smaller business units. Flexible production technologies are reducing the tyrannies of economies of scale. Specialised functions are being contracted out to specialised firms. In the words of Robert Howard, in the Harvard Business Review:

SPEECH.PARA: Increased demand for more specialised products, nonstop technological innovation and cheaper and more flexible computer-based technologies are inaugurating a decentralisation of production.

It is precisely this type of company that has led the re-invigoration of Australian manufacturing that is occurring already in the export area. We need to do a great deal more than simply provide level playing fields, tax breaks or tariff walls for these companies. Some examples of the sort of approach occurring now are the cooperative research centres and the National Industry Extension Service, but I would like to see a fair bit more being done.

PARA.TAB: I just make a quick comment in this context about economic policy generally, because this approach sits very effectively with recent developments in economic theories that are called either `endogenous growth theories' or `new growth theories'. Economists such as Paul Romer have demonstrated the serious inadequacies of the neo-classical model. These new models show that the market solution is not necessarily the optimal solution; that government intervention can increase the real rate of growth; and that investment in innovation and human capital is critical for generating growth. Although these theories are still being tested empirically and still being developed as models, they do confirm our commonsense, instinctive view that the neo-classical model is based on false assumptions, ignores fundamental variables, and is not well supported by empirical evidence.

This leads me to the second theme that I intend to pursue in a long-term sense in this place—on the proviso that the people of the electorate of Melbourne give me that long term, which I sincerely hope they do. These theories also relate to the inadequacies of the neo-classical model, and to the greening of economic decision making. In spite of great progress, we still have entrenched conflict between human economic activity and the need to protect our natural environment. The key reason is that we operate by antiquated models of economic decision making, at both the national and the corporate level. The measure of environmental damage is not incorporated into these structures. The adverse effects of economic activity upon our environment are deemed to be externalities: they do not count. `It is not privately owned; it is not tradeable; therefore it is not relevant'.

I am thankful to say that business is at last getting serious about these issues, even in parts of the mining industry. The old adversarial approach of saying, `How do we beat the greenies?', is giving way in many areas to the much more constructive approach of saying, `How do we solve the problems?'. However, the approach which business is taking is still relatively narrow and it is still weighed down by the idea that growth is the answer to everything. That devalues the nature of the problem. It suggests that solving the problem is only a luxury that we can undertake if and when we get the money to do so. It also ignores the fact that if we have growth without solving those problems we will, in fact, exacerbate them.

However, I still must acknowledge that business is getting its act together, and I applaud that. Many feasibility studies for projects are now incorporating things such as environmental impact statements at an early stage, so they do not become something to be fought over at the end. My objective is to move this process of change to a higher level so that we can link economic decision-making processes to our broad environmental objectives. I define those objectives as closed-cycle production, to the maximum extent that we can get it; a reduction in greenhouse gas emissions; a steady increase in the efficiency of our use of materials and energy; a switch to organic agriculture and renewable energy use; and a cessation of the invasion of natural environments by human economic activity, and preservation of species.

What we have to do—and it is difficult—is to link those goals with our economic indicators. National economic statistics measure our wealth creation, but they do not measure the damage we cause by creating it and by using it. Corporate decision-making indicators—company accounts and the like—do not even properly address the corporate impact of environmental damage, much less the community impact of that damage.

I do not have any instant solutions to this problem, and that is why I am suggesting that this is a long-term thing that needs to be addressed. I hope honourable members in this House will be interested in taking me up on this. We have to get the issue away from the high-profile battles, away from people lying in front of bulldozers, and into the boardrooms, into government. We have to make sure that the decisions have been made properly and in an environmentally sensitive way from the outset so that we do not get to the protest stage.

It is time that we internalised the environmental externalities. We have to integrate environmental indices into our economic decision-making structures. The company balance sheet must ultimately be linked in some way to a natural capital account of the nation so that national goals and indicators for environmental protection can be linked with the decisions that we actually make about economic activity, either in this place, in State parliaments or in companies.

The mention of State parliaments brings me to my third and final theme: my desire to see the abolition of State governments. Like many in this chamber, I am committed to the achievement of a republic in this country by the year 2001. I have no doubt that we will traverse many other constitutional issues in our journey towards that goal. Although we may not achieve a two-tier system of government by the year 2001, it is critical that we examine these issues while attention is focused on our structure of government.

The States are as much an anachronistic relic of colonial times as are our links with the British Crown. In 1901 the States reflected genuine focuses of economic and social activity in this country; they have long since ceased to do so. They are now an impediment to good government, a fount of economic inefficiency and a mis-allocation of scarce public funds. In this era of micro-economic reform, with interstate economic activity ever increasing, what we are getting from the States is eight different legal and regulatory systems in areas such as criminal law, environmental law, consumer law, trade and occupational qualifications, food standards, workers compensation—and so the list goes on. Business is confronted with a multiplicity of conflicting regulatory demands and overlapping planning regimes which generate inordinate delays, conflicting demands and fragmentation of the planning process. The States compete with each other for investment, including foreign investment, at the expense of their own citizens by trading off cheaper electricity, cheaper workers compensation premiums and the like. The boundaries of the States have about as much relevance and logic as the boundaries imposed on Africa by the colonial invaders in the 19th century. It is not necessary to be a genius to work out that the Murray River was adopted as a boundary in the days when no-one had heard of pollution and it was thought that natural resources were unlimited.

TAB.TAB: The complexities of the distribution of powers between the States and the Commonwealth cause many anomalies and many problems that lead to an inadequate approach by government at large to issues in the community. If we want to see the ultimate absurdity of our system of government, we only have to look at recent chaos surrounding issues such as daylight saving and Australia Day. Those issues highlight the stupidity of the system. How many other countries in the world celebrate their national day on different days in different parts of the country?

PARA.TAB: Fortunately, there are a few people on the conservative side of politics who adopt a constructive approach to this debate and who do not respond with attempts to frighten small children late at night with boogiemen. Ian McPhee is an honourable example. The honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was even quoted in the Australian about 18 months ago implicitly suggesting that it would be a good idea if the State structure were done away with. I suspect the honourable member might have changed his mind in recent times, but time will tell. In its publication `Government in Australia in the 1990s: a business perspective', the Business Council of Australia described the existing structure of government in this country as `archaic, inefficient and in urgent need of reform', and called for a two-tier system of government.

In conclusion, I ask the economic rationalists on the other side of the House—if there are any left since 13 March—to give very serious consideration to this issue. There is one at least—that is good to see. If we are to be a truly independent nation, economically vibrant and innovative, and to provide efficient and responsive government to the people of Australia into the 21st century, we must not exempt our antiquated system of government from the flood of change which is sweeping through this country. I expect to be standing here in the year 2001 representing a truly independent Australian republic, and I intend to do everything within my power to ensure that that republic is genuinely democratic, efficient and accountable. Mr Speaker, I thank you. I commend the motion to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Stirling I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

—Thank you very much, Mr Speaker. May I begin by congratulating you on your election as the Speaker of the House of Representatives. In light of the fact that the former member for Stirling was widely touted as the next occupant of your high office, you might consider that I have done you a favour and I would appreciate the kindly nod in my direction from time to time. I would hope, and I encourage you to ensure, that the position of the Speaker of the House of Representatives is rebuilt into one which is respected by both sides of the House.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to congratulate the Labor Party on its victory, although I do so with some reservation. In a country as great as ours all Australians deserve to have the opportunity to choose their representatives without fear of distortion of any party's policies, without half-truths and downright misrepresentation. Such behaviour preys most heavily on those in our community who feel most vulnerable and insecure, the elderly and the unemployed in particular.

To all the people who helped me in any way in the campaign for Stirling, I extend my eternal gratitude. They campaigned, as I did, with dignity and integrity and at all times with the utmost truthfulness. I extend a special thankyou to Senator Sue Knowles, who is with us in the gallery today, who talked me into running for office, something for which I shall never forgive her.

I am very proud, as I stand here today, to be able to acknowledge the wonderful support of my wife, Wendy, the war office, who is seated alongside Sue Knowles, and of my children, the former anklebiters—Jane, Ryan and Jacinta—who these days are more into neck biting, I fear. They have withstood the rigours of my campaign above and beyond the call. They have gone without in order to see our success. I extend my love to my devoted wider family, who travelled from throughout Western Australia to support me. I am grateful to have the opportunity to continue in the footsteps of others of my family who preceded me in this place, in particular my great-grandfather, Malcolm Duncan Cameron, the member for Barker from 1922 to 1935. It is my desire and intention to ensure that I make my stay in parliament as dignified and representative as his.

Throughout my campaign to win the seat of Stirling I made a particular promise—some might say the threat—in this my maiden speech to take the theme of yes and no. Too often I have heard in this House, and indeed on the hustings, longwinded answers, full of hot air, bluster and overblown egoism—replies replete with rhetoric but overwhelmingly short on substance. I have to make it clear that I am not opposed to lengthy replies to sensible questions; I am completely opposed to wasting the time of the Parliament with an unprofessional attitude to the business of government.

I come from the other world of bluster and hot air, the media—radio and television broadcasting, to be precise. I also come from management in those media. As with those areas, there can be no room in our Parliament for those with attitude problems, no room for those who waste time, no room for those who do not get the job done swiftly and honestly, and there is certainly no room for those who cannot take on any task without good humour and total professionalism. There is a place for a short—dare I say it—one-word reply; there is a place for action and quiet achievement; and there is a place for the words `yes' and `no.'

As I speak in this House for the first time today I am indebted to the people of my fine electorate of Stirling for going against the national political trend and for putting in me their hopes and their trust. It is a trust that I accept with humility and considerable fear. I fear to fail them but I will not do so for I have made to them an indelible pledge of duty. And as for their hopes, they are the same as mine—for an Australia proud of itself. I see Australians working and playing together, Australians living in peace and prosperity, Australians contributing to the family of nations and becoming a far greater nation because of its compassion and good grace.

In talking of our hopes, dreams and aspirations I would like to touch on the question of whether we should become a republic. I am in favour of progress for Australia but only if it is in the best interests of the Australian people. I therefore welcome any debate on the future of our Constitution so long as all Australians can participate and ensure their rights are protected and enhanced. Any discussion should consider all the options including the matter of the head of state, States rights, the Australian flag and voluntary voting, an issue about which I feel quite passionate. Any changes, however, should only be made if they are in the best interests of all Australians and certainly not if they are in the best interests only of some megalomaniac hidden away in Canberra.

One of the great things about living in Australia is that it is a free country and that is how it should stay. Indeed, when I look at the make-up of my electorate I see a diverse ethnic mix with many immigrants coming to our great nation to escape homelands plagued by both religious and political persecution. They have come to a land of freedom, a country without oppression or serious friction, a country where they should be able to fulfil their dreams. They have found their safe harbour in Australia. That is how I want this country to stay. I am sure these new members to our country are proud they made their move and just as proud to now call themselves Australians.

In recent times many of our newer Australians have had to bear the tragedy of watching the destruction and disintegration of their former homes and the persecution and suffering of their relatives and friends. The fact that in the main they have not brought old conflicts and divisions to scar their new home, despite in some cases overwhelming temptation, does them and our nation great credit. In my campaign for Stirling, to have had the active support of people who formerly called home the nations of Europe, Africa, the Middle East, the CIS, Asia, South America, Canada, and the United States gave me great pleasure and great confidence in our country's future.

Prior to the Federal election we saw in my State of Western Australia a State election that rang out with the disgust of the people at the despicable way government had been managed in my State for the last 10 years. The voice of the people rang out loudly, over and over, with one clear statement—never again. Their trust in politicians has been eroded to the point where we rate lower in the credibility stakes than do dishonest hawkers and charlatans. It is a sobering reminder to all of us about our responsibilities as the representatives of the people.

The Federal election, too, very clearly showed the sentiments of the people of Western Australia. It has been published in the press that Western Australia is the most conservative State. One thing this Government must remember is that the people of Western Australia voted for change. They voted for the coalition and our vision for the future. They voted for the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) and his team. Because of this I would suggest to the House that, rather than being the most conservative State, Western Australia is the most progressive State in Australia.

Despite its success in the recent elections I still say to the Government that it should look dispassionately at what it has done and more particularly at what it did not do. We, the elected representatives of the people, must now become healers and builders. We must heal the pain that Australians from all walks of life have suffered over the last 10 years. We must heal the divisions that have been created in our society and bring back a sense of love for our country. We had it once, we can do it again. To do it we need to rebuild this nation. We need to rebuild and revitalise an economy battered by unscrupulous economic vandals. We have to assist a work force brought up on a philosophy of near enough is good enough. We have to assist a society made complacent by hand-outs and do-gooders. There is a whole generation of young people without dreams. That is the greatest tragedy of all. That is what we need to facilitate—dreams for the young.

We need to encourage those who would dream of a better future, a safer future for our kids. We need to encourage those who would dream of a compassionate and secure retirement for our seniors where law and order is not a dream but actually prevails. We need to have a country where there are real opportunities to live a productive and happy life. Let us show our young people by our example in this place that we who represent them dare to dream a vision of such breadth that their dreams for full and happy and useful lives are filled with certainty. Australia has the intellectual property—we have had it all along—and it is only by harnessing, nurturing and encouraging this invaluable asset that we can build a secure stairway to the bright future that all this country richly deserves.

I cannot hide my disappointment at the Government's inaction since 13 March. While I welcome a debate on the republic, it should not be the be-all and end-all of Government policy. It should not be a distraction. I am disappointed the Government has still failed to make the necessary changes to economic policy to alleviate the suffering of our unemployed and disenfranchised. They have taken our industrial relations policies because they were bereft of ideas. I urge them now to consider some of our economic policies which we knew had the right formula to pull us out of the recession and make Australia a leading and competitive nation.

The coalition has been wrongly stereotyped as a development at all costs party. This could not be further from the truth. I mentioned at the beginning of this speech that I had the wonderful support of my three children. They were part of the reason that I ran for this Parliament. I wanted to ensure the standard of living they inherited from us was better than our generation enjoyed. Economically, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has ensured that this will not occur. Environmentally—I cannot deny it—the Labor Party deserves some brownie points, although it has sabotaged many development projects simply to buy the support of the so-called green political parties in an attempt to win their preferences at elections.

There is no way that I or any of my colleagues would have any desire to harm our precious environment. I want my children, grandchildren and all future generations of Camerons to inherit an environment which is not harmed in any way. For that reason, I could not support policies which are environmentally destructive.
