When I was travelling around during this election campaign, I found to my horror that this booming industry was not only being stopped dead in its tracks, but at least half-a-dozen farms had been closed down because the water was going out into the ocean. Every country in the world, and most certainly in the Pacific, has a huge prawn and barramundi farming industry, and the only country in the world where effluent cannot be let out into the ocean is Australia. So another industry has been stopped dead in its tracks and, as far as we can quantify at the present moment, another 100 jobs have been lost.

We pleaded with the federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy on the TB eradication program, and at State level we, as a government, told the relevant department what to do, but then we were quarantined by the other States. We were brutalised, so we had to go along with the way the TB eradication program was going. It did not wipe it out. We have still got TB in our State. It did not wipe out TB, but it most certainly wiped out half a million head of cattle. Five meatworks closed. Two of them were in the electorate of Kennedy, and that threw another 500 men out of work. Just to add that up so far, that is 1,400 jobs lost in the electorate of Kennedy.

I have not finished yet. Century mine has announced that it is going to commence operations and it will employ 1,000 people. That has been widely canvassed in the press in Queensland, but because of environmental considerations and land rights legislation this project cannot go ahead at the present moment. So 1,000 jobs should be there, if not now, at least in the next 12 to 18 months, but they are not going to be there because the company is not moving at all. It is staying exactly where it is, and who can blame it?

If honourable members want to know why the country is in the state it is in, they should look no further than Shelbourne Bay. The Shelbourne Bay region has something like 70 dunes. One dune is blowing into the ocean. We can scientifically prove, without any equivocation, that the dune will not be there in 70 years time. Not one single grain of sand will be left. It does not take a scientist to work that out because the dune is already protruding about 100 metres into the ocean now. We export silicon at $55 a tonne. These figures are old. I think they date back to 1988. I apologise to the House for not updating them, but I am sure the relativities would be similar now.

We imported silicon as optical fibre product then at $3 million a tonne. Since it is 99.98 per cent pure going out, there is almost the same number of molecules or atoms going out as coming back in, except that it is re-formed. However, the $3 million stays in Japan, not Australia. When we attempted to develop that dune, we were told we could not because of environmental and other considerations. Honourable members should remember that we are talking about silicon. What coal was to the last century; what petrol has been to this century; please God, silicon will be to the next century.

I had the very great honour of putting the first solar energy, stand-alone power plant in the world into Coconut Island. It was amazingly successful. It was abandoned, of course, by the enlightened socialists who took over after us, costing the taxpayers of Queensland, I might add, an extra $8 million. That is what it costs to use diesel rather than solar power over a 25-year time frame in an isolated community. We export silicon at $55 a tonne, and it is imported into Australia as optical fibre, silicon chip, aerospace material, clean solar energy and glass. The silicon goes to Japan, and we then pay a fortune to buy it back. So honourable members should look no further than Shelbourne Bay.

Some 30 per cent of power is lost in sending it to North Queensland. So if the Tully-Millstream station is not built, 30 per cent of the power that is used in North Queensland is wasted. Also, we are short of power in North Queensland. It is a clean form of energy. I think it would be better to do it as pump storage rather than hydro, but the scheme has been stopped dead in its tracks. That is another 1,000 jobs lost to the Kennedy electorate. It was announced that that would go ahead, but it has been stopped. Another example is the Kirrama resort.
There is a roadway going to the Kirrama resort and 100 jobs are involved in its construction. That has also been stopped.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—The honourable member will have to conclude because his time has just about expired.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. There are one million people being paid not to work. A very great Australian, the person I most admire in Australian politics, Edward Theodore, in this House said, `Let us pay people to work rather than not to work'. One of the things he said was, `Let us build the Bradfield scheme'. We have people having their crops destroyed. We have people out here whose land is ravaged by drought. Let us build it. It is not a dream. Those are documents prepared by some of the most qualified engineering firms in Australia. (Time expired)

—I must admit I came to this debate unprepared but what I want to do is talk about what I see as Australia's greatest challenge. I actually wrote a paper on this some time ago. Australia has faced many challenges in the past. I guess the first great challenge this nation faced was the First World War when arguably the First and Second AIF constituted the greatest soldiers this nation has ever seen. Many were slaughtered and that denied to Australia a lot of the leadership that should have been here for the development of this country.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to reflect when people try to divide history and divide a culture that the First and Second AIF contained in their ranks many soldiers who were actually born in the United Kingdom. In fact, at Gallipoli, where Australia performed enormously well, one-third of our soldiers were born in the United Kingdom. It is also not widely known or recognised in Australia that the losses suffered by Britain in that battle were twice as high as ours. That was a great loss to Australia because it took away the leadership that should have been here after the war. I believe it was one of the greatest losses we have ever suffered.

The next great challenge we faced was the Depression where we had massive unemployment. A third of the work force was unemployed in this country. I think the third challenge was undoubtedly the Second World War. The fourth challenge, while not being as visible, will probably be more important to the future character of this nation than any of the other three. I refer to the coming battle between the nationalists and the internationalists.

One of the sad things is that those who often pose as nationalists are in fact internationalists who are seeking to tie us to treaties with other nations. They seek to lock us into international obligations which are primarily not in the interests of Australia or, I might add, the interests of the Australian people.

I think there are men of honour on both sides. There are people on the internationalist's side who truly feel that Australia has no other option other than to lock itself into being a part of something else. This is a continuation of the cultural cringe. This harks back to our first great conflict, the First World War, when we lost that strata of leadership. Prior to the First World War this view did not exist in Australia. This was a proud nation, this was a nation where the Australian tail used to wag the British dog. Foreign policy in this part of the world was made by Australia.

An example of that, of course, is Mabo. It was not Britain that annexed the Murray Islands. Britain wanted nothing to do with them. They were annexed by the State of Queensland in 1859. It was done against the wishes of the British. They simply went along with it because Australia demanded it. Quite clearly the Murray Islanders are of a different culture to Australian Aborigines. They are a Melanesian culture and in the Melanesian culture there is a history of land tenure.

I take issue with a lot of the evidence given in the Mabo case. I think it was probably fairly suspect. The concept of terra nullius did not mean there were no people in Australia. That is a nonsense, of course there were people here. But everywhere the British went, be it New Zealand, Malaysia, India, North America or Fiji, they signed treaties with the natives.

They signed treaties because that was their modus operandi. That has its own problems, and we have seen those in North America and New Zealand, but that was the way they operated. The instruction to governors-general in Australia was always to sign treaties. The reason they did not was that there was no structure under which to sign them.

It is also true that, in large parts of this nation, there was simply no Aboriginal habitation. I was involved in the opening of the Nullarbor, the last great pastoral development Australia will ever see; there will never be another one. When I went to that area in 1960, there were no kangaroos on the Nullarbor, for the same reason that there had been no Aboriginal habitation—because there was no water. Within four years of putting the bores down on the Nullarbor, a man could shoot 100 kangaroos a night. In the late 1970s, to survive, I did so.

I believe that, if we are to have a truly independent Australia, we must have full employment in this country. We cannot have full employment without industry policy. Anyone who tells people that we can have jobs for our kids without manufacturing in this country is simply lying or, of course, stupid. They are not mutually exclusive; they could be both. I believe that we have to look very carefully to this manufacturing industry, and it has to be recreated in Australia.

The problem we have in Australia today is simply this: as the economy improves—and it is always going to be cyclical in nature—immediately there is wealth in the community it is used to suck in imports because there is no manufacturing capacity in Australia. We can ask ourselves why. Both political parties must take blame for the reason. In the days of Malcolm Fraser the exchange rate was kept artificially high, which simply drove manufacturing industry to the wall. We had years of irrational high-tariff policies. I am not a high-tariff protectionist, but I do believe in the support of Australian industry.

Nowadays, we have the level playing field, for which my party must take some responsibility. This too has decimated Australian industry, for there is no level playing field; and we have seen other nations who do not pay lip service to this nonsense thrive at our expense. I think we have to get much smarter in the assistance to industry. In terms of exports of manufacturing goods, our achievements have been considerable. I think the 18 per cent compound growth over the last 10 years is creditable, but it came from a very small base. A large part of it is motor vehicle offsets. There are some good endeavours. Shipbuilding is an excellent example. I was depressed to see in the Governor-General's speech that we are going to reduce the shipbuilding bounty, for I have a view that one should give assistance to the industries which are effective.

If we are to get to manufacturing industry in this country, we have to change some of the ethos. The problem is not wages. I can tell the people of Australia this: if the wages of this country were halved, we would not create massive employment in this country; we would not create a mass of jobs at all. One of the problems is the availability of capital. People talk about the high savings rate in Japan and how this was the engine that drove the Japanese economy, and I will concede that there probably is a greater ethos to save in Japan. This is substantially because the Japanese have an appalling social security system whereby people have to supply their own because there is no government provided safety net. So people have to save.

But there was another issue. The Japanese kept very tight control of currency. They did not allow money to leave the country. Had they done so in the early 1950s, Japanese money would have fled Japan to other countries where returns were greater. The money was forced to stay in Japan. I believe that this country would be well advised to look at currency controls to control the outflow of currency from this country, to force the people to keep their money in this country.

If people want to take their money out of the country they should have to have a very good reason for it. If they can convince people that there is a good reason, then it would be okay and they would be permitted to do so, but generally we should have currency controls to keep the money in the country, to make it available to industry here. One of the great costs of an industry is capital equipment. Without that, there is going to be no competition. The average age of machinery in Australian factories is getting into the eight- to 10-year range. In Korea it is two years. That is where the productivity lies. It does not lie in cutting wages; that is simply not the answer.

If we are going to build a united country in Australia it is important that we look at some of the problems that are working against this. I have heard just about every speaker in this House applaud multiculturalism, but what do we mean by multiculturalism? What I mean when I talk about multiculturalism is officially sanctioned and funded multiculturalism. I abhor that sort of multiculturalism; I think it is dividing this nation. I believe that if it were put to a vote of the people of Australia it would be overwhelmingly rejected.

I come here as the member of an electorate which has a very large migrant constituency, one of the largest in Australia, and I have overwhelming support from migrants. The reason most migrants come to Australia is for the benefit of their children, and these migrants want to be Australians. Many of them reject being closeted and told, `No, you can't be a real Australian, you've got to be an ethnic'. I find that situation intolerable. I believe that anyone who comes to Australia should come here with a commitment to this nation, to being Australians and to making this their home. If they lack that commitment, I think we are entitled to say to them, `Why are you here? We have no need for you'. Truly I believe that Australia has no need for people who have no commitment to this country.

Looking at the immigration program generally, I believe that for environmental reasons, for social cohesion and pure economics, it is time to reduce immigration to this country. We have seen the Triads imported to Australia through the business migration scheme. The cost of this to the nation and to each of us individually is enormous, if it were calculable—we do not really know what the cost is, but it is clearly enormous. It has done nothing for the benefit of this country. We are told we need these people to enhance our trade with Asia. Ironically, of course, our trade with Hong Kong has dropped dramatically since we have had this large influx. It seems to me that there is never any scrutiny of the arguments that are used to sustain high levels of immigration.

What is the effect of the importation of skills? The effect is to promote migrants over Australians and to deny Australians training in those skills. If we are going to build a nation it is far better to train our people to make sure that they have the necessary skills. But this is part of the cultural cringe I have talked about: the cringe that has developed that it must be better overseas; the cringe that used to be directed towards Britain and the United States is now directed towards Asia. It is a nonsense. I have a friend who is the chief pilot for a large organisation which provides technical services. This company is a world leader that has expanded across the world and it has opened branches in America. My friend said to me, `When I knew we were going to America I thought, "I will really have to be on my metal now because this is the absolute peak of aviation", but when I got there I found the standards were abysmal, that if I could get Australian pilots in there—which I can't because of work permits—I could increase my company's productivity by 200 or 300 per cent'. Yet how many people would look to Australia as the peak of aviation and to Australian pilots as being the most competent in this technical field?

I have another very good friend in Kalgoorlie who is a mining engineer, probably one of Australia's best mining engineers, particularly in the area of difficult mining and deep shaft construction. He is British but he has mined all over Europe, Africa and Australia. He said to me that he will get a job done in Australia quicker, safer and cheaper than anywhere else in the world. He said it is not because Australians work harder—in fact, he gives that to the Irish—but he says they work safer and smarter and they show the initiative required. He said he can do a job with two men less on the platform, which is important in shaft sinking because of the constraints of room. I think this international view is a credit to us. Yet how often do we hear that we must import these skills because somehow we are inferior? I abhor this cringe which Australia has developed. It is unnecessary and it has done a lot of damage, and it is being used today.

We are now being told that we must move into part of the Asian sphere. Now, I believe in trade with Asia. I go to China a lot and the Chinese do not think they are Asian; they look upon themselves as Chinese or Han people. They have a healthy disrespect for a lot of other Asians. They like us precisely because we are not Asian; they see us as a non-threatening Western technology nation. If Australia is going to trade successfully we must trade with the world. The world is our oyster. We must supply the world in those things which we are particularly good at producing.

There are going to be trade barriers raised against us but they will not be raised in some of the areas vital to Australia's trade. We will sell our minerals because we are the world's best miners. We provide competitive price and quality product. In other areas it will not be so easy. We must seek other alternatives. But I say now that manufacturing export industry is simply not enough for Australia. What we need is import replacement. If we had that import replacement industry, our improving economy would not be sucking in the overseas exports that we are doing now and compounding our current account deficit.

I am in the process of writing another paper, an interminable and an unrewarding job in this place, because for backbenchers it is hard work, lacking the resources, and, with media that do not pay much attention to other than the frontbenchers of either side, it is a disillusioning business. But I put it to honourable members now that we ought to think along these lines. In Queensland we have proven resources of oil 25 times the size of Bass Strait, enormous resources of proven oil, in shale. Those shale oil resources, because of Australian technology, are now buyable at about $24 a barrel. I saw the price of North Sea oil at $20.80 a barrel the other day—not that far off the marked price. That is about the equivalent to our Bass Strait high quality oil, the same high quality oil which you can get from shale oil.

If we were to forgo excise on the sale of oil, we could deliver petrol to petrol bowsers at the same price as, or probably marginally cheaper than, we can now. Forgoing that excise would be of very good use, unlike the Liberal Party's intention to simply throw it away and waste it and obviously get the money from somewhere else. This would be very constructive because we would turn energy from a narrow, highly capital intensive industry into one which employed a lot of people.

If we were to decide as a nation that we were going to develop our oil resources from this area, it would have an important impact on manufacturing industry. Heavy industry would blossom to provide the plant and equipment to do this. It would take time and improvements would be incremental. As the availability of shale oil improved on the market the Government would reap its benefit from pay-as-you-earn taxpayers rather than from excise on the oil. The Government would not be out of pocket in the long run, we would have unemployment on the way down and we would have something that was developing cohesion in this nation.

We would also make available, of course, our Bass Strait oil for export. The Fraser Government introduced world parity pricing. The real reason for it was to get more revenue, but it was applauded by the oil companies because they got more money, and what is going to happen now, under this scenario, is that they can export to the world. We will always sell our oil on the world market because it is good quality oil and the world would like to deal with us. There would be no trouble selling it. We would have to accept the world price, but I would estimate, and it is a ballpark figure, that we are spending something in excess of $25 billion a year on oil. If that were made available for export income, we then clearly would have the growth in the current account deficit beaten.

There are many other areas in which we should take these initiatives. We will not take these initiatives unless we have a united Australia confident in itself and confident in its future. If we are prepared to face the world clear-eyed and unafraid, we will survive. We will not survive as a nation by grovelling to others, by seeking to tie ourselves to the skirt strings of other nations or other groups. We must survive on our own ability as a nation. We must look to the world for those challenges.

There is no embargo, for instance, on horticultural products into the Common Market. There is absolutely no reason why we could not be exporting horticultural products into Europe. We have developed the technologies so that these things can be sent fresh by boat, reducing the cost. Just think of this: the world's greatest market for table grapes is the United Kingdom; it imports $1 billion worth a year. It would like to import them from Australia. Why the hell are we not selling them, because they are paying twice the price that prevails in this country? There is there, I hope, Mr Deputy Speaker, some food for thought, and I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his speech on the occasion of the opening of the 37th Parliament, His Excellency the Governor-General stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is essential for the economy as a whole that we make the most efficient use of our transport infrastructure and that a national focus be given to this matter.
He went on to say further:
Funding for roads of national importance will lead to the lowering of transport costs.

Mr Deputy Speaker, may I therefore take the opportunity to criticise in the strongest terms actions taken by the previous Labor Party Government, led by the present Prime Minister, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), and the then Minister for roads, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), regarding their punitive attitude to the Liberal State of Victoria and their favoured treatment of the Labor States of Queensland and South Australia, as well as the Prime Minister's own State of New South Wales, on the topic of road funding.

PARA.TAB: Victoria's significance to the national economy is enormous, as is reflected in the following statistics obtained from Vic Roads on 28 April 1993. The State's gross domestic product—GDP—is 27 per cent of Australia's GDP. Victoria's population of 4.3 million makes up 26 per cent of the national population. The State's share of national employment is approximately 26 per cent. Victoria generates about one-third of the export of products which are most important for long-term economic growth. Manufacturing is the main employment sector in Melbourne, while Melbourne is the largest employment centre in Australia for the manufacturing sector. The port of Melbourne handles 44 per cent of containers moving through capital city ports. Finally, Victoria attracts one-third of visitors to Australia.

Resultant upon these statistics, road transport in Victoria is a significant factor in the cost of providing the services and products that contribute to Australia's international trade, accounting for up to 15 per cent of the total delivered price of commodities. Reduction of transport costs represents one of the few real opportunities to directly lower costs for our export goods and import replacements, thereby improving Australia's international competitiveness and improving our balance of trade. To do this, Victoria requires targeted investment in its road transport systems.

One would have expected the Commonwealth Government, being doubtless aware of the strategic importance of Victoria to the well-being of the nation's economy, to deal impeccably and without fear or favour regarding its projected road funding program. Indeed, the 1993 land transport strategy, a document produced by the Federal Department of Transport and Communications under the previous Minister, the honourable member for Charlton, states just that. On page 34, in the section relating to the redefinition of road responsibilities, it claims:

SPEECH.PARA: These changed responsibilities will encourage greater accountability and strengthen the direct link between revenue raising and spending.

No such direct link between revenue raising and spending exists under the proposed distribution of untied funds in accordance with financial assistance grants formulae. Despite the fact that 27 per cent of total travel on Australian roads occurs in Victoria, including 35 per cent of the national interstate road freight, which is expected to double in the next decade; and despite the fact that Victorian motorists contribute 27 per cent of the federal fuel excise revenues used for road funding, in 1992-93 Victoria received only just under 20 per cent of total Commonwealth road funds, being 12.3 per cent of the national highway funds and 27.6 per cent of other allocations.

PARA.TAB: This allocation was despite there being additional funds provided through the Government's One Nation initiative, the accident black spots program and urban transport and provincial cities and rural highways programs. This is bad enough, but there is worse to come. Indicative budget advice to Vic Roads, received from the Federal Minister in January, suggests that Victoria will receive only 19 per cent of the total Commonwealth road funds in 1993-94—10.2 per cent of national highway funds and 34.8 per cent of other allocations. That will decrease to as low as 13 per cent in 1997-98—11.8 per cent of national highway funds and 20.4 per cent of other allocations—when the revised federal road funding arrangements are fully implemented.

I will explain what is probably known to some people in this place, but may not be known to the community at large. The former road classification system, which ended in December of this year, consisted of, firstly, national highways. These are the main highways of Australia—for example, the Hume Highway, the Western Highway and the Sturt Highway. The Commonwealth Government has total responsibility, including financial responsibility, for these—including the corridors surrounding the highways, involving construction, overpasses, land surrounding the highways and so on.

The next category is that of national arterial roads. An example of this is Melbourne's Eastern Freeway, which presently runs almost to my own electorate of Deakin. In this category, the Commonwealth Government had only limited responsibility but still provided funding for these projects. Proposed change in funding arrangements will severely curtail such projects. The national arterial roads funding arrangements will be replaced by untied Federal grants for road building, known as the financial assistance grants system—FAGS.

Under the old system, in assessing priorities between States and intrastate, economic necessity was the criterion. For example, such considerations as connections to industry, value to local communities, usage of roads, et cetera, were taken into account. Under the new FAGS, economic criteria is no longer of any importance. There was an allusion to this in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement, but it had been discussed at the special Premiers Conference in July 1991, at which time it was mooted that the sum of $350 million should be committed to the States in untied grants. This was to be discussed at a Premiers conference in November, which was never actually held.

A letter was sent by the Prime Minister to the Premiers, dated 5 June 1992, in which the decision concerning new funding arrangements was conveyed. The official bureaucratic justification at the federal level of the new funding arrangement, FAGS, is that funds are limited and it does not have the resources to fully evaluate national arterial road projects using economic criteria. In fact, this is a wonderful cop-out to allow funds to be averted away from economic necessity to political expediency; away from the Liberal State of Victoria, my own State, to the Labor States of Queensland and South Australia—not forgetting New South Wales, which may be Liberal, State-wise, but also is the federal domain of the Prime Minister.

The detrimental effect of the new road funding arrangements on Victoria is obvious from statistics already mentioned. Perhaps the most blatant example of discrimination is the fact that, although Victoria pays 27 per cent of the national fuel tax bill, ultimately, it will only be reimbursed for 13 per cent of Commonwealth total road funding.

However, there are more detailed statistics contained in graphs prepared by Vic Roads, which I will later seek permission to incorporate in Hansard. Those entitled `Victoria's contribution and share of total Commonwealth funding' and `Commonwealth road grants—Victoria' are of particular significance. The charts showing the proposed new funding arrangements on the road systems surrounding the cities of Melbourne and Geelong show the devastating effects of funding cuts. As a result of these cuts, the Sturt Highway upgrading cannot commence for five years; the Goulburn Valley Highway upgrading cannot commence for four years; the Western Highway upgrading cannot commence, and so on.

Around Melbourne, the arterial road systems have suffered even more substantially. The Springvale bypass cannot proceed; the Scoresby Freeway cannot commence within the next five years; the Western Ring Road is delayed for at least two years; and the extension of the Eastern Freeway, which will run through my own electorate of Deakin, is substantially slowed.

In the Melbourne Age of 5 May of this year, the Victorian Government Treasurer, the honourable Alan Stockdale, raised doubts over the future of the city freeway links despite a new 3c per litre petrol levy by the Kennett Government to start on 1 July. This will raise more than $150 million a year for roadworks in Victoria. The dramatic cuts in federal road building grants already mentioned are expected to leave the State well short of funding requirements for up to 10 planned major road projects.

If the expected Federal cuts eventuate, Victoria will have only $17 million extra for road building in the 1993-94 financial year and this is despite the controversial 3c per litre levy on petrol and diesel fuel raising

SPEECH.PARA: $157 million. Mr Stockdale has rightly expressed confidence that the Federal Government would deliver a better financial deal for Victoria than predicted. I might add that it is certainly to be hoped that the new federal Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, the senator for the Northern Territory, will review the situation as soon as possible and adopt more just criteria in the apportioning of road grants, based on economic need, than was done by his predecessor.

PARA.TAB: The honourable senator should do this because there is a clear argument that, based on Victoria's contribution to the national road freight task, 35 per cent of national road funds should be directed to the State. Based on Victoria's contribution to national road based revenues, at least 27 per cent of Federal road funding should be directed to this State. Victoria's forward programs included in this report have been developed on this latter basis. Any allocation less than this figure would be undermining Australia's national economic performance. In conclusion, Mr Deputy Speaker, I seek leave to have two of the graphs I referred to incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 March the Australian people, certainly in my view, turned their backs on the policies of division and instead chose the policies of inclusion. Let there be no mistake, the Opposition's Fightback package was nothing less than a full-frontal attack on the values which have made Australia great, and the ideal of a fair go for all. The policies which the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) took into the last election can only be described as extremist, including, as they did, the introduction of a GST on almost every good and service, the abolition of the award system and its replacement with individual contracts and the abolition of Medicare.

PARA.TAB: Of course, since March 13, the Opposition has had the arrogance to infer that the Australian people got it wrong by falling for what they characterise as a Government scare campaign. Of course, it is the Opposition and not the Australian people who has got it very wrong. Honourable members opposite should have realised that the Australian people would never support policies that would divide Australia into the haves and the have-nots. It should also have realised that Australians would not allow the dismantling of Medicare, one of the finest health systems in the world, to have it replaced by an American style system.

Above all else, the Opposition should have realised that the people would never buy its miserable 15 per cent tax on almost everything, which would have changed the whole way Australians live their lives. It is interesting how quickly Opposition members are now keen to say that they never really supported the GST at all. However, I fail to recall many occasions during the life of the previous Parliament when Opposition members had the courage to stand in this House and condemn the Opposition Leader's policies of division.

March 13 was not only a great day for the Australian Labor Party nationally, it was certainly a great day for the Australian Labor Party in my electorate. The people of the Oxley electorate turned their backs on the coalition's reactionary policies and there was a swing of the order of two per cent to the Australian Labor Party. It is certainly a great honour to continue to represent the people of the Oxley electorate in this place, and I would like to place on record my many thanks to them for their support, not only on election day but also over the five years that I have been the member for Oxley. My top priority during this next term will be to continue to ensure that the Ipswich region, which I proudly represent, receives the full benefits of the programs of the Keating Government, which have been clearly outlined in the Governor-General's speech.

I particularly thank the many party supporters and friends who ensured that the Australian Labor Party received such an excellent result in the Oxley electorate. My special thanks go particularly to my federal division executive, my campaign director, Joel Mafi, and his campaign committee.

The Governor-General's address at the opening of the 37th Parliament on Tuesday, 4 May, outlined the Labor Government's policy priorities over the next three years. As was made clear in the speech, this Government's primary goal over its next term will be to achieve sustained reductions in the level of unemployment, and I am sure that is something that we all agree with. We as a government recognise that long-term unemployment has a particularly damaging impact not only on the individuals concerned but also on the wider society. Contrary to the Opposition's claims during the last Federal election, the Australian economy is now in recovery and beginning to grow again. The greatest challenge we will face over the next three years will be to ensure that the long-term unemployed receive assistance to get back into the work force as the economy picks up pace.

Over the past 10 years the Government has introduced a whole range of programs designed to assist the unemployed in re-entering the labour market. Indeed, it was the Labor Government which established the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Last year the Government made a number of important announcements in the area of vocational education and training. Following the youth employment and training summit convened by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) last year, the Government announced a national employment and training plan for young Australians. It is estimated that some 96,000 young people will be assisted by this $700 million package in 1993. Among the measures announced by the Prime Minister was the career start traineeship, which provides young people with the opportunity to combine work and training to increase their skills and enhance their career prospects.

The landcare and environment action program, better known as LEAP, which provides 15- to 20-year-olds with work and vocational training on projects which help to preserve our environmental heritage, is one of those many programs. Under LEAP young people are provided with up to 26 weeks of vocationally relevant training and work, including field experience, in areas of land care, conservation, environmental protection and cultural heritage. Those are all very important areas in my own electorate, including the city of Ipswich. It is a very old city, certainly the oldest provincial city in Queensland, and heritage is one of those things that we protect very strongly.

In addition to the measures contained in the national employment and training program for young Australians, a number of programs targeted at the older unemployed were announced in last year's Budget. Several local organisations in the electorate of Oxley, including some skillshare programs—MATES, mainly for the mature age training employment service; Goodna HUGS, the help unemployment Goodna skillshare; workventure; and the Ipswich YUPI skillshare program—have taken advantages of programs offered by the Government to provide quality training programs to the unemployed. These organisations have been quite successful in helping unemployed people from the Ipswich region back into the work force, and I put on record here my thanks and congratulations to them all for the work that they are doing in assisting these people to get back into the work force.

While as a whole the Government's labour market programs have been quite successful, it is important that the effectiveness of these measures is constantly reviewed to ensure that resources are not wasted. I am sure that all honourable members will therefore welcome the Prime Minister's announcement on Monday that the Government will review all labour market programs to ensure that funds go to areas that will create the most jobs.

It is important that all sections of the community, the business community, the trade union movement, existing trainers and other concerned community groups, are consulted during this process of review, so that the Government can develop a solution to the issue of unemployment, and I know—

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: House of Representatives: Number of Sitting Days

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we get into the start of the 37th Parliament and as I see the new faces around the corridors of this great House, my grievance today is for the continuing disregard for the institution of parliament shown by this Keating Labor Government. The House of Representatives will meet for only nine days for this autumn session. In fact, the peoples' House will meet for a total of nine days in a period of eight months. I believe this is scandalous and, at a time when the public's reaction to the parliamentary process can be said to be lukewarm at best, the Government yet again displays its arrogance in regard to the institution of parliament.

PARA.TAB: Despite the speech made in this House by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) earlier this week, one should not be surprised at his arrogance if one examines the track record of the Hawke-Keating Government. However, it is not in terms of the number of sitting days that the Government's attitude is displayed. In other ways successive Labor governments have sought to undermine the authority of parliament. The refusal to make major policy announcements in the House and the abuse of Question Time which has caused the new Speaker to make statements about desirable and necessary changes are but two examples.

I want to drawn the House's attention to this Government's complete and utter disregard of the role of parliament in terms of the number of sitting days. The fact that this House will meet for only nine days in a period of eight months is indeed scandalous, for which the Government deserves to be soundly condemned. Although charged with the duty of responsible and representative government by this country, the Keating Labor Government persists in undermining the very institution of parliament. A mere nine days this autumn session is clear testament to this. There is no excuse for such a paucity of parliamentary sittings and the nine days is simply not enough if one is to examine the proposed legislative program.

The use of the guillotine in this House has been brought to an art form by the Labor Government. Proper parliamentary scrutiny of proposed legislation is going to suffer. Presumably we will, yet again, be faced with the ridiculous situation of all night sittings. Why? Because of the Government's inability to sort out its own legislative timetable.

The Australian public deserves better than this. They deserve the right to know that their elected representatives will be granted sufficient time to enable a thorough examination of legislation, particularly as it relates to their individual electorates. Honourable members must have the right to be afforded the opportunity to have their own input in regard to proposed legislation. They deserve the right to expect that legislation passed by this House would be free of errors, omissions or oversights, which unfortunately occur through haste.

Sadly this Government has denied not only these fundamental rights but the expectations of the ordinary community as well. What opportunity does an individual have in expressing his or her views in regard to proposed legislation when a Bill is presented and passed in the same night, as has been the case when the guillotine is in operation?

The lack of sitting days is a clear reason why the House is placed in this predicament. This House's ability to have the time to scrutinise legislation, debate issues of national importance and raise issues of concern to constituents is a critical aspect of the democratic process. Reductions in the amount of time that this House sits must mean that the democratic process suffers, and that forms the basis of my grievance today.

I expect that the Government will cite the federal election as the reason for the ridiculously low number of sitting days this year. To use the 1990 sitting pattern as a guide, which, of course, was another election year, then it is highly likely that the House will sit for fewer than 40 days this year, and this would be one of the lowest number of sitting days since Federation.

The lowest number of sitting days for any year was in 1937. Strangely, that was also an election year when the House sat for a mere 29 days. In 1990 the House sat for only 38 days, which does not set a good precedent for 1993. Given that we had an election in March, as was the case in 1990, then I would reasonably expect that the sitting pattern for this year would resemble that of 1990.

Should this be so, then it is not unreasonable to expect that this House will meet for the lowest number of days since pre-war times. There is simply no excuse for this. In the past when there had been a federal election, governments managed to arrange a suitable number of sitting days. One has only to go back two elections to 1987. In that year, in spite of the federal election being held, the total number of sitting days was 74. This number was in fact one of the highest since the mid-1970s, when the three years of the Whitlam Labor Government saw a high average of 71 sitting days.

To make further comparisons, one has only to go to the 1983 parliamentary year when, despite a March election, Parliament was able to sit for 49 days. I would suggest this means an extra fortnight's sitting compared with the total for the 1990 year. The simple fact of the matter is that, despite the Government's protestations about the federal election necessarily reducing the total number of sitting days, this is simply not true, and past sitting patterns attest to this.

I am reminded at this time of a remark from the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, with regard to the low number of sitting days. At the end of the 1990 Budget session of parliament, Mr Hawke proceeded to tell the House:

SPEECH.PARA: that this Government has not at any time attempted to reduce for political ends the number of sitting days available to this House.

My colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) interjected at the time, `What rubbish!', and I am inclined to agree with that comment. There is no doubt that successive Labor governments have manipulated the parliamentary program in a manner which has undermined the parliamentary process and the esteem in which this House is held in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: It is utterly stupid that this autumn session of parliament should conclude on 27 May. Why we are not extending our meetings at least until the middle of June I do not know, and there has been no explanation—unless, of course, we are meeting an undeclared timetable of the Prime Minister and his senior Ministers for trips overseas. Whatever it is, one cannot get over the inescapable fact that the Parliament is being downgraded. As the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said in his speech on Tuesday:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the number of sitting days should be increased so that we have time to consider legislation properly and so that we will all work more sensible hours when the Parliament is sitting. That is also fundamental to good government.

I also draw the House's attention to the Labor Government's reluctance to announce major policy items in the House; rather it announces them on the hustings. It is a habit that has been developed by the Labor Party of not making announcements in this House. This means that there is no opportunity, therefore, for proper parliamentary discussion on the issue, whatever it may be. Prime Minister Hawke became a past master at this, and the present Prime Minister is proving an apt pupil and is following in the same way. Not only have we had to go through the debacle of pay television decisions and announcements, but we have also seen the nonsense of the position of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on the Labor pledge to remove aged pensioners from the tax system by 1995. All these decisions were made outside the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: So, despite the fine speech made by Mr Speaker on his accession to that role, which we on this side of the Parliament give every encouragement to him to carry out, we have some fairly vital decisions to make. Firstly, this House should sit for more days and at more sensible hours. Secondly, the Government must make all policy decisions within the Parliament itself, thus allowing a proper debate on the issues. This has been one of the real traditions of the Australian Federal Parliament. Lastly, we must see that the House is conducted with decorum, with a vast improvement in the playing of the issues and not of the man. Until these three suggestions are met, it is my sad prediction that the role of the Federal Parliament will continue to diminish, and that the attitude of the Australian community to members of this Parliament will continue to worsen.

TALK.START.PARA: —People in Australia who live in urban communities such as major metropolitan cities have come to understand that life in an urban environment does involve a number of problems and a number of issues, and the issue that I wish to talk about this afternoon is the question of noise. I represent a seat in urban Brisbane, in the southern suburbs, and my constituents suffer from a number of noise problems, which they have come to understand are part and parcel of living in a major city. We are, unfortunately, besieged on a regular basis by traffic noise from road vehicles, and by railway noise because of movement of freight and passenger trains. Last, but by no means least, a considerable amount of noise is generated by the movement of aircraft, both in landings and in take-offs, and it is this particular element that I wish to address in my remarks today.

PARA.TAB: My electorate is in the unenviable position of having an airport within its boundaries, Archerfield airport, a secondary airport in Brisbane which is mainly used for commuter traffic. It is also in the flight path of most of the planes arriving and departing from Brisbane airport. Because of that, the constituents in most of the suburbs of my electorate experience unsatisfactory levels of aircraft noise from time to time. Most of them probably moved in after the establishment of Archerfield airport, so one might say they have no-one to blame but themselves if they are prepared to move into suburbs which come close to Archerfield airport, since it was there first.

However, when they moved into the environs of Archerfield airport, there was a curfew on Archerfield and planes were prevented from departing after 11 p.m. and did not start again until 6 a.m. the next day. That curfew has now been removed and there is heavy traffic in the very early hours of the morning, at about 2 a.m. or 3 a.m. in particular, which is commuter traffic bringing materials and business papers from provincial cities of Queensland through Brisbane to Sydney. The residents of Oxley have suffered, I believe, unnecessary and undue hardship because of the level of aircraft noise that is generated by the fact that Archerfield airport is now an open airport.

I understand the needs of the business community to have maximum use of that airport and the greater efficiencies that that entails for aviation and for transportation, but it is a problem for the living standards and the quality of life for the residents of my electorate in the suburbs that border Archerfield airport. I think it is an issue that we need to be considering.

The major issue that I wish to talk about this afternoon, however, is air traffic movements from Brisbane airport and a proposal that has been included in the original development plans for Brisbane airport which the Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation appear to be still committed to. The new Brisbane airport was opened in 1988. Since that time it has been a major cause of concern to the residents on the south side of Brisbane because, once Brisbane Airport opened, air traffic changed its direction and movements over Brisbane. Prior to the opening in 1988, most of the air traffic moved over Moreton Bay to land at Eagle Farm. Now most of the air traffic movements are over the southern suburbs of Brisbane, so that the residents of my electorate of Moreton and that of my neighbouring colleague, the honourable member for Griffith (Mr Humphreys), have suffered an enormous increase in aircraft noise due to the new airport. When it was first being planned we were told that Brisbane airport would involve most aircraft flying over the bay, but that has not come to pass, mainly because of the orientation of the major runway.

In September 1991 I made a speech in this House concerning the need for the development of a cross-runway. There is already a cross-runway in the Brisbane airport but it is only a short runway of 1,400 metres and not large enough for large aircraft. Therefore, all of the large aircraft, the major passenger aircraft and particularly the 747s, have to land on the main runway, the 01/19 runway, which entails flying over the southern suburbs of Brisbane. In that speech in September 1991 I made a strong plea for the extension of the existing cross-runway. I repeat that plea today. I believe it is very important that that cross-runway be developed, not just for the alleviation of noise but also to reduce the safety concerns that we have with regard to the existing 01/19 runway.

The problem with Brisbane airport is that the cross-winds that flow across it create some enormous safety risks from time to time on the 01/19 runway, and we have evidence that such risks have occurred in the past on a number of occasions. The major prevailing wind across Brisbane airport is from the south-east and the aircraft would be better served if they were able to land on the cross-runway rather than on the main runway, because that would be in line with the prevailing wind and would not create enormous cross-wind pressure for them.

Recently we have seen evidence that CAA and FAC are intent on building a parallel runway to the 01/19 runway. That would increase the noise and safety problems that we suffer with Brisbane airport. I have campaigned strongly, and I will continue to do so, against the construction of a parallel runway, not only because of the impact it will have on my constituents but also because of the risks that it will create for the whole of Brisbane. It is my very firm view that we should be moving as fast as we can to take most of the passenger aircraft movements away from the built-up city area and over Moreton Bay so that there is a reduction in aircraft movements that impact on the built-up area.

The proposal by the CAA to construct a parallel runway is something that we need to oppose strenuously. There is already an existing cross-runway that can be extended from 1,400 metres to 2,600 metres at a much lower cost to FAC and CAA than the building of a new parallel runway of 3,200 metres. I have been told by the CAA that a 2,600-metre cross-runway would not be sufficient, and yet I find that the third runway being built at Sydney airport is in fact a runway of 2,600 metres. If a length of 2,600 metres is sufficient to deal with Sydney airport's needs, I can see no reason why a similar runway would not be sufficient for Brisbane's needs.

With the demise of the third major carrier, a number of funding opportunities now present themselves to allow the immediate upgrading of the cross-runway in Brisbane. A number of projects scheduled by the CAA for redevelopment of other airports were contingent upon there being a third major domestic carrier. Now that that is not proceeding and the development of a third major carrier in the near future seems unlikely, I believe that there are funds available to enable the cross-runway development to occur at Brisbane airport immediately. That development has importance for reducing noise impacts over the city of Brisbane and for eliminating some safety risks that I think we now have with the major use of the main runway. It would also enable Brisbane airport to cope with the increased usage that it is going to be facing over the next decade.

The current proposal is not to build a new runway for at least another 15 years. I believe that the increase in air traffic movements over Brisbane is going to warrant some expansion in its facilities long before that. We have an ideal opportunity to utilise the savings that have been made available to us because there is not the need now to proceed with the developments proposed to take account of Compass. We can transfer those funds to the development of a new cross-runway and ensure that the people of Brisbane no longer have to suffer the major noise impacts that they do from Brisbane airport. I shall be taking these matters up with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), who has been a very understanding and sympathetic Minister who has tried to do what he can to help the people of Brisbane. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some 172,000 expatriate British retirees in Australia who have become permanent residents. The majority of them have made the decision so that they can spend their remaining days in contact with their families. Most were typically in their late 60s when they decided to leave Britain and had directly, or through a breadwinner spouse, paid taxes in the UK and contributed to its national insurance scheme for the duration of their working lives. On average, these tax and insurance contributions have been made over nearly 50 years.

PARA.TAB: Most of the 172,000 ex-Brits of whom I speak left Britain at the very ages at which they might reasonably be expected to draw more frequently on the UK health and ancillary services, thereby adding to the usage and the strain on the services. For those people, the costs and strain have become a cost for all Australian taxpayers to bear. The burden is simultaneously lifted from the British Chancellor of the Exchequer, as is the duty of care from Westminster, and transported to Australia. Transportation thus takes on a whole new meaning. The people are probably a whole lot more worthy now than in the 18th century, but the costs to us, arguably, are not.

Given that this situation is unlikely to change while Australia continues to admit Britons under our family reunion program, surely it behoves the British Government to concede benefits that Australia extends to our former citizens now residing in the United Kingdom. It may not be widely known that British pensions are now frozen at the levels payable when the British citizens left the UK. Those pensions are not adjusted for the effects of inflation as are those of people similarly placed who have not emigrated. Australian pensions payable to our former citizens now living in Britain are adjusted on a regular basis for inflation as measured by the consumer price index. It is a double standard about which I grieve today. It is a one-sided arrangement that our Government seems conspicuously unable to remedy.

One can assume that the arguments have been conveyed to the bureaucrats and the British Government. Such arguments would no doubt have drawn the attention of the British to the cost benefits of health care and ancillary benefits which will not have to be met because 172,000 people at ages where the demand is higher than for those not yet retired become the responsibility of Australian taxpayers. That will probably never change, but insult is added to injury when Australia is bound to top up British pensions payable in Australia to adjust for inflation. That is what presently happens.

The cost to Westminster of keeping expatriate pensions in line with inflation would surely be small compared to the costs of providing housing, health and other services required by the aged should those retirees have chosen to remain in Britain. In Australia, those who have full residency status or who are applying for a change to such status receive full Medicare benefits. As well, we have acted not just to top up British pensions to adjust for domestic inflation, we have gone even further and we protect the recipients of British pensions from the effects of fluctuations in the value of the pound sterling.

There are thousands of Australian age pensioners living in the United Kingdom to whom we pay full entitlements, including inflation adjustments. While I stand to be corrected on the figure, I understand that there are some 234,000 people living in the UK who are entitled to receive Australian benefits, including age, supporting parents, invalid and other pensions. None are penalised in the manner of British pensioners resident in Australia. On the contrary, all of our expatriates living in Britain are paid the same benefits as their equivalents who have remained in Australia.

British expatriate retirees residing in Australia do not receive the same consideration from the British Government. Age pensions, as I have already pointed out, are frozen at levels applicable to the day they leave England's shores. We Australian taxpayers are left to pick up the tab for the effects of inflation. We continue to protect British retirees against fluctuations in the exchange rates. Our fairness, however, is not reciprocated.

We will, of course, continue to meet the expense of health care for British residents of an age where they will need to call increasingly on such care, without reciprocity. We will continue to make it easier for these people whose benefits are paid under the British national insurance scheme and ensure that they are able to calculate tax deductions, again without reciprocity. If UK pensioners are unable to obtain the total amount of contributions paid in the UK, as an alternative the Australian Taxation Office will accept a figure of eight per cent of their pension income as the undeducted purchase price after it has been converted into Australian dollars. It is also possible for those who have not already claimed a deduction to have this backdated for three years.

Given that background, it is bordering on reprehensible that our Government has been unable to secure redress of the inequities being visited upon Australian taxpayers, and for far too long. Perhaps even this administration can now be moved into action. As luck would have it, the opportunity presents itself to tackle the issue with some vigour. The British member for Davyhulme, Mr Winston Churchill, has introduced into the House of Commons what is known at Westminster as Early Day Motion No. 915. If passed by that Parliament, the remedies I seek can be achieved. It has the support, I understand, of other British MPs but not necessarily of a majority. It is therefore both timely and imperative that the Government actively and energetically support the measure through its agencies in London.

Surely it cannot be too hard to convince the Brits of their debt of reasonableness towards those of their former taxpayers who were for many years valuable contributing members of their communities in that country. They are presently penalised because they merely wish to spend their remaining years in Australia near to their families.
I urge the Government to get off its backside and take advantage of what is a unique opportunity and above all take the appropriate action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, you and I were members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, chaired by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), in the last Parliament. That committee brought to light a lack of information to people and the threat of a widening gap between the information rich and the information poor as we go into the next century, if we do not take action now to ensure that people have proper access to information. It is also clear that people do not have proper access to services. George Bernard Shaw wrote in The Doctor's Dilemma:

SPEECH.PARA: The main object of the professions is to keep the laity uninformed.

Sometimes I wonder whether the main object of government is to keep taxes at a minimum. A lot of people would laugh and dispute that assertion but, when we see some of the problems that people bring into an electorate office, we wonder whether the object of government is rather to keep taxes at a minimum than to provide taxes to help people.

PARA.TAB: On the first matter, the professions keeping the laity uninformed, on which I quoted George Bernard Shaw, it was interesting when I first started in my old profession of pharmacy in 1951-52 how doctors would very rarely tell patients what was wrong with them. I can recall one patient dying of arsenic poisoning. She was not told why she was taking arsenic in a particular tonic over many years. The pharmacist did not tell her or give any warning on the label, and when she died her husband said, `No-one told me she should not be taking this tonic all of those years. It did not have on the label that there was arsenic in the tonic and she just kept on getting repeats'.

It is interesting that pharmacists are regarded in any public survey as the most popular of professions. Suddenly I am a different person—I come into politics and we are right down with used car salesmen and people like that. I think I am the same person, but apparently I am a very different person.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong party, though.

—Wrong party; right. But I argued right through my professional life about the need to give people the proper information. Even today one can get a prescription from a doctor, go into a pharmacy and not get the proper warnings about side effects and incompatibilities. However the pharmacists have improved.

PARA.TAB: At the pharmacy which we had before I came into Parliament in 1983 and which we sold in 1985 we certainly handed out warnings and statements, but I still cannot persuade all my former colleagues to make sure that people see all that they need to see. One will get a small item, for instance eye drops, where the pharmacist's label that states how they are used covers warnings such as `Keep below 4 degrees' or `Do not take this prescription with certain foods'. Some cannot be taken, for instance, with cheese and that sort of thing. So important information is covered up. I received a prescription only the other day on which important information was covered up.

But there is progress, because the pharmacist asked whether I had been given information from the doctor about the item, and I was able to say yes. But I believe it is important that pharmacists come to a system, maybe using a tag rather than a label, which assists people by ensuring that information that is directly on the container is not covered up. It should automatically state in detail what it is for and how it is best taken. With the computerised system one can now get programs which give full details of the product.

Lack of access to services often results from a lack of information that is given. People come into our offices who have had problems getting access to legal aid. How often that happens. The lack of access is not only due to the lack of information about where and how to get it but the access itself is often a problem. There are requirements for legal aid which, I believe, are far too strict. For instance, there is a very low financial threshold. If an inquirer has assets which are not very great or a certain amount of income which is not very great, legal aid is not accessible.

Legal aid will often not take cases which are not regarded as winnable. I have spoken already in this Parliament about Mr Fred Saw of Merimbula, who wanted to go to the High Court because he disputed the decision of a judge. The legal aid people said that his case was not winnable, so he has gone on for years trying to get justice on that particular matter. I am not passing judgment on the decision of a judge but I do say that there ought to be better access so that he can get some lengthy legal advice.

Another criterion is that there are strict guidelines that have to be adhered to. I recall a lady coming to see me just two or three weeks ago. After slipping on a floor in a club she decided she wanted to take action against that club for the accident. She met the income and the probability of winning requirements but she was told that she did not meet the strict guidelines that apply. If she had put her foot out and tripped someone else up and an action had been taken against her, she would probably meet the guidelines and be able to obtain legal aid.

There are also many cases where lawyers do not explain to people what they are doing. Legal aid is given but it is received the day before the court hearing; people are thrust into the court and come away saying that their lawyers did not really mention everything that had been told to them. They ask why such and such was not said. Often the lawyers have their reasons but, again, the profession does not always explain to people the reasons for doing things.

It is unexplainable to me why, for instance, our colleague the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) did not have things properly explained to him when he stood. He was a schoolteacher, but he was not in active employment at the time. The High Court—which has shown itself to be very flexible in a lot of cases in recent years—showed a lack of flexibility. That is my personal opinion; I may be treading close to abusing my privilege, so I will restrict my comments on that matter. The electorate of Wills was deprived of a member for far too long. When the honourable member for Wills stood again, he was re-elected.

This happened similarly, I believe, with an elector in Queanbeyan—Alderman John Wright—who stood for the Queanbeyan City Council. It was not explained to him what would happen and he did not tell his department. No-one ever told him what would happen when he became a member of council. Suddenly, one day he was told that he had taken employment without informing the department. No amount of argument could diminish the tedium of the responses we had on that issue. Apparently, within the meaning of some Act, voluntary service as a member of a local council is officially regarded as employment, and no-one can find out why. In other words, the law is not just an ass; it is an ass covered with a blanket. The council just insists on calling voluntary work, as a member of local government, employment.

The blanket of secrecy must be lifted. Patients should be told as much as possible about their ailment and about treatment. Citizens' respect for the law must be raised through more frankness and flexibility. I believe that vigilance by legislators and administrators must reduce the use of the technical requirements, which are often used in the professions to avoid frankness, responsibility and comprehension of the real problems of people who come and deal with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The pioneering spirit is alive and well in western Victoria and, in particular, in Corangamite. I refer to the innovative and exciting new proposals to privatise the Melbourne-Geelong-Warrnambool railway line. I congratulate the Kennett Government and, in particular, Minister Alan Brown on taking this initiative and awarding the contract to West Coast Rail to conduct this railway line for the next seven years. This is a major policy change. A State government has handed the railway system, or a part thereof, over to private enterprise.

PARA.TAB: I grieve on behalf of all the people of Victoria who today, I understand, are subject to $70 billion worth of debt, if the audit committee's report is correct. In that context, the Kennett Government had no alternative but to look at arrangements with the Warrnambool rail line. The option that was facing it was to close that particular line. It was losing $5 million a year, under its current arrangements. The Government decided to put out for contract the conveyance of the people from Geelong to Warrnambool, either by road or rail or a combination of both. Having put that out to contract, the Minister, in his wisdom, and the Government last Friday decided to give the contract to the West Coast Rail consortium so that this rail line will be operated privately.

This is an exciting and innovative approach. The privatisation of sections of Victorian railways, within the railway network, will now provide real competition and a quality of service to railway users. This could be a landmark policy decision for all Australian railway users, because we have this concept of government owning the railway line and subcontracting the railway line to the private sector operators. The Government, in this particular instance, has undertaken to maintain the track for its own freight operations and, of course, will be charging the private operators a maintenance fee to keep the track in good working order.

I draw the attention of the House to the other well-known private rail operation, which is in the Pilbara region. In 1965, 111 kilometres of rail were set down from Port Hedland to Goldsworthy, and it was able to transport the iron ore from that inland mining town to the coast, where great tonnages of ore were transported under a private sector operation. As I understand it, it is profitable, effective and very efficient.

The Warrnambool line tender—which the Government was out to save $5 million on—now means that this service will be kept going. There was a lot of local political activity in Colac, Warrnambool, Camperdown and Geelong to maintain this particular rail service. Not only will the service be maintained, it will be maintained in the long term, and it will also make a profit for the group. As I said, that will mean that the railway line will be maintained to retain the freight traffic in this area. How will all of this work, in an environment where EPAC has estimated that the Victorian public transport system is losing $884 million per year with urban commuters, country rail travel trains and trams? EPAC has estimated that the Victorian public transport system is the biggest money loser of all State corporations throughout Australia.

We have a very exciting change taking place. We have a fundamental change of attitude and in the methods of operation and the numbers of people employed. West Coast Rail will now have a new approach towards customers: it will be seeking customers and looking after the passengers. It will be thinking about new services. It will be innovative in the way in which it introduces catering arrangements on those trains, in the hope that passengers will enjoy a better standard of catering and so will be attracted to travel by train. The 265-kilometre trip from Warrnambool to Melbourne will be serviced three times a day, five days a week, both ways. It is a very good service and provides excellent service to all of those people who wish to travel at various times of the day.

Concession card holders will receive benefits similar to those they now enjoy, and the Government will reimburse the private sector operators for those particular persons. The West Coast Rail operation will incorporate modern management in its accounting systems, ticket sales operations, cost control and capital reinvestment programs. What is more important, it will integrate with the current V/line systems. Plans are now in place to make sure that that takes place, and that passengers will be able to buy tickets that will integrate with the rest of the Victorian system. It will, of course, provide a much more flexible system than is currently available.

Currently, V/line, on this particular operation, has 69 persons involved in running the system. The West Coast Rail operation is indicating that it will run the system with 15 people. That is a dramatic change in the numbers of people involved. It will have a private sector ethic in providing the service, in getting on with the job and working hard to make sure that its particular enterprise keeps going.

West Coast Rail will purchase the rolling stock at competitive prices from V/line. In a rail system that is contracting out there is a fair amount of rolling stock, both in terms of locomotives and rail carriages available, and that will be purchased at very competitive prices. Of course they will continue to ensure that this rolling stock is maintained under V/line guidelines, so the safety factor will be maintained. The 265-kilometre journey encompasses the population centres of Warrnambool, Camperdown, Colac, Geelong and Melbourne. It is very appropriate that those areas be serviced by train, and it does lead to making this particular operation very successful, as compared with more sparsely populated country areas. If we compare the figures for rail travel with those for car travel, an economy rail ticket from Warrnambool to Melbourne costs in the vicinity of $88 and that compares with RACV figures of $260 for travel by one motor car. That is not to mention the stress and strain of travelling down the Princes Highway.

I am pleased to be associated with those people in the West Coast consortium. They bring a depth of experience because of their running of the Geelong Steam Preservation Society: they run that tourist railway efficiently and very effectively, keeping on schedule and providing a very good service to the tourist and the public. The group consists of Mr Don Gibson, a lawyer who has been associated with a number of public transport operations; Mr Garry McDonald, a banker who will bring a sharp eye to the financial matters and who is a great railway enthusiast; and the third member of the consortium, Mr Michael Menzies, whose full-time occupation is a senior job on V/line.

The other key feature about the people in the consortium is that they can actually drive the trains themselves. They have hands-on experience with railway operations and they will bring that expertise to the arrangements. They understand train maintenance, passenger aspirations, rail tracks, locomotives and all the things that passengers are interested in.

This will be a first in Australia. We will have newer trains in the region, improved customer services, better trained staff and world best practices. I am sure honourable members of this House wish the consortium well in this new, exciting venture. It will lead the way to a new era of train travel in Victoria. This operation will give an opportunity for other State governments throughout the Commonwealth to follow this lead in privatising some of their rail tracks to provide a better, more profitable and long lasting service for Australian rail travellers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I offer you my congratulations, and note that you still enjoy the support of your coalition party for the high office of Speaker. Let me offer my commiserations on your lack of success in that regard.

PARA.TAB: Following my re-election, I would like to thank a number of people. Firstly, I thank Peter Baxter, an old mate, who was my campaign director and ran a very good campaign, together with the executive of my FEC. I also thank Tom Kenny and Steve Farry, together with all the branch campaign directors, and Alderman Michael Sommerton, Jim Metcher, Peter Van Der Ryden, Bruce Rowling, Peter Clapham, Alderman Wayne Forno, Steve Hutchins, Brian King, Siri de Silva, Malcolm Douglas and Danny Mackin. It is true to say that we have never worked harder or more effectively in a campaign.

I also thank all the branch members who worked so tirelessly in various capacities throughout the campaign. It was very pleasing to see so many people volunteer to assist during this campaign, and we were very pleased to receive that assistance. I also thank those who generously donated to my campaign.
