Most importantly of all, I thank the good voters of the electorate of Chifley who supported me in increasing numbers on this occasion, notwithstanding that there were more candidates in the field and that, of course, the Liberal Party of Australia ran its favourite stooge, independent candidate Alderman Joe Bryant. I report to the House that the primary vote went up by about 8.8 per cent, and the two-party preferred vote went up by about 2.6 per cent. I pledge to the people of the electorate of Chifley that I will be doing my favourite thing, and that is working tirelessly on their behalf, hoping never to betray the trust, confidence, encouragement and support that they have so generously given me in my time as the member for Chifley.

I want, in particular, to report on a major event in my electorate this week. I was very pleased to open the Luxford Food Court. It was a $10 million project that took six months to complete. I congratulate the two partners in this development. Peter Campbell, from Clarendon Homes, was born in North St Marys in my electorate. He is a very successful builder who operates and is based in Penrith. The other partner is Frank Galea, who was also born in my electorate, in Rooty Hill, which is not too far from where I live.

It is unfortunate that following the crash in property values developers now have a tarnished reputation. I pay tribute to the vision of Frank and Peter. They had the ability to conceptualise just what this Luxford Food Court plaza would do for retailing in Mount Druitt. It took quite a bit of determination given that all the major banks had knocked them back. It was only Challenge Bank in Western Australia that could see the potential and share the vision that they had, and I commend Challenge Bank for that. I suppose that the major banks have been so bruised that they are not able any more to see the potential of projects like this.

Luxford Food Court is going to cause Mount Druitt to provide the best shopping for people in the western suburbs of Sydney. I would certainly encourage as many as possible to try it. We have three main retailers. There is my old friend John Velcich with his largest chicken place at Luxford Court. Duffy Brothers, who are well known fruit and vegetable people in the western suburbs of Sydney, have their largest shop there. And Jewel food court has established a unique shop, the largest of their shops—the first of the Super-J stores.

The Super-J stores are going to usher in a revolution in retailing because whilst we think of Jewel food stores as providing the keenest food prices, and they are certainly doing that, they have also gone into retailing a variety of things that they have not done before. That includes electrical goods, clothing, you name it. Whatever you want can be found at a Jewel Super-J store.It will be interesting to see how it goes. I believe it will be very successful and I certainly wish Jim Fleming, the Managing Director of Jewel, every success with this venture. I predict that we will see quite a number of Super-J Jewel stores.

I think there are going to be a lot of shoppers owing quite a lot to a dedicated small band of retailers. As I said, try Luxford Court. One thing I can guarantee shoppers in the western suburbs of Sydney is that Mount Druitt is now the hottest shopping spot at the moment and will be for some time because of this.

Of course, a successful $10 million project constructed in six months from go to whoa takes the cooperation of a lot of people. I would like to acknowledge the role of the local council led by Alderman Jim Anderson who goes out of his way to welcome these sorts of developments and ensures that they do not meet any council problems. There is also the builder, Beach Constructions, and all the workers who worked on the site.

I suppose one of the nicest things I saw at the opening was the presence of Paul Galea, Frank's dad. If Mr Jennings was a proud old builder then I have to say that Paul Galea was a proud old dad. Of course, Frank's wife was there, Sylvia, and also Zoe. We have named one of the streets Zoe Place and I urge the council to keep it as pristinely clean throughout its life as it was during its opening. I am sure Zoe is going to take a great deal of interest in that. To all who were associated with it, I wish them every success. They certainly deserve it.

In the short time that is left to me I would like to raise another matter that occurred during the election. I think a totally irresponsible approach was taken by the New South Wales environment Minister, Chris Hartcher. In a deliberately political and partisan way he set about scoring election points by suggesting that people living around the ADI site would be at risk due to radiation. As a Federal member for eight years, one of my keenest desires has been to see that radioactive waste removed and I regret that as Parliamentary Secretary I was not able to because of matters outside my control. Those matters were more to do with the then Minister for Science.

In raising these reports, which were reproduced on Channel 7 and in the Melbourne Sun-Herald, the Australian and the local papers, he unnecessarily worried residents whose houses surround the ADI site. We are going to redevelop the 1,500 hectares into a combination of passive recreation, housing and industrial areas. He suggested that people who proposed to move into the redeveloped ADI site would somehow be placing themselves at risk. He ordered his EPA officials to investigate it. Of course, anyone could have told us that the investigation was going to get a nil result and say that there was no problem. Indeed, that has been the outcome.

I think what I object to most, apart from his having raised the matter in such a cavalier way, is that the Minister failed to release the report publicly. He certainly sent a copy to the Department of Defence. But, having made such a splash and so many headlines, I think it is really outrageous that he did not make an equal effort to ensure that people were fully informed that there was no danger. There is no danger. I find his actions completely reprehensible.

Environmental issues are important. I think that Ministers for the environment have a duty to pursue their concerns and interests responsibly, not irresponsibly. Mr Hartcher has done himself and the New South Wales Government a great disservice by entering this debate in such a partisan, political and biased way. I will not be disappointed when Chris Hartcher is no longer Minister for the Environment.

DEBATE.TITLE: GRIEVANCE DEBATERadio and Television Services: Mid-north Coast of New South WalesTax File Numbers

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue I want to mention first in this grievance debate is the need for increased television and radio coverage for the north coast of New South Wales and in particular for the mid-north coast. I speak particularly of the provision of SBS television services, the ultimate extension of Triple J youth radio to the north coast, 2EA services, ethnic radio, and ultimately commercial FM. While I am putting in a wish list, I will say that we should have regional ABC on FM as well.

PARA.TAB: I noted in the election campaign that the Richmond electorate was promised SBS services by the end of 1994. Regrettably, the public perception up and down the whole of the north coast of New South Wales is that the Government is now engaging in a form of very specific pork-barrelling. That is not doing the Government any good at all because most people are very concerned about this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you call it a bribe?

—I suppose one could call it that. There have been claims that the mid-north coast is a substantial area. Of 5,000 petition signatures presented to this Parliament last year, 1,500 came from the electorate of Cowper alone, and I will be presenting nearly another 800 next Thursday. I know that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) has a lot on his mind at the moment with pay TV, but people in my electorate are concerned with the basic provision of SBS. I am told that the Minister has nearly 1,500 letters sitting on his desk, waiting for an answer. I think it is fair enough to ask the Minister when he will answer and why he is insulting the people of the north coast of New South Wales by not deigning to answer their letters.

PARA.TAB: Just in the area that a transmitter from Mount Moombil, near Coffs Harbour, would cover, there would be at least 150,000 people. The number is more likely 200,000, but we will be conservative and say 150,000. The capital cost is $1 1/2 million. I know that that is a lot of money, but we can compare it with what we are spending elsewhere—and this is the provision of a service that is vital for people of ethnic diversity. That $1 1/2 million to get that service established is only $15 per head. The recurrent cost is $250,000, or only about $2.50 per person per year. I believe that the Government has been totally insensitive and has left itself wide open to attack when it appears to be going to extend SBS only to Government-held seats.

I would like to tell the House that, of the 150,000 people we are talking about, 10 per cent come from 14 major ethnic groups. In Coffs Harbour alone 5,000 people from a non-English speaking background, from 53 separate countries, have been identified in the last two years. So, if the Government is fair dinkum, is concerned about a multicultural Australia and is concerned that people outside the capital cities get the services they need, it should take immediate action to start introducing SBS to the north coast of New South Wales—and not just to the Labor-held seats; let us be a little fair about this.

I am also concerned about a matter relating to tax file numbers. I was told recently about a teenager who secured a job—one of the lucky ones of the one million unemployed—working on a banana plantation and, to do the right thing, he had to submit his tax file number. The law allows him 28 days in which to submit that number and if it is not submitted within that time there are pretty heavy penalties. I make the point here that the law should apply both ways, not only to the taxpayer but also to the Taxation Office. The young man did not get his tax file number for six weeks, and that put him under a fair bit of strain because he was fair dinkum and did not want to attract any fines for not providing the employer with a tax file number. I suppose it is not a major issue, it is not earth shattering, but I believe it is very important indeed. There should be one law for all in Australia, for all individuals and for all organisations, and that includes the tax man as well.

The next point I raise concerns the community of veterans of Australia. I have had a great many letters in recent weeks from veterans who are really fearful about the implications of the Auditor-General's recent report on the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I say quite clearly to this House that I have no hesitation in saying that men and women who have served this country in time of war and who have risked their lives should not be worried by recurrent sniping at their rights. Every now and again such sniping sticks its head up, and every now and again we have to knock it back into the ground because it is not appropriate that men and women who have risked their lives for this country and who have suffered injury and ill health should continually be worried by the threat of having their rights taken away.

I say to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) that he should reassure the community of veterans that the rights of veterans will not be taken away as a result of the Auditor-General's report on the department. It is not right that they should be worried by this and the Minister should make that very clear. I state very specifically at this point that the coalition would never take action to reduce the rights of veterans who are receiving pensions. Those pensions are payments—in many cases they are compensation—and they are sacrosanct as far as we are concerned.

Also sacrosanct is the matter of retrospectivity. I believe the Minister should immediately reassure veterans that there will be no retrospectivity in any changes that the Government might come up with. The price of liberty is eternal vigilance, and honourable members on this side of the House will continue to be vigilant to protect the rights of veterans who have served this country.

The next matter I raise relates to Sporobolus africanus, that is, giant Parramatta grass. I see some honourable members in the chamber who come from country and rural areas who will know what I am talking about; there are others from Melbourne and Sydney who may not have a clue. But I need to tell the House, in particular those honourable members who have never seen giant Parramatta grass in their lives—if this is the first time they have heard of it, it will not be the last—that it is a weed which is invading the pasture and farmlands of Australia. Quite frankly, it poses an incredible threat. Unless we take efficient and prompt action to provide the adequate research necessary, it will have a devastating impact equal to any occurrence of foot and mouth disease in our livestock.

This sounds fairly dramatic, I know, but I believe this is the case. It is already spreading all over the north coast of New South Wales, and it is not stopping at any borders. It is going further all the time. It is out of control. I must say that some money is being spent on control. In 1991-92 New South Wales local government authorities spent $244,000, and a further $50,000 was granted by the noxious plants advisory committee for a special giant Parramatta grass awareness campaign. I tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, we do not have to make the farmers on the north coast aware of it. They are aware of it. What we have got to do is to have adequate research to work out some biological way of beating it. I commend the New South Wales Government, which has provided additional funding for a coordinator. That will supplement the work being done at the University of New England and the Queensland University which is being funded by the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and the Australian Meat Research Corporation.

I believe this particular weed, which is invading pasture and other farmlands, will be the AIDS of Australian agriculture. I say to the Government, and I say to the Minister, that we need to get funding immediately for a massive research program to beat giant Parramatta grass before it destroys Australian agriculture. Heaven knows, Australian farmers are in enough trouble already, with the drought and reduced prices and world commodity situations. This weed must not be allowed to continue right over Australia. It probably will not get into Western Australia because the desert will stop it, but it is carried by vehicles, by wallabies and by other animals. It must be stopped. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise in the grievance debate today is a very serious one. It concerns the actions of the Kennett Government in Victoria with respect to programs which are of relevance and importance to the Commonwealth Parliament. I raised this matter a couple of weeks ago in a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I want to refer, as a Victorian MP and as the member for Calwell, to one of the areas which were most viciously hit in the previous round of cuts by the Kennett Government. I am extremely concerned that these next cuts are going to impact in a very unfair way—in the way in which the previous round did. In fact, when cuts are made in the way in which these were made, the situation is so grave that it threatens to undermine the social justice strategy of the national Government for the nation, particularly for the State of Victoria.

PARA.TAB: In raising this matter I do not wish to take away from a government the right to cut expenditure. That is not the issue. The issue, however, is this: the cutting of expenditure which directly relates to programs for which the Commonwealth has part responsibility must be a matter which is worked out in consultation with the Commonwealth. This has not happened in the case of the Victorian cuts.

Admittedly, the Liberal Government in Victoria has been faced with a difficult financial situation, but it is possible to deal with that financial situation in a fair way. The Kennett Government is not dealing with it in a fair way. It is not sharing the cuts across the board. In fact, it is attacking the key areas of education, health and welfare. Especially in the area of health there has been a massive cut, which is of great concern to me and to the Ministers responsible for this area.

Clearly, if a government is going to try to get the support of the community for a cutting exercise of the kind which Mr Kennett has been involved in, it is important to try to share the burden. That has not happened. There has been great iniquity in the way in which Mr Kennett has proceeded.

There has been great iniquity in the way in which the cuts have been made and no sense of social justice whatever has been shown by Mr Kennett. I cannot imagine anyone with less sense of social justice and social concern than Mr Kennett, from the way in which he has proceeded in this matter. Let me give an example: $381 million cut from health. The biggest cut is from health. As I said in my letter to the Prime Minister, when I expressed my concern about this, that means that the staffing levels in health are expected to be reduced by 24 per cent or 4,000 jobs. That is the equivalent of closing both the Royal Melbourne Hospital and the Royal Children's Hospital. That is how big it is. If they are not closed, many other hospitals and community centres will most likely be closed—as a consequence of the activities of the Kennett Government.

There is such a thing as consultation and negotiation, especially where programs are being funded jointly by the State and the Federal governments. That has not happened in this case. The situation is even worse: the people of Victoria have not even been told the specifics of this program. The Ministers of the Kennett Government could not even be bothered doing the hard work of working out what programs they were going to cut before they made the announcements. They have simply announced in the area of health, for example, $381 million; in the area of education, more than $100 million; and so forth, without announcing where the cuts are going to impact. That is completely the reverse of the process of fiscal responsibility used by the Commonwealth Government, where we always announce the specific programs. We do not announce a big cut in a certain area and say nothing of the programs.

What has happened as a consequence is that no-one working in the State sector in Victoria, especially in these areas of health, education and welfare, knows whether he is still going to be employed. It is several weeks since the Government of Victoria made its announcement yet we still have not had the specifics. Is this the way to run a State? It certainly is not. It shows an inhuman disregard for the Public Service in the State of Victoria when all the public servants are worried about what is going to happen in terms of their future. That Government has not even bothered to say to people, `These are the areas in which we think we are going to make the specific cuts'.

What is Mr Kennett's response to these sorts of criticisms? His response is that he is trying to get the State of Victoria and the economy moving again. His idea of getting Victoria moving again is to sack 32,000 people in six months. That is his idea—32,000 people, with no regard for where savings may be made in other areas. He comes in just in the human areas, in the areas of concentration of labour, where people are needed for human services, and he cuts massively in those areas—32,000 people. Then he has the impertinence to suggest that somehow the private economy is going to grow so quickly in Victoria as to take up 32,000 jobs. A calculation of the sort of thing that would be required to create 32,000 jobs shows that, in terms of the normal size of private enterprises nowadays, we would need to create more than 2,000 enterprises to take up all those people in Victoria.

This is the man who says that he wants an economic recovery in Victoria. The first thing he does is to say, `We have got an economic problem. Let's not try and work out the way to handle this in a sophisticated fashion. Let's come out and slash and burn and cut 32,000 jobs'. That is 32,000 people, with families, that have lost their jobs in Victoria as a result of Mr Kennett's actions. We have a diminished number of Federal Government members from Victoria; one of the reasons is that in the recent election a lot of people in Victoria voted against Mr Kennett's actions. I can assure you that if he continues in this way there will not be too many Victorian Liberal members left. The reality is that this sort of exercise, this sort of government behaviour, in terms of cutting and slashing, is unacceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to on 5 May 1993, the debate is interrupted, and I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —As some time has passed since the general principles concerning the conducting of the period of members' statements were formulated and as there has been considerable change in the membership of the House in the intervening time, it may suit the convenience of the House if I outline the guidelines I intend to observe.

PARA.TAB: A member will be allowed to make one 90-second statement and, if no other member rises to receive the call during each 15-minute period, up to two subsequent statements.

The call will normally alternate between non-government and government members, subject to members who have not received the call during a particular 15-minute period being afforded priority over members who have received the call in that period. Independent members will be called in the frequency that reflects the ratio of their representation in relation to the House's total membership.

Standing order 106A precludes Ministers from being called to make 90-second statements. By virtue of the resolution of the House of 5 May 1993 indicating that, for the purposes of the procedures of the House, any reference to Ministers shall be taken to include Parliamentary Secretaries, with the exception of references to questions seeking information, Parliamentary Secretaries will not be called. The Opposition front bench will not receive precedence.

The Standing Orders and practices of the House applying to debate and speech in the House will apply to members' statements. The use of unparliamentary language and the making of personal attacks upon those whose actions can be questioned only by way of substantive motion will not be in order. The Standing Orders permit the giving of oral notices during the period of members' statements, provided a written copy of its terms is lodged with the Clerk at the conclusion of the 90-second statement.

The calling of quorums, the raising of spurious points of order and procedural motions and other disruptive tactics are not in accordance with the spirit underlying the period of members' statements and will not be tolerated.
The timing of 90-second statements will be by stopwatch. The speech timing clocks will not be used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your guidance, Mr Speaker. I want to quickly read part of a letter that a business house in my electorate received recently. It says, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: We are top government functioneries in the department of ministries of Finance and Aviation, headquarters Lagos respectively. We have been mandated by our colleagues within the above mentioned ministries and the Central Bank of Nigeria, to seek your assistance in effecting the remittance of $20,260,000.00 America dollars into an off-shore account anywhere in the world.

Our position as contract custodians and members of the contract tender's board has enabled us to monitor the award and execution of various contracts within our ministries. We have used our good post within our ministry to over-invoice some of this contracts to the tune of the above mentioned amount. We have now come together since the present regime will be handing over power at the end of this year to a democratically elected civilian regime, to seek for a way to make sure that this fund which is now lying in suspense account at the Central Bank of Nigeria is remitted into an account for onward disbursement between ourselves and whoever provides an account for us.
For providing the account to which the fund is remitted you shall be entitled to 30% of the total sum involved, 10% has been set aside for any such expenses.
And it goes on. I hope that, if this is a bona fide letter, nobody in Australia is taking up the offer, which is clearly an international swindle.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) unfortunately has left the chamber, but he knows as well as the whole community that the health system in this nation is in chaos because of the policies of the Keating Government and the Cain and Kirner governments, particularly, in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: I want to raise a matter of health at this time. The Bendigo Sub-region Aged and Disability Services Development Committee has written to the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) regarding private health insurance. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: At a meeting of the Loddon Campaspe Seniors/Older Persons Forum held on 25th March, 1993, it was unanimously decided to urge your Government to re-introduce a tax deduction for persons who contribute to a Private Health Fund.
Older people who strive to keep up their private health insurance and also in many cases pay the Medicare levy, are being financially disadvantaged by the current system.

PARA.TAB: I hope that in your new position as Minister for Health, you will endeavour to have this most important issue, for all older people addressed. We appreciate that this is a national issue affecting young and old, who believe in providing for their own health care and should not be penalised by the present system.

SPEECH.PARA: All I can add to that is that, if the Government does proceed down that line, it will simply be introducing one of our policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make some comments on the nature of Australia, and particularly my constituency as it is now, given some of the comments that we heard earlier about what the nature of Australia really is. I think a city like Logan, one of the fastest growing areas in Australia, truly reflects the kind of population we have now.

PARA.TAB: In particular, I want to pay tribute to a group of people involved in what is called the Logan Migrant Neighbourhood Centre. They have really taken their notion of multiculturalism to its nth degree. In particular, we now have a very thriving Islamic women's association, which I know that many honourable members will find perhaps a little strange. This is a group of women whose religious views in many ways set them apart from the rest of society and who also find that they have great language difficulties. What these women have done of their own accord is to ensure that they now have access to English classes, and they are seeking child care. Of course, it is always a difficulty for women with young children to access training and language classes and so on.

This association has banded together with groups of other people, particularly newly-arrived migrants from eastern Europe—in particular, Romania—and people from Colombia, Uruguay and other places in South America, to create a centre which is vibrant and very much part of modern Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been much talk about the connection between the Whitlam Government in the 1970s and the current Keating Government. I am happy enough for those connections to be made because, if ever there was a case for guilt by association, that is it. But there is one other link between those two governments that is occurring right at this very moment in Western Australia, and that is the move to disband the Australian Army Band in Perth.

PARA.TAB: The reason I say that there is a link between that action and the Whitlam Government's record is that in the 1970s the Whitlam Government tried to do the very same thing. In fact, that was only stopped thanks to the efforts of the then Western Australian Liberal Party back in those days.

The Australian Army Band, Perth, which was formerly the Western Command Band, then the band of the 5th Military District, was formed at Swan Barracks in December 1949. Originally a brass band, it was converted to a concert or military band in 1972 with the inclusion of reed instruments and increased in size to its current strength of 34 musicians. Its primary role is to provide support for military, regal and vice-regal functions for all three services, but as a secondary role the band performs over 250 engagements per year in both metropolitan and country areas. The band has a wide repertoire, ranging from classical to popular.

Notable performances have included the world swimming championships, the America's Cup challenge and being responsible for the opening concert of the Festival of Perth each year. It would be a great shame indeed if the Australian Government were to be successful in disbanding the Australian Army Band, Perth. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, could I first offer my congratulations to you on being elected Speaker of this great place. Last Saturday was a very important day for the labour movement, particularly in my electorate of Oxley, which is based in the city of Ipswich. Being 1 May and Labour Day, we as usual celebrated in true Labor tradition and we had our march down the streets.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, it would not be celebrated in the areas represented by those opposite because they would not know what it meant. In the last election campaign, they were talking about trying to destroy Labor traditions in one fell swoop. The good thing was that the people of Australia saw that. Certainly the people in my electorate saw it more than those anywhere else, to the extent that the Liberals even had trouble finding a candidate, which is not surprising.

PARA.TAB: We in the labour movement are very proud of the traditions of the labour movement and that is why we celebrate that day; it is a very important day. Provincial cities like Ipswich have celebrated that day, and the first Labour Day march was actually held in that city. I would like to put on record my thanks and appreciation to the local Trades and Labour Council in Ipswich, particularly the Secretary, Ian Fenton, who worked so hard to make the day a success. It is a very important day for us to celebrate. Brisbane always celebrates that day on the Monday following the Saturday, but the provincial cities in Queensland generally use the Saturday to commemorate that day. I know they do in places like Barcaldine, where the second Labour Day march was actually held. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I bring to the attention of the House a program in South Australia which we can all celebrate. This program is known as Operation Flinders and the program is designed simply to allow young offenders an opportunity for some form of rehabilitation other than the rehabilitation that we normally associate with prisons and the penal system. Under this program, the South Australian Police, community groups in my area, led by Miss Kay Harrison, and Aboriginal groups have been getting together to form Operation Flinders and allow young people an opportunity to spend some time camping in the Flinders Ranges of South Australia, largely supervised by volunteers. The reason I bring this to the attention of the Federal Parliament is that what has been unique about the program has been the involvement of the Australian Army. It has been the Australian Army's preparedness to make tents and facilities available that has made this program such a success.

PARA.TAB: I think we should celebrate the involvement of the Army and we should recognise that this program has allowed young people to express themselves, to involve themselves in a program of self-discipline and to be involved in goal setting, so getting a new perspective on life. Many of them have had no real opportunity to experience life beyond the urban jungle and Operation Flinders has given them a chance to camp under canvas and see another side and a better side of Australian life.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Railways: Western Line, New South Wales

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take this opportunity on the first formal occasion I have had to congratulate you on your election as Speaker and also to extend my congratulations to the Deputy Speaker.

PARA.TAB: I would like to refute some comments made in my electorate yesterday, in the city of Orange, by the New South Wales Minister for Transport, Mr Bruce Baird. In making a number of comments about the future of the western rail line in New South Wales, he somehow made a linkage between the future of the western rail line and actions by the Commonwealth Government. It should not be forgotten that the western line in New South Wales is owned and operated by the Government of New South Wales through the State Rail Authority of New South Wales. I remain committed as a Federal member to the importance of this line because, if in fact this is to be part of the National Rail Corporation into the future, clearly any freight that transits between Sydney and Perth and return has a 400-kilometre shorter journey than through Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide, once the standard gauge link is completed. Naturally, as a committed advocate of rail in this country, like a number of members in this House, I am very keen to see the standard gauge link between Melbourne and Adelaide, but I do not necessarily see a nexus between the completion of that line and the insecurity of the western rail line. My view is that the New South Wales Government continues to make excuses. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my congratulations on your elevation. I have one minute in this House to remind people of the dangers in Victoria of the Kennett Government. The cuts that it is making to the education budget down there are tremendous. Just look at this: 200 people at a meeting, all parents protesting about the cuts down there. Our kids who go to school in Victoria have got to empty the rubbish bins because of the cuts. They cannot have sports competitions, they are not allowed to have a rock eisteddfod. Schools are being cut all over the place. In the electorate of Isaacs, next to mine, the school was closed down. I do not think I have heard the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) complaining about it yet, but it was closed recently because of the cuts in Victoria. There has been a tremendous attack on education—(Time expired)
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to on 5 May 1993, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—Before calling on questions, I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon members of a delegation from the Parliament of Nauru. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the Government's current assessment of the dangers posed to Australian troops and the Cambodian peace process by the recent military activities of the Khmer Rouge? Can the Government indicate what level of Australian military involvement in Cambodia will continue after this month's elections and for what period?

—The Cambodian peace process is fragile but we think remains on track. The international community, including Australia, is determined that the elections will proceed and our group there, the UNTAC force, has to this stage of the proceedings been able to conduct itself in a way which will facilitate the taking of a proper ballot and the holding of an election in that country.

PARA.TAB: We are firmly committed to supporting UNTAC in the lead-up to the election. While there have been some attacks on UNTAC personnel, we do not believe the situation has deteriorated to the point where the viability of the electoral process is threatened. The essential point is that the United Nations be able to pronounce the elections free and fair. That now is not far off.

While the Khmer Rouge have posed problems only in certain particular areas of the country, some of the reports of their positions in recent weeks are, in many respects, simply a recitation of things said by them over the last six to 12 months. So, from Australia's point of view, we have not seen a wholesale deterioration. Therefore, from our own point of view, we are not considering at any stage, and have not, any withdrawal on our part. I laid out the conditions under which that might occur at the time of this commitment. The Government will now see the election take place and then consider its position after that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development advise the House on the state of the automotive industry?

—I thank the honourable member for Port Adelaide for his question; he obviously has a keen interest in the fortunes of this important industry. As honourable members may be aware, yesterday I tabled the yearly report of the Automotive Industry Authority. That is sobering reading but reading that we all should be very proud of, at least on this side of the House where we have indicated our support for the industry.

PARA.TAB: The first and most important part of that report relates to that finding by this independent agency that Australian automobile quality is now equal to or better than many imported Japanese cars. I am almost tempted to repeat it but time does not permit me. But that is a very sobering message and one which we all ought to be very proud of, and certainly the industry ought to be proud of.

Included in the report were acknowledgments of very significant increases in productivity, a significant drop in industrial disputation and a growth in exports now to $1.247 billion, that being a rise of well in excess of 200 per cent since 1984. Contrary to urban myth, our cars are now priced similarly to those on sale in the United States and are cheaper than those obtained in the United Kingdom.

In terms of the investment outlook, the industry confidently projects investment in the order of $2 billion during the next three years, a rise again of 19 per cent. The key parts of these investment proposals are those by Toyota and Mitsubishi. I have been acquainted with both companies over the past few weeks and both have indicated in quite compelling terms that the underlying rationale for this very massive level of proposed investment is the change in workplace and managerial culture that has led to the achievement of world's best practice across a whole range of this industry's endeavours.

So for the pain of the last decade, I think this country is now looking at the potential for very considerable gain. We have set tough benchmarks for the automotive industry, but achievable benchmarks and ones that will configure it to be an internationally competitive automobile industry, producing a high quality and increasingly competitive product. Of course, a happier side to all of this is the increasing level of the production of the automobile and components industry that is going into the global marketplace.

In conclusion, I think that every member of this House ought to acknowledge the significant improvement in this industry over the last decade, sadly reflect upon the barren policy approach of our opponents to this industry in terms of zero tariff policy proposals and so on, and reflect on the gains that this country is now making after having experienced the pain over the last decade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to the $2.1 billion current account deficit for the month of March, and ask: is it a fact that, as the Prime Minister has said, to reduce unemployment the economy needs to grow by more than four per cent per annum? Is it also a fact that, as our growth rate approaches just 2 1/2 per cent, our balance of payments deficit is already blowing out? Does the Government now accept that we are in the pincer predicted by the Prime Minister in his banana republic comments in 1986, that Australia cannot reduce unemployment without causing a balance of payments crisis and cannot solve a balance of payments crisis without increasing unemployment?

—I guess the most notorious point in the honourable member's question is that finally the Opposition has acknowledged that the Australian economy is growing. We have spent the last several years with the Opposition continually telling us that we are in recession and, when it was clear we were emerging from recession, month after month the Leader of the Opposition and his former shadow Treasurer said that they were expecting a double dip recession. They continued to say throughout the entire campaign that Australia was in recession, still in recession and unlikely to come out of it.

PARA.TAB: Now we have the great conversion of the Opposition, as evidenced by the honourable member for Mayo, who now acknowledges that Australia is growing at 2 1/2 per cent. Congratulations! I hope that the honourable member for Mayo can educate his leader because just before he himself is about to predict the inevitability of another recession—which was the burden of his question—at least he has arrived at the point where, in between the recession he thought would never end and the recession he thinks is about to begin, at least we have had one day of recovery on the part of the Opposition.

Of course the figure for the balance of payments for March was a disappointing one, but there are many commentators around the country who believe, as we do, that this is probably a rather wild figure. In other words, if you look at this question not on the basis of just one month but on the basis of the last three months, you will see that the average monthly figure—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is trending up.
—You have a great deal to learn, sonny.
—Order! The Treasurer might just resume his seat for a moment. The honourable member for Mayo has asked a question. I suggest that he sit there and listen to the answer.

—If one looks at the three-month average of the monthly current account deficit, one finds that it is $1.2 billion which is, of course, well on track for the $15 billion current account deficit estimated at the time of the Budget and, I suspect, somewhat below the revised forecast which was included in Investing in the nation just prior to the last election.

PARA.TAB: I think the point here is that the Opposition should be careful about latching on to one month's statistics. Even Mr Spicer said that you should be cautious about embracing one month's figures as indicative of a trend. At least on that, if on practically nothing else, Mr Spicer has it right. I think the Opposition would be well advised to consider these matters in terms of the last three months and bear in mind that the Government did have a Budget forecast for $15 billion which was revised upwards before the election campaign.

This whole question does raise issues about how Australia is going to manage the recovery. This is going to be a very different kind of recovery for Australia because it is going to be one in which we can look forward to a period of low inflation. What we are now faced with is the challenge of a long run of sustainable, low inflationary growth; and that raises new challenges for Australia, particularly in terms of maintaining our competitiveness. The points that the Prime Minister has made in relation to wages policy are an important part of that, and the points that I have made about improving Australia's saving performance are also a crucial part of managing that future growth for Australia.

On the other hand, of course, the Opposition is in a state of total shambles: it has no policy about anything. If you take something as crucial as tariff policy, you find the Leader of the Opposition still waving Captain Zero's flag of zero tariffs by the turn of the century. Yet you have the Leader of the National Party and the shadow Treasurer now saying that that is all rubbish and that that ought to be abandoned; in other words, you have the shadow Treasurer turning on its head one of the crucial elements of how Australia should proceed through the 1990s and beyond. What he wants to do is reverse the trend towards Australia becoming more competitive, and simply turn his back on the world and start the process of lifting tariffs again. The Opposition has a lot of thinking to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Complete rubbish.

—Of course we have seen many reports from the honourable member for Mayo, in which he has challenged the sense of the Leader of the Opposition's policy in relation to tariffs. He says this is one of the many areas which need to be reviewed by the Opposition.
—That is completely untrue.

—Well, I will leave you to spend the next two years contemplating your future and your future policies. We, on the other hand, will get on with the business of running sensible economic policy in this country.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Is the Minister aware of recent reports claiming the Government is considering the provision of special benefits targeted to some categories of the long-term unemployed? Are the reports correct and what is the Government's intention in this matter?

—Let me welcome to Question Time the honourable member for Lowe in her maiden question in this House. It follows a very good maiden speech delivered by her earlier today. She is well and truly off and running as a parliamentarian and that is a good thing for this country and for us all, particularly as, clearly, she has decided to identify herself with some of the most significant issues confronting this country.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister has, on a number of occasions in public and in this House, mentioned a decision by the Government to make a specific study of those who are unemployed and concentrate upon those who are long-term unemployed. On the last set of figures, for March 1993, there were some 370,000 long-term unemployed amongst the total number of unemployed. They are rising as a percentage of the total number of unemployed and my Department's estimates would be that the figure will rise over the next year or so well above the 400,000 mark.

We are going to find a situation in this country which is now being experienced commonly throughout the Western world. After a period of recession there is an almost intractable problem of a large group of individuals in society who are finding it virtually impossible to get back into the work force. Even though we would expect over this period of time a reduction in the total levels of unemployment, that reduction would not of itself cause those figures on long-term unemployment to fall. This is a problem that is not unique to this country. It is a problem that is being experienced throughout the Western world.

We do have in place a series of labour market programs which are making some difference to this. Some 490,000 job seekers were assisted by those labour market programs last year. In defence of those programs, of those long-term unemployed who actually found work in the work force over the last 12 months, some 80 per cent had been through those labour market programs to which I referred. They are absolutely vital in providing opportunities for long-term unemployed people to get back into the work force. Clearly, they are very significant.

I cite one of those programs as an example. The jobstart program which saw 57 per cent of its participants remain in unsubsidised employment after their jobstart subsidy had ended. Of the long-term unemployed group—the program does not apply just to the long-term unemployed—some 50 per cent had maintained themselves in employment beyond the subsidy period. On top of that, another 3 per cent or so went into unsubsidised education and training. So that of itself has been a very successful program. I could cite other programs of equal success.

We are viewing this situation firstly in the context of the short-term requirements to devise appropriate strategies for the current Budget, and there is an interministerial office group looking at that at the moment. We are also examining the problem on a medium-term basis. We have recently appointed Dr Chapman, of the ANU, to undertake a study and we will provide opportunities for community input to that study in the Government's consideration of its outcome. His job will be to define the nature of the problem of high levels of long-term unemployed; to identify and analyse relevant issues; and to develop a set of options for reducing the level of long-term unemployed for government consideration.

During these studies, there will be obviously a great deal of speculation from time to time. Some of that will be engaged in by Ministers. It is not a process that simply will be confined to my Department. It is a process that will involve a whole series of departments of government and it is an opportunity for a great deal of community thought to go into this and for the community to express views on it. This is not a problem that is going to be readily solved. It will be a problem still with us well beyond employment issues being salient in political debate in this country.

I think it is reasonable to assume that, as unemployment numbers clearly start to fall, so will public interest in unemployment. It is the nature of the thing. Where that has happened elsewhere this group of people have remained intractable, with all the consequent effects of poverty and poverty for their children in the community and it is that problem which we are morally and practically committed to deal with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy whether he agrees with his Queensland counterpart, Mr Casey, that an additional 30 per cent of farmers will have to leave the land. Are these the same people whom the Prime Minister, during the election campaign, said had only themselves to blame? Is it a fact that the Government's high interest rate policies—interest rates were in excess of 20 per cent for some 18 months at one point—the imposition of high taxes and charges, together with the lack of a decent IED scheme, and the agonisingly slow and inadequate reforms in the workplace, have very substantially reduced the capacity of farmers to cope with the current disastrous downturn?

—If the Government were to do nothing to assist farmers affected by drought—and, in the case of the wool industry, those affected by the plummeting prices—it would be true that we would be losing something like 30 per cent of farmers. But that is not the position this Government has chosen to pursue. We have seen the need to deliver constructive assistance to the rural sector on the basis of those areas affected by circumstances over which they have no control. They are the areas affected by drought—in some cases, drought that has now lasted for three years—and by the fall in the wool price. The fall in the wool price was due to a world recession that was not predicted on either side of this House, coupled with the Russians being out of the market and the pressure that has been put on the stockpile—a stockpile that was created because the farm leadership believed it could rig a price that the rest of the world was not prepared to pay, thereby guaranteeing security for their membership.

PARA.TAB: We have seriously tried to map out a sensible direction forward. I believe that the rural sector has a very strong future in this economy. I believe that if we actually do more than trade the commodity in this nation—if we actually get diversity in industry, based on rural industries—we will have a much more sustained future. I do not believe that farmers have to do this on their own. That is why it is very important that the programs we have implemented and announced in our rural policy better equip farmers to meet the circumstance of change and to position themselves for the future.

I saw the Opposition's ridicule of a comment in the Governor-General's speech two days ago about our announcement of a world best practice program. The Opposition has said that the factories of this nation have to adopt world best practices. Why not the farms? They are the base, the building block, of food processing—the issue that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development referred to yesterday. We do not expect the farm sector to do it on its own. We have a range of policies in place for the short term and for the long term. If we get that right, if we develop policies sensibly in this place, we will secure the farm base and keep the good farmers on the land to their own benefit as well as to the benefit of the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to the previous question, would the Minister advise what contributions are being made by the States to that offered by the Commonwealth Government to assist struggling woolgrowers and producers affected by the drought?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Eden-Monaro for his question. I know the keen interest he has taken in the wool-growing industry, particularly as he represents some of the best wool-growing country in this nation. Yesterday I outlined the package of assistance that this Government developed for the wool industry, but I made the point that, if we were to get maximum assistance to the farm sector, it required the States to match their obligations as agreed to last year.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday I reported the fact that I was concerned that the Victorian Government was not prepared to match that assistance. I am pleased to say that, late yesterday, it appeared to have come to the party. There is still some difficulty with what it says is needed. The Victorian Government says that it is only $4 million; we say that it is $6.6 million. But the Victorian primary industries Minister has told me that his Government will meet fully its obligations. I will pursue that to the extent that is necessary.

I note that the honourable member for Gwydir, who asked me the previous question, was also keen to encourage the States to come to the party in their matching obligations, and in a media release on 28 April, after having welcomed the wool package, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I urge the state governments to allocate their matching finance and implement these interest subsidies immediately.

Unfortunately, those on the other side representing the National Party do not seem to have too much influence with their colleagues in New South Wales, because yesterday Ian Armstrong, the Minister for Agriculture, said that the extent of their assistance would only be to provide for interest subsidies up to 80 per cent, not the 100 per cent that we have said that we are prepared to support.

PARA.TAB: It is all very well for those on the other side to get up and ask what we are doing in terms of the rural sector. To express concern and compassion and say that there are real problems is easy. The words come easy. It is the delivery of the outcomes that is the real test. This Government has delivered constructively in terms of wool and drought, but those opposite and their colleagues have consistently failed to do it. Yesterday I had cause to mention the fact that the Kennett Government in Victoria, in its approach to the rural sector which is going through one of the worst crises in living memory, has actually cut expenditure to the rural sector by 10 per cent. Today we report the fact that it is the New South Wales Government that is short-changing farmers. So, when those on the other side want to express concern, they should not rail at us, because we have delivered. They should get on to their colleagues and get them to match their obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. I refer to the Minister's answer in the House yesterday when he said that advice had been received from the Attorney-General's Department that to put a financial hurdle in place would not enable the Government to have a price based system for pay TV tenders. What specific section of the Attorney-General's advice was the Minister relying on when he made this statement to the House?

—I thank the honourable member for Goldstein once more for his question; it took a little bit of time to get one today. I want to start off again by making it very plain what this policy is about. The real focus on this policy should be directed to what we are delivering to the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to the honourable member's question.
—You only get one question—not half a dozen.
—Order!
—The real intent of this policy will be implemented.
—Where in this statement?
—The intent of the policy is to make sure that the Australian people get the best quality pay television, and that is by compressed digital technology through the satellite.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. The question to the Minister was extremely specific. He should answer the question. If he does not know the answer, he should say so and sit down.
—There is no point of order.

—What I was saying and I will continue to say is that this policy is about providing the Australian people with the best possible outcome in pay television. We are about to do that by giving them access to the communication technology through the satellite. We have gone to a price based bid, and that price based bid will show a return to the Australian people unprecedented compared with what our opponents did. In relation to the specific part of the question, the advice was to the department and not to the Minister of the day. It was the basis on which the tender process was set up. I am advised by the department that that process could not have been undertaken unless—no, sorry—let me correct that. It was advice to the department and the advice to the department was that putting in the hurdles referred to in the Attorney-General's advice would have precluded a price based system.

What are the Government's intentions in this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen criticisms of the Government's proposal from the Leader of the Opposition, other opposition spokesmen, and I think also from some sections of the Law Council of Australia. I do not believe that the criticisms being levelled by the Leader of the Opposition have any basis at all. They seem to be on the premise that we are somehow moving away from a merit based system in terms of the appointment of the judiciary.

PARA.TAB: Let me make it clear that any proposal which the Government is considering has, as its fundamental, the basis that all appointments to the judiciary must be on the best person for the job, on the basis of excellence. That is the basis of any proposal we will be looking at. It is also, of course, a matter of fact that, if we look at the make-up of benches throughout Australia, there are very few women serving and very few Australians from non-English speaking backgrounds.

I do not believe anyone in this House would suggest that there are not outstanding excellence and talent on behalf of Australian women or those Australians from non-English speaking backgrounds. The proposal that we are looking at is whether there should be a broadening of the pool from which appointments are made.

At the moment, the process generally involves drawing judges from senior ranks of the bar in each of the States. It is also true to say that there is excellence in the ranks of solicitors, in the ranks of academia, and indeed in the ranks of government solicitors. I think it is also appropriate that the very process of appointing of judges also should be looked at. At the moment it is a fairly informal process where consultations may be undertaken with members of the judiciary and sections of the legal profession.

I believe a system that could be looked at would be more open than that, maybe formalising the process of consultation. I think a very important comment in terms of this debate was made in the editorial in the Melbourne Age this morning. This editorial dealt broadly with the position of women in paid work, but made, I think, some important comments. It said:

ANSWER.PARA: In one crucial area of public life, the law, the representation of women is abysmally low . . . it is unfortunate that a move by the Federal Government to broaden the gender and ethnic base of the judiciary has immediately been attacked by the Opposition as somehow diluting the merit principle in judicial appointments. Of course judges should be appointed on merit, but unless it can be argued that women are less talented and capable than men in this area, there has to be discrimination at work, given that there are so few women on the bench.

Discrimination in that sense is not that there is not some overt barrier there saying that we will not select women or people from other backgrounds but merely that the same sort of barriers which see so few women indeed in this Parliament and in senior decision making positions throughout Australia are also at work in terms of the judiciary. These are matters that we should be concerning ourselves with, and it is disappointing that the Opposition, in my opinion, makes very inane comments in response to what is a serious and worthwhile proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is once again directed to the Minister for Communications. I remind the Minister that yesterday he told the House that the Attorney-General's Department had proffered advice that to put a financial hurdle in place would not enable the Government to have a price based system. I ask the Minister now: is it not a fact that there is no mention in the Attorney-General's advice to either non-refundable deposits or financial as distinct from other hurdles, and that as a consequence, yesterday, the Minister misled the Parliament?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just not the case. Let me make it very clear. I will read the advice given to me:

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the existing bidders, in particular Hi Vision and UCOM, concerns that have been raised about financial capability to meet the bid and the suitability of directors and other associated persons, the advice from the Attorney-General's Department of 23 November 1992 indicates that these concerns could not lawfully have been addressed in the determination of the allocation system of setting up hurdles which applicants would need to satisfy before moving into final selection based on price.

What we have continually said about the reference to the deposit is that there is a problem with the process. That process is being investigated in the department, and we know that honourable members opposite will now support the legislation I will bring into this chamber after Question Time to put in place a deposit, if it is required, by any future bidder.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Industrial Relations inform the House about recent trends in official statistics measuring the level of industrial disputes in Australia? What action is the Government taking to ensure a continuation of a low level of industrial disputation? Is the Minister aware of alternative proposals affecting industrial disputes?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I inform him and the House that I am delighted with the most recent ABS statistics regarding the level of industrial disputes for the month of January 1993. They show that the number of disputes, that is, 35, and the number of employees involved, that is, 4,400, were the lowest recorded at any time since December 1961—31 and a bit years ago. For the year to January 1993, the number of working days lost per thousand employees at 158—I repeat, 158—was at its lowest level since 1962.

PARA.TAB: These outstanding figures do, however, mask some worrying trends because, whilst the Australia-wide figures are at a record low level, the number of working days lost per thousand employees was higher in both Victoria and Tasmania: Victoria at 370 and Tasmania at 285. In Victoria the position has significantly deteriorated since the election of the Kennett Government last October. Honourable members opposite do not like the statistics, but they tell a story. For instance, in November 1992, 83 per cent, or 502,400 of the working days lost in Australia were lost in Victoria. Similarly, 60 per cent of the working days lost in December were also lost in Victoria. Given the renewed bout of industrial trouble in Victoria—and I might say there was a stoppage yesterday and the Opposition was conspicuously silent in this place—it seems that that State will continue to inflate the national figures.

The high level of disputation in Victoria has been caused by the removal of the safety net of awards caused by the abolition of the industrial commission there and the move towards individual contracts. That is an approach that is mirrored in the Opposition's jobsback policy. For our part, in promoting cooperative workplace reform, we have rejected that approach, the Victorian approach, the jobsback approach. We have undertaken to keep a safety net of awards; we have undertaken to legislate for national minimum standards, to maintain the industrial umpire and to promote collective bargaining, not individual contracts.

We are confident of our approach, and we know that on 13 March the Victorian approach was categorically rejected. Indeed, if one includes Tasmania, seven of the seats won by the Government were in the two States that really went out of their way to embrace the policies of conflict. Already the Federal Government's approach has seen more than 800 federal enterprise agreements covering 680,000 workers put in place. Meanwhile, in Victoria, for all the disputation, for all the horror, we have seen only 50 employment contracts launched in that State to date.

It is clear that the Victorian, and hence the jobsback, policy approach has failed, and failed dismally. It seems to me that the only one who does not accept that is the honourable member for Bennelong, whom I saw on the Sunday program only the Sunday before last. He said that keeping the award system as a safety net had no appeal whatsoever for him and the only aspect of his policy that he would change was the $3 an hour youth wage—of course, he does not attribute that policy to himself, but to the Leader of the Opposition.

The truth is that, unless the coalition changes course and adopts the Government's cooperative approach, we will see Jobsback go the same way as Fightback and the same way as the Victorian industrial relations system—that is, right down the gurgler.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Following the election of the Kennett Government in Victoria, Northland Secondary College—a school with a much respected Aboriginal program—was closed. Subsequently, but in an unrelated incident, the St Kilda footballer Nicky Winmar was the target for racial abuse during a game at the Collingwood football ground. Given the Prime Minister's avowed commitment to Aboriginal reconciliation, why has the Federal Government decided against providing funding for Northland Secondary College? Furthermore, given his eminent involvement with the Collingwood Football Club, does he intend painting the big picture for those football barrackers and officials whose insensitivity has impeded the progress of reconciliation?

—I do not think one can make the logical link that because one is committed to reconciliation with the Aboriginal community therefore the Commonwealth must fund every school in the country which in any way services Aboriginal children. The State of Victoria well understands the special qualities of some of these schools—schools for intellectually handicapped children and other disadvantaged groups, as well as schools supporting Aboriginal children—and they have been well debated publicly in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: These are judgments which have to be made, and are being made, by the Victorian Government. Governments get elected to make judgments but, again, they have to temper those judgments with the social considerations which are relevant at any particular place or at any particular time. I think the honourable member's concern is well placed, but the place to remedy it is the Government of Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —The second part of his question.

—You are a stickler for the big picture issues, Tim, I know—particularly the big social issues of the day. Yes, I am a supporter of the Collingwood Football Club; and proud to say so. I am quite sure the President of that club, Mr McAlister, has understood that his remarks have offended the Aboriginal community in this country and, as I have read the reports, he has sought to redress them. I suppose being basically a clever fellow, he will learn from that mistake. I am not sure the same can be said for the whole community in some of these respects.

PARA.TAB: I can only hope that the publicity which has been given to his remarks in Victoria will be a good thing for the reconciliation process. If the goodwill which he has demonstrated subsequently is any measure, the community will be much better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Is the Minister aware of recent reports regarding an anomaly in the application of Austudy for a number of Queensland TAFE students? What action has he taken to resolve this matter?

—I thank the honourable member for Moreton for his question. Yes, I am aware of the problem which was reported in Tuesday's Courier-Mail and also followed representations from the honourable member for Groom. With Austudy, as with many other initiatives, the Government is constantly looking at ways to make a good system work better.

PARA.TAB: At the broad level we recently introduced the Austudy supplement which allows young Australians to increase their income at their time of greatest need; that is, when they are studying, with repayments commencing five years after they graduate and then only when their income exceeds $27,700 a year. I note that a recent study in the Australian Economic Review showed that up to 88 per cent of female students and 68 per cent of male students would be better off by taking up the supplement.

In the case mentioned by the honourable member, we are again conscious to ensure that the scheme applies fairly. It appears that some students studying at Toowoomba TAFE had lost Austudy eligibility for 10 weeks because the TAFE put back the commencement date of the course at very late notice. The Austudy rules were correctly applied. It is not normally appropriate to pay Austudy to students for periods of several months in the year in advance of starting their course. In this case, however, there was a clear anomaly. The postponement of the course commencement date was entirely beyond the control of the student.

In the circumstances, therefore, I have instructed that an amendment be made to the Austudy regulations to provide for the backdating of assistance to students who, because of circumstances beyond their control, start their course later than the allowable starting period.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question once again is directed to the Minister for Communications. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that when Senator Collins was interviewed on Lateline last night he was specifically asked by Kerry O'Brien whether the Attorney-General's advice made it unlawful to include a non-refundable deposit in the conditions for the tender. Senator Collins said, `No, of course it doesn't. As I say, look at the advice'. Will the Minister explain to the House why he is totally at odds with Senator Collins on this matter and why he has just mislead the House a second time?
—The honourable member for Goldstein is continually clutching at straws. He should read the advice that he is referring to—
—I have.

—Then he cannot read. If he has a look at the advice, what I was referring to the House yesterday in particular was proposal A in the advice. The series of questions and answers there clearly indicate that I did not mislead the House.
—Mr Speaker, as the Minister has—
—Order! If the honourable member for O'Connor has a point of order to raise, he will come to the dispatch box.
—Mr Speaker, as the Minister has referred to a document tabled in the Senate, would he please table that document?
—My recollection was that the Minister referred to a document in the possession of the honourable member for Goldstein. There is no point of order.
—Could I ask that the Minister table the first document he referred to in the answer before this last one when he quoted what he has claimed to be advice? Can he table that document?
—It is a confidential document.
—The Minister for Communications: were you quoting from private documents?
—Yes. It is confidential.
—I call the honourable member for Fowler.
—Mr Speaker—
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. He knows better than to simply stand. Until he is called he does not start to speak to the Chair.

—I raise a point of order. If a member asks that a document be tabled, it should be done at the time. It was not done at the time. At any rate, it is for the Minister to decide whether it is a public document. As I understand it, it is a private note.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order on this matter. I would refer you to the fact that the Minister said in his last answer that the document he referred to was the document that was tabled yesterday. I would ask that you check Hansard on this very important matter.
—I have already ruled on that particular issue. There is no point of order.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. What is the Government doing to relieve the appalling human suffering in the former Yugoslavia?

—It gives me no pleasure to agree with my friend and colleague the honourable member for Fowler about the nature of the suffering in Bosnia. I think that on both sides of the House we would all agree that that is appalling and that it is right for the Australian Government to make a response to it.

PARA.TAB: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—The Australian Government has already provided over $1 million in emergency humanitarian assistance to the former Yugoslavia. In response to that continuing and deplorable suffering in that region my predecessor, the honourable member for Werriwa, announced in March that the Government would provide a further $300,000 for relief activities. On the basis of advice that we have had from Australian missions and international agencies working on the ground in Bosnia-Herzegovina, I have decided that that increased support for relief efforts should be channelled through United Nations agencies.

PARA.TAB: Those agencies have advised us in turn that the highest priority is simply for food. Consequently, I have decided that $200,000 of the additional $300,000 will be provided to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for emergency food supplies, and that a further $100,000 will be allocated to UNICEF, the United Nations children's fund, for services to the principal victims of the conflict in the former Yugoslavia who, tragically, are mainly women and children. Those two agencies have the experience, the independence and the infrastructure to maximise the effectiveness of the aid that we are providing. Like most of our previous assistance, it will be made up not just of food but also of clothing and medical supplies, with provision also for the counselling of rape victims. It will help meet the most pressing needs of people who have fled the fighting, particularly refugees from Bosnia-Herzegovina.

Obviously, and tragically, no amount of money will ever fully stem the suffering in the former Yugoslavia; that trauma will linger for years, even if the fighting stops soon. But help from Australia can make a difference; it can help prevent malnutrition, disease and death, and it can help people in small ways to start their lives again. Unfortunately, that task will not be properly fulfilled unless the peace efforts which are now, I hope, bearing some fruit are fully fulfilled.
