INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The cavalier attitude displayed by the Government towards ministerial responsibility in the pay TV affair.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well known in this Parliament and around the country that the present Government is intent on overturning many of the traditional attitudes, practices, customs and conventions of this country. Some of them may have stated, some of them may have inferred, but I never believed that we would have demonstrated in the first two days of Parliament the absolute commitment of this Government to the complete overturning of any semblance of the doctrine of ministerial responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Ministerial responsibility has probably been defined more frequently, and on occasions has been attended by more humbug, than just about any other doctrine in our parliamentary system. But, reducing a definition of it to the essence of language that I believe most Australians would identify with—in other words, if I could give it a nationalistic definition; and I am sure that would appeal to those who sit opposite—most Australians would understand ministerial responsibility as meaning simply this: if we take the car and the money, we have also got to take the responsibility. That is what, through the whole of this episode, Senator Collins and the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) have conspicuously failed to do.

We have this unfolding saga of farce and drama where the bungling incompetence not of the departments but of the Ministers has been revealed. It reached its absolute apotheosis today when the Minister for Communications not only found himself guilty of having misled the Parliament on two occasions—he misled the Parliament yesterday and he misled the Parliament today—but he also found himself in absolute and direct conflict with Senator Collins.

The nub of this whole matter is that the Government has realised that Senator Collins should have imposed a requirement of the payment of a non-refundable deposit when he made those decisions and before they were announced with such fanfare a couple of weeks ago. If that had been done, all of the nonsense about the financial stability, the viability, the capacity to raise equity and all of those other attendant matters would have never arisen. But what he basically says now is, `Look, I could not do that because the law would not allow me to do so'. It transpires that Senator Collins was presented with a bit of paper that stated, `You can ask them to put down $500'. He was talking about hundreds of millions of dollars. He was talking about $389 million for the Budget of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis).

In those circumstances, if a Minister of the Crown is presented with a bit of paper that he instinctively knows relates to a tender that is worth hundreds of millions of dollars, is he really saying to the Australian public that a man or woman exercising ordinary commonsense without any advice at all would not find it passing strange that an amount of $500 is a bit on the light side? Does the Minister really need the advice of the crown law authorities to tell him that? Does he really need the advice of the department of communications to tell him that?

It seems that members of this Labor Government have terrible trouble when it comes to documents. Some of them have trouble when they sign documents, as with Senator Collins, and some of them had problems a few years ago, on two occasions, when they did not sign documents, namely taxation returns.

The fundamental charge that we make against this Government, against Senator Collins and against the Minister for Communications in this place is the very simple, uncluttered proposition that Senator Collins failed the ordinary commonsense test of a reasonable person applying his mind in a reasonable manner to a fairly simple proposition. That is what it is all about. We really have to ask ourselves whether a man who fails to realise that $500 is on the light side when we are dealing with hundreds of millions of dollars is really fit to discharge the responsibilities of ministerial office.

What does the Minister do? Does the Minister have the common decency to stand up and say, `Look, I made a mistake. I did not read what I signed'—in other words, in the parlance of this Parliament—`I did a Jim Cairns; I did not read what I signed.'? The honourable member for Warringah (Mr Mackellar), the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) and others who were there at the time well remember the price that Jim Cairns paid when he did not read what he signed when given a document. He did not remember that he offered a commission to George Harris to pledge the worth of the Commonwealth around the world in order to raise loans. He did not realise it. He obviously did not read what he signed.

Quite honestly, that is what I believe happened on this occasion—Senator Collins did not read it. I cannot believe that he would be so stupid to accept that $500 was enough when we are talking about something worth hundreds of millions of dollars. What other explanation can there be? He was either grossly negligent in not reading what he signed or he was totally stupid in accepting the advice that he was given. He cannot lay the blame on anybody else.

What I think sticks in the craw of many people on this side of the House is that, when something goes wrong with that mob over there—do honourable members know what they do? They always lay the blame on somebody else. When the then Minister for the Arts, Sport, Environment and Territories signed the cover and did not read the inside, it was all her department's fault. When her department issued those motifs for the Commonwealth Games or the Olympic Games and there was not any representation of women athletes on it, she really lectured staff of her department; she really ticked them off. She brought the head of the department down, she really carpeted him and told him that he had to lift his game. There was no suggestion that she might have to lift her game; no suggestion on this occasion that the bumbling Senator Collins ought to lift his game. What does he do? He says, `I cannot understand how my department can be so incompetent'. He ordered an intra-departmental inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they are not able to defend themselves.

—As the honourable member for Bendigo properly interjects, they are unable to defend themselves. And what else does he do? Today he announces in the Senate that he is going to have an inquiry into the department conducted by an outsider with legal and administrative experience. If he is going to do that, why will the Government not agree to a Senate inquiry? Why is the Government stonewalling on a Senate inquiry? Does the Government not like the idea of this thing being let loose in the hands of the Senate?

PARA.TAB: The Government does not want the questions to be asked because any dispassionate inquiry into this matter is ultimately going to say to Senator Collins, `If you want the car and the money, you've also got to take the responsibility'. That is what ministerial responsibility is all about. And there are a lot of people sitting over there who would like to be Ministers; there are a lot of people who try very hard to become Ministers in a government party. Senator Collins has got plenty of competition, and Senator Collins is sitting on a knife edge.

The really poor, unfortunate person of this little exercise is the good old Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall). He is only the immediate past new generation, because he was appointed after the last turnover in the Government's ministry. And what has been his contribution today?

TALK.START.PARA: —Confusion.

—Confusion, as the Leader of the Opposition says. What was his contribution yesterday? It was to try to tell this House that he had legal advice which said that, if one imposes some kind of financial hurdle, one would undermine the whole basis of a cash based bidding system.

—I am glad the Minister interjected. That is what he said yesterday. And he wanted the House to believe that non-refundable deposits equalled financial hurdles, and he wanted the House to believe yesterday—and he repeated it today—that the Attorney-General's Department had told the Government that one could not do that.

PARA.TAB: The Minister compounded his error today in answer to the second last question put to him, by not reading from the advice of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). He did not read from the Attorney-General's advice; he read from the advice given to him for Question Time by his own department. And that is why he did not want to table that document. Yet he was trying to mislead the House into believing that he was reading from the advice of the Attorney-General's Department.

Why does the Minister not have the honesty to get up and say whether he is telling the truth on that subject? That is why he did not want to table the document when the Leader of the Opposition asked him to: because he had read from the advice of his department which was some kind of paraphrasing—and a shonky one at that—of the advice of the Attorney-General's Department. The truth is that there is nothing, according to our reading, in the advice of the Attorney-General's Department to back up what the Minister said yesterday. There is nothing at all in the advice that talks about financial hurdles or undermining the cash price basis of the tendering system. And the Minister repeated today that which he misled the House on yesterday. He has compounded his deception by trying to mislead us into believing that today in his first answer he quoted from the Attorney-General's advice when he knew damn well that he had quoted from his department's advice. That is why the Minister wanted to keep it under wraps. The Minister has failed the basic test of ministerial responsibility: he is not being truthful to his peers in the Parliament. The fundamental obligation that people have in this place is to tell the truth when they come before the dispatch box in this Parliament.

But the Minister has another problem. Not even Senator Collins agrees with him on the proposition about hurdles. If the Minister had seen Senator Collins last night on Lateline—and I would have thought at the moment that viewing such an interview was de rigueur for Keating Government Ministers given the problem that they have with the subject—he would have seen that a very simple proposition was put to him. Senator Collins said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if any of those conditions had been put on prior to price being used to determine the allocation, it would have been unlawful to have done it.
Kerry O'Brien interjected and said:
And that includes the issue of a non-refundable deposit?
Senator Collins's answer was:
No, of course it doesn't. As I say, look at the advice.

In other words, last night Senator Collins was saying that the advice did not say that the Government could not impose a non-refundable deposit. Not only was the Minister wrong in trying to infer that to the House—he did it yesterday and again today—but also he was out of step with what Senator Collins had said, and he was also misleading the House in trying to have us believe that non-financial hurdles equalled and included the imposition of a non-refundable deposit as a condition of accepting a tender.

PARA.TAB: The Minister is wrong about that. He has contradicted Senator Collins. He has misled the Parliament twice in trying to foist upon us a false view of the advice of the Attorney-General's Department. And he made it even worse today by trying to have us believe that the advice he was reading from was the advice of the Attorney-General's Department and not the advice of his own department. I think the Minister has failed the basic test of ministerial responsibility. I think that he has made an almighty mess of the situation and, quite honestly, if ever anybody fitted the exaltation, `If you want the car and the money, you have to take the responsibility as well', the Minister for Communications certainly does. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with great interest to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). It is really very interesting. We have from the honourable member for Bennelong a large amount of frustration: first, at not being on this side of the House, and, secondly, at not being supported in the ballot when he put himself forward to the members of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: I said that I had listened very carefully. I must correct one point. The honourable member for Bennelong stretches a long bow. He said that I had tried to mislead the House by saying I was quoting from advice from the Attorney-General's Department. I said I had been advised. If the honourable member checks that, I am sure he will find that to be the case. I did not try to pretend that it was advice from the Attorney-General's Department; it was a confidential document to me. There were other pieces of advice in that document that were not related to the issue.

I think ministerial responsibility is a very important issue. In my view, it is the ultimate responsibility of Ministers to deliver good policy to the benefit of Australia. That is the real responsibility of Ministers, and is exactly what the whole issue is about today.

The policy of the Government is very clear and, I believe, correct in this particular case; that is, for a national pay TV system to be delivered by satellite using compressed digital technology for the benefit of all Australians. The ultimate policy angle is to deliver that technology at the same time as we receive the best price for what is a public asset. That is the ultimate policy here; that is what this is all about. The Opposition continues on fishing expeditions because it has nothing of substance to talk about.

For the record, I will outline what this process is because I think it is very important. The process to allocate licences A and B following close of tenders involves basically three steps. Firstly, the bids are assessed on price. This is an impartial means of selecting who goes on to the next stage. Secondly, it involves the ABA and the TPC checking the validity of the bids. The third and final stage is the discipline of the marketplace, the Opposition's favourite marketplace, requiring that the bid price be paid in full in 30 days.

This worked in detail as follows. A decision was made by the communications selection team, with Attorney-General's advice, as referred to by the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), on the conformity of the bids. The highest priced tenders were then identified for each of licences A and B and the company was then advised accordingly. Details of the successful tenders were then referred to the Australian Broadcasting Authority by the Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications so that the process could be undertaken for the issue of the licence. The ABA then needed to form a view about the suitability of the applicants under section 98 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992. The ABA referred the ownership details of each tender to the Trade Practices Commission for an opinion under section 93 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 regarding the compliance with part IV of the Trade Practices Act 1974.

The Trade Practices Commission has a maximum of 45 days to provide that opinion to the ABA, but it can obviously take less time, depending on the complexity of the issues involved. When these processes are complete, the ABA will notify the applicants. The licence can be issued on payment of the bid price within 30 days of that notification. The company needs to persuade the marketplace that the amount of its bid and its plans for running the company are commercially viable. If it cannot persuade the market to provide the necessary capital, the bid will fail. This is the policy that Senator Collins put in place, and is, I think, a good policy for the people of Australia. If the tenderers cannot pay the bid amount, the licence will be offered to the next highest bidder.

The process is a very open one. It involves scrutiny by the Australian Broadcasting Authority and the Trade Practices Commission. It also involves scrutiny by the marketplace. If the price offered is too high, the bid will fail. The Government has acknowledged that there is a deficiency in the process and has acted swiftly to correct the problem. But the problem is only one of process, as the Opposition would understand if it really looked at this issue. I hope that there will be support today when we introduce the Bill to fix up the problem of process. It is not a problem of policy, which is the responsibility of Ministers and not departments.

The outcome will be that licence holders who have met the standards required by the ABA and the TPC will then be charged with providing digital satellite technology to the people of Australia for pay television with the payment to the public purse of an amount which reflects the market value of the public asset, which exposes the claims by the Opposition of deals with media mates for what they are—tired lines from an intellectually bankrupt Opposition.

Honourable members on the other side of the House are being too opportunistic and two-faced. They dress this issue up as ministerial responsibility, but they do not know what it means. The Opposition is using this issue to cover up the fact that it agrees with what we have done and what we are about to do.

I will quote from the shadow Minister for communications, Senator Alston. The comments were made in the context of Senator Alston's claims on the weekend that we should have adopted a merit based process to test the financial viability of bidders. This is completely contrary to the policy principles Senator Alston outlined on behalf of his party in the chamber during the tabling of the Senate committee report. Arguing against an exclusivity period for the initial licensees, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would certainly argue that viability is a relevant factor but it ought to be a matter for the players and the marketplace.
Later in the same debate Senator Alston said:

The need to ensure diversity will largely be a matter for consumers and I think it will evolve over time without any direct intervention. . . Certainly viability ought to be a matter for commercial judgement rather than for Government intervention.

The Opposition is claiming that, in some fashion, Senator Collins did not act with propriety or responsibility. This is not borne out by the actual charge made in the Senate. It was not a charge concerning policy. The whole process in the charges is one concerning process. That is the differential here. Ministers are charged, I firmly believe, with the administration of policy. It was a charge dealing with process, as I said before. It was claimed that he was negligent in not reading the details of the tender document.

PARA.TAB: That sort of detail is a matter for administration. The Minister who makes the policy and objectives clear is acting responsibly. That is what both Senator Collins and I have continued to do. It is up to the department to get the administration right. The first occasion that Senator Collins and I were aware of a deficiency with the satellite licence tender process was after Friday, 30 April 1993 when the announcement was made. We were made aware over that weekend. As Ministers, responsibly we took action.

Senator Collins initiated the investigation into the department's process and we initiated legislative amendments to overcome the deficiency. It is not only the Government that is saying this. Let me quote from last Tuesday's Sydney Morning Herald which said:

SPEECH.PARA: The priority considerations in awarding the pay TV licences are to get the best value for taxpayers and the best value for future pay TV viewers.
What they have won is the right to be vetted by the Trade Practices Commission and the Australian Broadcasting Authority as potential licensees.

PARA.TAB: Critics should also consider what alternative procedures were available for awarding the licences. Of course, the Government could have stepped in, examined all the bids, and decided that only some consortia had the wherewithal to tender for a licence. But on what basis would it have made that decision? Just as importantly, on what basis would the Government have been perceived to have based its decision? Favouring its media mates? Picking winners? A price-only tender not only had the virtue of simplicity but of an absolutely objective criterion for ranking the bids.

Another criticism of the tender process is that it has thrown up two companies with no proven experience when it comes to getting a pay TV service up and running. That may be perfectly true. But it doesn't follow that only established media companies should therefore be considered for pay TV licences. That is an argument for maintaining an exclusive industry club.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me also quote from Fred Brenchley's article in last Tuesday's Australian Financial Review, which said:
Three cheers for the auction process.

PARA.TAB: After years of political interference and delay on pay TV, the auction of two licences has at last introduced a note of impartiality and market discipline.
The auction has demonstrated not only that some 50 bidders are prepared to participate in pay TV, but they are also willing to pay a substantial economic rent to do so.
The auction has introduced some much needed arm's-length handling of licences to operate public airwaves. That arm's length can now be measured by that great market leveller—price.

That document clearly indicates that setting up the hurdles would have impeded a price based bid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been a member of this chamber for 8 1/2 years. In those 8 1/2 years I have not seen a more pathetic defence by a Minister under attack in this Parliament than that seen today and yesterday. Neither this afternoon nor yesterday did the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) answer the allegations levelled at him by honourable members on this side of the House. The allegations go to the very heart of his responsibility as a Minister of the Crown. They surround the fact that he misled the House today and yesterday—a total of twice in two days. They are allegations of incompetence, both on his part and on the part of his senior Minister, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins.

PARA.TAB: We see from this display today the result of having a ministerial appointment system designed not on merit but on the basis of which State members come from, which gender they belong to, whom they voted for in the last leadership ballot or which faction they come from. That is the method of appointment of Ministers under this Government. The natural consequence of appointing people under that methodology is that fools and incompetents rise to the office of Minister. If we ever wanted to see an example of the truth of that, we have just witnessed it today, and we witnessed it yesterday when we sat here and listened to this Minister's defence.

We have seen in this issue, as we have seen over the last few years, a complete lack of ministerial responsibility and an inability to administer a portfolio in a competent and professional fashion. I am reminded of 1988, I think it was, when the former honourable member for Parramatta, Mr John Brown, was under attack over an Expo contract. Do those who were here then remember that? That Minister ultimately had to resign because he misled the House.

I suggest today to this Minister that he ought to go back to his office and start to think about his future, because he has not addressed the claims and the allegations that were made this afternoon in this House by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) in his address on the matter of public importance. We have seen today and over a period of years that when Ministers get into trouble they try to wriggle out of their responsibilities.

What has the Minister for Transport and Communications said over the last few days? He has said, `Oh, this giant embarrassment, this complete stuff-up, is not my fault but the department's fault. It is the one to blame. Don't blame me. I am only the Minister for Transport and Communications'. Where does the buck stop when it comes to responsibility in the administration of government in Australia? Under the system that has operated in this country since Federation, the buck rests with the Minister responsible; yet these people who are prepared to accept all the kudos, all the wages and all the lurks and perks of office are not prepared to accept that the buck stops with them.

This Government has been a champion at this practice, whether it is the Minister for Communications in this House or the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, in the other House. We have had plenty of examples of this situation with other Ministers. I am reminded of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), who has been in a lot of trouble over the years. That is why he has been called Biggles. Do honourable members remember the problems that he got into over the appointment of Brian Burke as our Ambassador to Ireland? It was not his fault; it was the responsibility of a departmental officer. Do honourable members remember the Marshall Islands affair? It was not his fault; it was the fault of the responsible officer—in fact, I think it might have been his senior adviser, Miles Cooper—not the Minister's fault. Exactly the same trick is trying to be pulled today. The Government will not get away with it because we on this side of the House know what ministerial responsibility is all about.

I suggest that members on the government side of the House also know what ministerial responsibility is all about, because I happened to take the opportunity today to go back over some of the things that these people said when they were in opposition. I go back to a speech made by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), who is now the President of the Federal Labor Party. In a speech in September 1981 when he was in opposition, he referred to ministerial responsibility and said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . But if a major blunder occurred in a department, of real importance to Australia, and if the minister were unaware of it, that minister should accept responsibility for the mistakes of his department and offer to resign.
The following year, the Hon. Lionel Bowen became Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, and in a speech in September 1982 he said:
Ministerial responsibility, I remind honourable members, does not concern the question of what one knew; it concerns the question of what one ought to have known.

The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who still sits in this House today, is sitting on the back bench now—not because of any personal responsibility, but because of a failure to get his department to administer what he should have done. He paid the penalty. A speech made by Lionel Bowen a few weeks later indicated that these people really knew what ministerial responsibility was. They are trying to wriggle out of it. Lionel Bowen said this:
Each Minister is responsible to parliament for the conduct of his Department. The act of every civil servant is by convention regarded as an act of his Minister.

If this inquiry set up by the Minister to try to ease the pressure on him proves that the mistake was made by a civil servant in his own department, then under the guidelines referred to by these people in opposition that Minister, Senator Collins, ought to resign. I suggest that these people really know that that is the truth of what ministerial responsibility is all about.

PARA.TAB: It is just sad that as we stand here today—two days after the opening of this Parliament for a new session, to try to give people of this country some fresh hope—we see members of this Government trying to wriggle out of their responsibilities. It shows to us that these people are immense hypocrites. They have not been able to live up to the oaths of office that they took as Ministers of the Crown. They have not lived up to the standards that they set for others to live up to when they were in opposition 10 or 12 years ago, and they have not been able to convince anybody here in this House today or yesterday that the charges of incompetence are not well made. The Minister for Communications has not been able to convince us that the charge that he misled the House on two occasions, which was levelled at him by the honourable member for Bennelong, is not correct.

I would suggest to the members of this House this afternoon, as we lead this debate, that it would be interesting to find out what this Minister will do when he goes back to his office. If he is a person of honour and dignity, as I hope he is, and if he is the sort of person who stands up to the principles that Ministers of the Crown before him have ultimately had to stand up to, that he, along with his colleague, Senator Collins, will offer his resignation to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

I would hope that in the interests of good administration, in the interests of maintaining the Westminster system of democracy, the Prime Minister will accept those resignations, because if he does not accept them, then I suggest that this Government has no principles and no standards. All that its members are here to do is to get the honour and the glory, the big pay cheque, and the lurks and perks but take none of the responsibility. If they try to wriggle out of this by blaming it on everybody else, nobody will believe it.

I put to the Minister again the allegation, made by the honourable member for Bennelong, that he has misled this House on two occasions and that his administration of his portfolio has been incompetent, and that he should resign.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to note the way that this debate has developed. It started off to be a matter of public importance based on the topic of ministerial responsibility, and progressed further to claims made by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) that the Minister has misled the House.

PARA.TAB: It is a very serious claim to make in this place that someone has misled the House, and in this particular case, it is very wrong. Not a single word that the Minister for Communications (Mr Beddall) has said at this dispatch box, since he got his first question in the portfolio yesterday, has had one element out of place and incorrect. I have listened very carefully to every word he has said, and I have had some interest in this matter for some time. So to come here and make the claim that a Minister has misled the House, knowing very well that not a word he has said was wrong, is in fact serious and mischievous.

Let us go to the heart of the matter. The key question being asked really is whether anything that the Minister for Communications said in his answers in this House yesterday or today is wrong. Those opposite claim to have the document that the Minister also used as his source—the Attorney-General's advice. They know very well—having heard his answer yesterday, and having had all yesterday afternoon, all last night and all of this morning to pore over it—that had one single word that the Minister uttered been out of place in relation to that document they could have put it on the table today. Where was the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp)—the Opposition's new star, its communications person—who is supposed to be putting the Minister under pressure? He did not even speak in the MPI today. The big star led us off yesterday with all his questions, but they went absolutely nowhere. The one reason why the questions went absolutely nowhere is that nothing the Minister said either yesterday or today was in any way wrong or misleading of the House.

Let me go next to a couple of other questions those opposite might ask. Has the Minister for Communications, or the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) for that matter, said anything in this debate that reflects either an error or a mistake? In this tender for the pay TV licences the Government made a decision to go with a price based process. For those people who do not understand the difference between a price based allocation and what the Minister for Communications correctly referred to yesterday as a beauty contest or a hurdles system, it might be interesting to note that the Government had a choice. This Government has had substantial experience now with a range of tenders, not just in transport and communications issues but in very major government projects over time.

One way to tackle the problem is to say to potential bidders, `Yes, we are looking for the price that you are offering, but here are hurdles that you will also have to meet in order to get the nod'. In this case, in the very difficult area of government broadcasting licences, the sorts of hurdles that have to be examined at some point under the legislation are whether the ownership requirements in the bid meet the Government's requirements for Australian ownership, foreign equity and the other issues that come into the ownership of licences; whether the bidder has the capability to carry out the function—I will come to this very important point in this case in a second—and whether the Australian content requirements have been met. Unlike those on the other side of the House, we actually do require that Australian industry and Australian film and production get a draw in these decisions. Whether the industry development requirements meet the policy and whether the bidder understands all the other conditions that are being set for the granting of the licence also have to be examined. Those hurdles can be set in place in the process and considered at the time of judgment of the bid. However, the minute that is done there is a move away from price only into the making of subjective judgments about whether one particular bid is better than another for a whole lot of reasons.

If honourable members in this chamber are not aware of the sensitivities involved in selecting pay TV licences—there is a very broad perception out there that, no matter which way the Government goes, whatever decision is taken, there will be inferences made that it was done to give benefit to some particular interest group—the Government made a very deliberate decision that in the first stage of the tendering process it would be price based only.

Those opposite claim to have a document. I have a document which I do not intend to table; it is confidential advice to the Government. If those opposite reckon they have it, they should table it. The document I have seen contains specific legal advice on this point. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not consider that hurdles can be incorporated into the pre-qualification stage whereby some potential bidders are eliminated before their bids are assessed on a price basis.

Simply placing obstacles in the way and still claiming that it is a price based system is not on. Let us then turn to the question the honourable member for Bennelong raised about the deposit. It does not matter what level of deposit is set; at some point people who are interested in the process will claim that they have been denied their due process under a `price based system'. In fact, the document the honourable member claims to have says exactly that—and he knows it.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Bennelong also asked: why has the Minister decided that this will be an administrative investigation and not a Senate inquiry? That is a very good question for him to ask because we can go back to Minister Collins's comments last year when those opposite decided to set a Senate inquiry going. His most prophetic words were, `Pay TV is now going to disappear into the great black hole of the Senate'. From the day the Senate got hold of it, the whole process has been stalled and messed about. Not only has it caused everybody to have to revisit the whole issue time and time again, but also it has also caused us to have serious questions about the ability of those in the other place to consider this matter without a direct political impression and direction as to how to tackle it.

There is this issue of resolving the administrative question as to the deposit in the system. The Minister has the legislation to introduce, for future reference. Those opposite can say that Minister Collins, in looking through hundreds of pages of documents, did not notice that the five per cent requirement was not there. No problem, he has admitted that everywhere—including on the Lateline program last night, as the honourable member said. But to come in here and say that any of this represents an attempt to mislead this House is not only wrong and known to be wrong, but also gravely serious. Those opposite do not do themselves any justice in saying so.

Bill presented by Mr Beddall, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 introduces changes to part 7 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to modify some aspects of the procedures for allocating satellite subscription television broadcasting licences A and B. Let me make clear at the outset that this amendment does not apply to those tenderers who were announced as the highest bidders on 30 April 1993. Those companies' applications are now at the second stage of the established process which will continue to finality. This legislation does not reflect a judgment that either of the current highest bidders is unable to meet its bid, but is to ensure that appropriate procedures are in place should such a contingency arise.

PARA.TAB: The process to allocate these licences, which was determined under section 93 of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, has three stages. The first stage that has just been completed involves an impartial assessment of complying tenders to identify which delivered the highest bid price. The second stage involves assessment of the tenderers so identified by the Australian Broadcasting Authority, which will need to form a view about the suitability of the applicants under section 98 of the Act. The ABA will also seek the opinion of the Trade Practices Commission in relation to part IV of the Trade Practices Act as required under section 93 of the Act.

The third stage involves actual issuance of the licence but only after the ABA and TPC processes have been satisfied and the full bid price paid. Under the legislation, Trade Practices Commission consideration could take up to 45 days. Following that, licensees have 30 days within which to pay the bid price. The interest of the public is that the issuance of pay television licences and the effective commencement of broadcasting services should occur as soon as possible. This has always been the Government's intention.

Until licences A and B are issued, it is not possible for the standard for a digital transmission system to be declared, nor for a third licence to be issued to the ABC. The legislation before the House therefore provides that, in the event that either of the present highest tenderers were not successful, any alternative tenderer who thereby had the opportunity to be assessed as a potential licensee would be required to provide a deposit of five per cent of the amount of its bid within three days of being given that opportunity.

That deposit would not be refundable if the licence was not subsequently allocated, unless non-allocation was due to an unfavourable report by the Trade Practices Commission. This amendment will put an additional step in the process after the initial identification of highest bidders. Its purpose is to provide an additional indication that those tenderers have the financial capacity to pay the price bid hence justifying continuation of the process through its detailed assessment stages.
The Bill is not expected to have a significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

I look forward to working with you during the term of this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to acknowledge, as you did yesterday, Mr Deputy Speaker, the work of your predecessor, the former honourable member for Stirling, Mr Ron Edwards, as the Deputy Speaker in this place. Ron was and remains a very good friend of both yours and mine. I miss him, of course, as I am sure we all will in this place. I just wanted to put that on the record too. I am sure we will see Ron from time to time if he does not come back the next time around. But that is another matter.

Earlier, before this debate was adjourned, I was speaking on the reference in the Governor-General's speech to employment, education and training. The Government will review the employment, education and training programs with a view to ensuring that those benefits are actually delivered to young people—indeed, all people who are unfortunately unemployed. It is important that that review goes ahead as soon as possible to ensure that those benefits do pass on to those people.

I will certainly work with my local community, the business community, trade unions, trainers and other community groups in the Ipswich region in particular to ensure that they make a contribution to those discussions. I am sure, knowing the people involved, they will be very keen to make a contribution to those discussions. I will be giving them every encouragement to play an active part in that process.

Earlier the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) spoke about the personnel at the Amberley Air Force base. Shortly a big housing development will be commenced in Ipswich. That development was referred by the Minister earlier to the Standing Committee on Public Works. I turn to the defence area and speak a little bit about that because the Amberley Air Force base is in my electorate, which is the home of the F111s, and the defence industry is very important to my electorate.

Of course, the important role of the F111s in Australia's defence was actually in danger under the policies that the coalition took to the last election. The then coalition defence spokesman, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), made it clear that the purchase of an additional 18 F111s to be used as spares, which was announced by the Government last year, would actually be in jeopardy under a coalition government.

However, it soon became apparent that there were divisions between the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and his defence spokesman on the issue of the purchase of these F111s. In an unannounced photo opportunity, I suppose one could call it, during the election campaign the Leader of the Opposition dropped into Amberley for his aircraft to be refuelled and was actually photographed in the cockpit of an F111. When the defence people had him in the cockpit of the F111 they suggested that it would be a good time for him to review the coalition's policy on the F111s. Of course he said that he would review the situation at the right time, but he did not give any commitment that he would change it. Anyway, the people of Australia have been saved from that because they made up their minds as to what they thought of the coalition's defence policies.

The Australian people really made this debate between the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Mayo academic by re-electing the Keating Government on 13 March. The Australian people have made sure that the purchase of those additional F111s will actually go ahead and ensure the future of the Amberley Air Force base.

The scrapping of the purchase of the additional F111s was just part of $200 million in cuts to the defence budget proposed by the Opposition prior to the last election. Other cuts included large cuts to civilian and officer numbers, with approximately 300 officers to go, $150 million in cuts to travel costs, office equipment, stationery, fuel and computer services, around $30 million in cuts to non-combat forces, almost total abolition of the commercial vehicle fleet and substantial cuts to personnel support services.

Cuts of such a magnitude would clearly have had a devastating impact on defence bases such as Amberley and on defence personnel. RAAF base Amberley is a vital part of the economy of the Ipswich region and plays an important part in the life of the general community of that region. The Keating Government, of course, remains committed to consolidating Australia's defence capabilities.

The defence white paper, which will be released during the Government's term in office, will continue the Government's defence priorities and the structure of the Australian Defence Force for the remainder of the 1990s. One of the defence success stories in recent years has been the developments in defence science. About $20 billion will be invested in defence equipment and facilities over this next decade. While this investment in equipment is absolutely necessary, it is essential that the Government does not overlook the needs of defence personnel. Over the next three years, the Government will continue working to improve the living conditions of defence personnel by upgrading facilities at military bases as well as improving defence housing. I am sure that, with this support from the Government, RAAF base Amberley will continue to play an important role in the life of the Ipswich region for many years to come.

In addition to Amberley, the Oxley electorate also includes a significant number of rural producers, particularly in the Lockyer Valley and the rural centre of Laidley. These rural areas were included in the Oxley electorate as a result of the redistribution which occurred prior to the recent federal election. Therefore, the primary industries and energy policy is of considerable interest to many people in my electorate.

During the last Parliament I served as a member of the committee set up by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on value adding in primary production during which time I gained a greater understanding of the potential export income to be gained through the development of processes that add value to our rural primary products. The Ipswich region, which has both a strong primary producing sector and a strong industrial base, is well placed to pick up on the opportunities now opening up in the area of value adding. Over the next term I will be working to encourage governments at all levels to provide greater support for the development of value adding for these primary products.

Value adding provides tremendous opportunities to increase the value of our primary products and to increase employment opportunities, as well as providing opportunities to increase Australia's export income and reduce our current account deficit. If Australia is to seize the opportunities for increased export income now opening up for us in the Asia-Pacific region, reform in our industrial relations system must occur. The only way such reform can take place is by the Government, business, workers and the unions working together constructively.

The attitude of the Government and the Opposition towards industrial relations was a clear dividing line between the major parties during the recent federal election campaign and I do not think much has changed. The Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) declared war on Australian workers and, as it turns out, they lost—which is a good thing for Australian workers. They sought to blame the trade union movement for all of Australia's economic ills. The Government, on the other hand, realises that if Australia is to become more competitive the old policies of confrontation must be replaced by a spirit of cooperation. We are committed to cultivating the partnership between business and trade unions which is essential if we are to achieve lasting reform of the labour market.

We are committed to increasing the flexibility of our industrial relations system by expanding the system of enterprise agreements. However, we will ensure that greater flexibility does not come at the expense of workers' basic rights and conditions of employment, which are essential parts of the system. This will be achieved by maintaining the safety net provided by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the award system which was referred to today by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) in Question Time.

The Keating Labor Government is committed to the policies of inclusion to ensure that all Australians are able to participate fully at all levels of society. We as a government recognise that we have an obligation to make Australia a more just place to live for all its citizens. However, we recognise that we have a unique responsibility to Australia's original inhabitants, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Indeed, in this, the International Year for the World's Indigenous People, we have a special obligation to address the human rights issues raised by the current position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Australian society. Achieving justice for Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders remains high on this Government's agenda, as honourable members would have noticed in the Governor-General's speech. I might add that it is an issue high on my own personal agenda, after having served as chair of the Government's committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs in the last parliament.

If Australia is to be able to hold its head high during international discussions on human rights, reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians must be achieved, and as soon as possible. The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation which was established by the Government in 1991 will continue to be a key participant in the process of reconciliation.

Last year's decision by the High Court on native title—more commonly known as the Mabo case—was a major landmark in Australian legal history. It overturned the racist concept of terra nullius which previously existed in the common law and recognised a form of native title for the first time. Mabo, which essentially recognises the dispossession of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, provides the foundation for reconciliation. I am pleased that the Government has begun discussion on this decision as part of the process of preparing a national response to the Mabo decision.

Mr Deputy Speaker, one of the hallmarks of the Keating Government has been its efforts to establish a more distinctive Australian national identity. In December the Prime Minister announced changes to the oath of allegiance for people taking out Australian citizenship. Under the new oath people who take out citizenship will swear allegiance to Australia and its people. That is an important change.

Honourable members have attended citizenship ceremonies from time to time and seen the people who have come here from many different countries. It is often quite confusing to those people when they have to swear allegiance to the Queen rather than actually to their new homeland. This is an important change that must be proceeded with as soon as possible. The revision of the oath of allegiance is just part of the commitment to a broader debate about Australia's national identity.

The Government—and the labour movement generally—remains committed to continuing to promote the idea of having an Australian head of state chosen by Australians. Recently the Prime Minister announced the establishment of a committee of eminent Australians to formulate a range of options for constitutional reforms. This is a committee that I fully support and an initiative by the Prime Minister which I wholeheartedly support. It is a pity that the Leader of the Opposition has chosen not to nominate a representative to serve on this committee, because if we are to advance this debate a bipartisan approach is essential. Changing our constitutional arrangements to reflect Australia's changing national identity should be an issue which unites us all as Australians. I would hope that we can maintain a mature and balanced debate as we decide this important question in the years ahead.

Australia is a great country, as we in this place all understand. But through all sections of society working together it can be an even greater country. It is essential that we all work together to make Australia the great country that it could be. We are now situated in the fastest growing economic region in the world and if we can tap into that growth we will have a prosperous future. But we can only do this by all working together.
I look forward to working with colleagues in this place over the term of this Government to ensure that a lot of the proposals contained in the Governor-General's speech are actually implemented.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Order! Before I call the honourable member for Indi, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure for me to finally be here, because it was as a schoolboy attending Albury High school with the Hon. Don Grimes and playing football against the honourable member for Holt (Mr Duffy)—who was a worse footballer than I was—that we all planned that we would come to this place and try to make a contribution to Australia. It was not an express agreement that Don Grimes and the honourable member for Holt would be in the ALP and I would be in the Liberal Party, but it was sensible for the area of Albury to at least have a representative from both sides of politics in the Parliament of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your reappointment as a Deputy Speaker. I would like formally to put on record my congratulations to the Speaker for his election and appointment to the high office of Speaker and, of course, to the Deputy Speaker.

In my time in the Victorian Parliament I took a great interest in the Parliament. I was very concerned, as I hope all honourable members are, about the way in which parliaments in Australia have become a place where the law has not been upheld as it should be, in the sense that there has been denigration of the institution, for many reasons. The community has lost respect in many ways for the institution of parliament and for the law-makers, and I think it really is incumbent on all of us to do a lot better. One of the contributions I would like to make as the honourable member for Indi is to help all of us improve this Parliament. I will refer in a little while to some of the areas where I think there are some vivid examples of what we need to do.

It is not the first time that I have spoken in the chamber that is the House of Representatives. Ironically, as many honourable members would know, when Federation was agreed upon the Victorian Parliament was agreed to be the Commonwealth Parliament by arrangement. So Victoria lent the building—that beautiful building at the top end of Spring Street—to the Commonwealth and the Legislative Assembly chamber became the House of Representatives. I have just come from the Legislative Assembly wishing you all well and saying that the rent still has not been paid.

I would particularly like to express my sincere appreciation to my predecessor, good friend and mentor, Ewen Cameron. Ewen Cameron was the 13th Cameron in this place, and I am very glad that the honourable member for Stirling, Mr Eoin Cameron, who made a marvellous first speech today, is the 14th Cameron. I can report back to my good friend Ewen that the place must be in good hands if there is another Cameron here.

Ewen was a man whom I admired very much. I know that he was respected on both sides of the House, which is something that we should all aspire to achieve but which, regretfully, many of us will not. I wish Ewen and Alison a happy retirement. He assures me that the rabbits have already been depleted on his property at Killeen, Euroa, and they are certainly under greater threat now.

I would also like to note that I am the second member for Indi who was also the State member for Benambra. The first member was, of course, Sir Isaac Isaacs. He grew up in a little town called Yackandandah. His father was a tailor; he became a lawyer. He was elected to the State Parliament. He was one of the fathers of Federation. He came here as the first member for Indi. He left a very daunting task for all of us who succeeded him. As a student of the Constitution and one who worries very much about the future of the federal system, I think that we should read again some of the words of Isaac Isaacs, Alfred Deakin and people such as that, because I think they were pretty wise. The safeguards they put in the Constitution remarkably have protected this nation very well, although they have caused some frustration.

It is a great pleasure for me to rejoin a colleague from the State Parliament who was elected into the State Parliament when I was first elected, and that is the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). The honourable member for Bendigo is an accomplished parliamentarian who has managed to convince the electors of Bendigo that their judgment is indeed correct. However, he does specialise in narrow escapes. I think that the honourable member's skill as a local member of parliament should be the subject of a treatise for all aspiring members of parliament.

I am also glad to say that the 10th member for Indi—I am the 14th member—was Sir John McEwen. Even though he did not belong to my party, I think, given time, I could have persuaded him to join. Nevertheless, I am very happy that Sir John McEwen's footsteps are very clearly imprinted in the history of Indi, and I hope that I can also make a contribution to the wellbeing and future of the people of Indi and help them achieve their aspirations.

I want to settle everybody down by bragging about my electorate and showing honourable members some of the things that we do in my electorate. In Indi we are in the process of helping Australia recover from the recession. We are producing marvellous value added food, which is one of the things that we have to do better than anyone else. I have some empty samples here of Uncle Toby's muesli bars, which are now being sold in Asia. I will give honourable members some figures in a minute, which will make them feel very proud. Not so much attractive to honourable members but to their pets, I have labels for Pal dog food and Whiskas cat food. Uncle Ben's in Wodonga is one of Australia's great companies; it is one of Australia's great employers of country people. It is selling successfully into Asia and can really teach Australians what best practice is. I wish I could bring people from Uncle Ben's as well as from other companies in my electorate here to tell the Government what it is doing wrong. But that is another story.

It is always best to leave the best until last. I have some Brown Brothers labels here. The first thing I did was to check that the wines from north-east Victoria and Indi are on the menu of the Parliament. It would be dreadful if I brought my constituents here and they could not enjoy the wines from north-east Victoria. Brown Brothers is a family business, now employing 200 and exporting into Asia, America and Britain. It is showing Australians what we can do. It is still owned by the family. I commend all those companies to you, Mr Deputy Speaker.

I have some other things from a small family company called Haberfields in Albury-Wodonga. It is exporting $6 million worth of cheese now and employing about 80 people in Albury-Wodonga. It is a family company.Haberfields could also tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, if it were given the opportunity, what it needs in Australia. One of the reasons that I stood for the Federal Parliament was that I really believed that Fightback would help us gain export markets—and I still do. I feel so sorry that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been slow in adopting our policies. I think we ought to send him another copy of Fightback to read. Under our policies we would have reduced the cost of exports by five per cent in the first year. That is a remarkable one-off figure, and it would have meant jobs. The other reason that I am here—and I am sure people on this side of politics feel very strongly about this—is that it is unacceptable that there be a million people unemployed in Australia, that there be 700,000 kids in Australia whose mothers and fathers are both unemployed and who are on some form of government welfare assistance.

If honourable members look at the current account figures this week—they will have a nightmare afterwards, as most of us would have—they will see that it is fundamental to Australia that we introduce reforms. Unfortunately, the Australian electorate did not quite make it this time—about 1,400 votes in the marginal seats. So my friends on the other side should not crow too much about the mandate. As the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said today, the only mandate the Government has is not to increase taxes. We are looking forward to seeing the Prime Minister deliver his mandate. What he really ought to do is adopt most of our policies. If he did that straightaway, we would be well on the way to reform.

If I can briefly mention my background, because it is part of the reason why I am so happy to be here, I started off my involvement with the Liberal Party selling newspapers on the railway station on which Robert Menzies formed the Liberal Party. That is in Albury-Wodonga and, incidentally, it is the longest railway station in the Southern Hemisphere.

I am very glad to say that next year is the 50th anniversary of the Liberal Party, a great political party. We might have lost last time but watch this space in 1996. We are celebrating our 50th anniversary next year and I, for one, hope personally that it will be celebrated in my electorate. I hope the Leader of the Opposition has heard that. It is a pretty good suggestion; it started on the railway station down there and it is a good place to be.

I was involved in small business. I helped my family run a small business. I studied law part-time, managed to qualify, became a senior partner in a provincial law firm and enjoyed the law very much. I have been involved in community matters that have to do with the very fabric of society, particularly in foster care and looking after children who have been the subject of abuse.

I was greatly influenced by many people in my career and I would like to mention briefly some of them: my parents, of course, for their input; my father who came from England and told me about poverty; what it was like to fight street gangs at the age of 11 so that he could go to school in London. His examples and hard work as a small businessman in Australia have always been an inspiration to me.

There are other people: my master when I was articled, Stan Jackling, who wrote the constitution for the Australian Association of Apex and was a great influence on me; Harry Flood, one of the partners who recently passed away and who was one of the commandos on Timor who used to observe the Japanese naval ships and report back. He was pursued across all those islands by the Japs but they never caught him. He was a great lawyer and an influence on me.

Also, I would like to mention Mr Justice Nagle of the Supreme Court of New South Wales and Mr Justice Crockett of the Supreme Court of Victoria who also, as barristers, were very interested in my career and helped me along. Obviously, I would not be here today if it were not for my family—my wife, Marj, and my three children. As someone said the other day, `Lou, why are you doing this? Wouldn't you have had enough, having been in the State Parliament?', but above all they said to my wife, `Why are you letting him do it after all of the years in State Parliament?'. The fact is, we are a team. We believe in Australia very much and we also take the view that everyone has a responsibility to serve his nation. We enjoy doing that so that is part of the reason I am here.

Honourable members would be interested to know that everyone says to me, and some of the journalists who have interviewed me from back home say, `What is it like, Lou? Is it different being up here in the Federal Parliament rather than in the State Parliament?'. They are really interested in honourable members and they think we are all different. That is what is coming through to me. I know honourable members are all human beings. I know we are all subject to the frailties of man. But I must say that there is a great interest in the Parliament, and I think that if we could do more to promote that interest and, above all, improve the standards of Parliament it would be not only a good thing for us in our career, but also a great thing for the community.

I was in this House last year in the gallery watching Question Time. The gallery was full of school kids. During Question Time, the Prime Minister, unfortunately, challenged Opposition members to poke their tongues out at him and things like that. I do not want to get personal because I should not be provocative in a maiden speech but to me, looking at those kids faces, they were absolutely dismayed. Hansard is replete with words like `scumbag' and all those sorts of utterances, and they do nothing at all for the Parliament. If there is any doubt about it, honourable members should look at the kids faces when they are visiting us in the gallery. I hope that the Prime Minister will not mind me reminding him that that is what the kids think of his behaviour.

There are many other areas that I would like to speak on but obviously time is not available to me. But I would like to mention briefly that I do not think Australians have put enough effort into the regional development of Australia. It is the most unrecognised issue, and it is one that I know a lot of governments talk about, but unfortunately there has not been a national policy on it. I would like to help this Parliament and I hope people from all sides will support me in the quest to have a better Australia, one in which all the population does not concentrate on the coastal regions and the major capital cities.

I have shown honourable members some of the things which we are doing in regional Australia, in Indi. Our potential has not been reached. Given the right regional policies, there are many parts of Australia like Indi that could do an enormous thing for Australia and create jobs. I would like to say particularly that the electors of Indi—most of them, about 50 per cent I would say, were formerly electors of mine in the State seat of Benambra—have been absolutely supportive of me. They gave me a very good mandate in the State Parliament. I had the second highest vote, I think, in the State Parliament and this time round I got 63 per cent of the two-party preferred vote.

I just mention that, not to blow my own trumpet, but to say that country people are interested in people who get out and do things, who try to unite city and country people and who bring this country into a strong position so that it can work cohesively as a nation. Regional Australian policies, in my view, should be absolute priority for all governments. I am also very interested, particularly as a former assistant Minister of health responsible for children's services, in the state of the health system.

It has been reported to me that if you are 60 and you are in Melbourne, if you have not got private health insurance and you need dialysis you do not get it and you die. That has to be verified. It is a strong statement to make but it is a fairly reliable report. When I was visiting the Royal Women's Hospital as Minister I remember being shown the neo-natal wards where the miracles of technology and medicine have saved so many lives, unfortunately at a great cost. I am told that the neo-natal programs are at risk because of the crisis in the health system. Surely to God, sir, the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) and the Keating Government should move urgently to address these issues because we have a crisis in health. I notice that Senator Richardson is looking at the possibility of providing incentives for people to take out private health insurance. Only 40 per cent of Australians have insurance, with more dropping out every day. We had 70 per cent about eight years ago. It is our policy that that should happen. Prime Minister, please do it. If he does not do it, he is going to have on his conscience the death of many people who will not have access to health care simply because the funds are not there.

Finally, in the last minute, I would like to say that Indi is in an area that is part of the Murray-Darling Basin. The Murray-Darling Basin represents about one-seventh of Australia's continent and produces 40 per cent of Australia's total food, some of it by Uncle Tobys and others. It is value added, getting jobs, earning export dollars. To me the policies of the national Government on Murray-Darling have been neglected. There is not enough support from the Commonwealth to look after that great resource of Australia. I would like, while I am in this place, to see that the Parliament focuses more attention on supporting the Murray-Darling Commission, which is a partnership between the State governments of South Australia, Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria and the Commonwealth Government, so that that valuable resource is looked after.

I would like briefly, as a former shadow Minister for water, to remind honourable members that we are already using in Victoria 50 per cent of our water for 1993. It is a finite resource. It has to be looked after and it is not in my view, from a national point of view, being looked after well enough.

I was going to make some quotes from Robert Menzies when he made his first speech. I will not have time but I would simply like to paraphrase them and say that the Constitution is indeed very hard to understand. Perhaps it is meant to be but it certainly, in my view, needs review. I am going to look forward to participating in the review of the federal system to avoid the creation of a single central government in Australia.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Before I call the honourable member for Macarthur, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech. I ask the House to extend to him the usual courtesies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is with great pride and pleasure that I rise for the first time to speak in this House as the sixth elected representative of the electorate of Macarthur. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, Macarthur has always been represented, since its creation in 1949, by a member of the Government party. Of the five previous members for Macarthur, four are still members of this Parliament. They are John Kerin; Stephen Martin; you, Mr Deputy Speaker; and Senator Michael Baume. The other previous member for Macarthur was the late Mr Jeff Bate.

PARA.TAB: Let me take this opportunity to congratulate the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) on his election to the high office of Speaker of the House of Representatives, and the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) on his election as the Deputy Speaker. In addition, let me convey to the honourable member for Cunningham the appreciation and best wishes of his former constituents of Macarthur for his outstanding service as their representative in this House for the past eight years. Let me also convey similar appreciation from former constituents to the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace), and the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), part of whose former electorates now fall within the electorate of Macarthur. Each of these members has provided outstanding service to their electorates.

I would also like to pay tribute to the Hon. Stewart West, the former member for Cunningham in this House. Stewart West entered parliament in 1977. He became a Minister in the Hawke Government and served as Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs from 1983 to 1984, Minister for Housing and Construction from 1984 to 1987, and Minister for Administrative Services from 1987 to 1990. Mr West's services to his electorate over 16 years exemplified what it means to be a Labor member of parliament.

It is a particular honour and privilege for me to represent Macarthur as a member of the great Australian Labor Party and as a member of the Keating Labor Government. I congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on his magnificent victory and look forward eagerly to the implementation of the comprehensive program outlined in the Governor-General's opening speech.

I joined the ALP in 1979, and I did so because it was the party—the only party—which had a fundamental commitment to equity, fairness and social justice, and the achievement of progressive, social democratic reform. The efforts of the Whitlam Government in this regard were rudely interrupted by the unforgettable events of November 1975—events which, hopefully, will never be repeated but which themselves helped motivate me to become politically active; indeed, it could be said that I have maintained the rage. However, much has been done to bring about greater equity and social justice since the election of the Hawke Labor Government in 1983.

I have been fortunate in my working life, and through my involvement in the trade union movement, local government and community organisations, to have had direct involvement with issues and policies which are great examples of the achievements of a Labor government. These include Medicare, our great universal health insurance system. I was employed in a team monitoring abuses of Medicare benefits by medical practitioners. However, our efforts were undermined by the medical establishment within the bureaucracy and were attacked by the more extreme elements of the AMA, forcing the Government to abolish our program during the doctors dispute in 1985. I might say that some of my colleagues at the time were less fortunate than I was in finding a new career. Indeed, at least two of them were so badly persecuted within the bureaucracy because of their vigilance and effectiveness in pursuing cases of medical fraud and overservicing that they were eventually forced into premature retirement due to stress related illness. However, the Medicare scheme itself, despite continuing opposition from elements of the medical profession, has survived and stands as a truly great Labor reform which will continue to improve even further.

The massive increase in Federal funding for child care is another example of Labor's commitment to social justice. Much credit for this is due to my colleague the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples) in his role as the Minister responsible. My local government experience with Campbelltown City Council has given me a valuable insight into the importance of child care as a priority for the community. As most of my electorate has a high proportion of young families, I look forward to the implementation of the new child-care initiatives announced by the Prime Minister before the election, and to the continuing expansion of the children's services program. However, as with so many other Commonwealth-State programs, the Government must overcome the difficulties of dealing with uncooperative State governments, such as the current one in New South Wales.

There are probably few better examples of a typical Labor achievement than the progress made in the past 10 years toward equal employment opportunity in Australia. This is an area in which I have worked for some years in the public sector. It is significant that every piece of legislation relating to equal employment opportunity in this country, both at Commonwealth and State level, has been passed by a Labor government. This has resulted in a much higher participation rate of women in the work force, as well as significant progress in breaking down gender stereotypes and eliminating discrimination against women in the workplace. However, there is still much more to be done in relation to EEO for migrants, Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders and people with disabilities.

During my six years in local government I have also been encouraged by the Federal Government's efforts in promoting better cooperation with local councils and providing increased direct funding. I note that it was Labor which attempted to provide constitutional recognition for local government by holding a referendum in September 1988. Unfortunately, however, the referendum was unsuccessful due to the negative campaign of the Opposition parties. Perhaps this matter could be once again dealt with as part of the review of Australia's system and structure of government, which will undoubtedly be completed well before the year 2001.

I would also commend the Government for the introduction in the 1992 Budget of the local government capital works program. Despite the gratuitous criticism of the Opposition and the attempted obstruction by conservative State governments, this program provided a much needed boost to many local councils. Not only is the program creating jobs and stimulating local economies, but also it has made possible the provision of desperately needed capital works and community facilities which councils have not been able to afford due to the recession and to continuing funding cuts by State governments. This is particularly important in newer areas with rapid growth, where councils have struggled to provide the infrastructure and facilities to keep pace with the community's needs.

I have mentioned just a few of the reasons why I am proud to be a member of the Australian Labor Party and to represent the party in this House. Certainly, the people of Macarthur will benefit greatly from the Government's re-election. As an electorate with many young families and first home buyers, issues such as child care, education and housing are of high priority, along with employment. In these areas Labor's policies were clearly superior to those of our opponents. Macarthur also has a predominance of small business people who would have been severely disadvantaged by the Opposition's proposed goods and services tax—a point which became clear to many of them during the election campaign.

Job creation is clearly a high priority for this Government, and in this respect I am encouraged by the emphasis on regional development foreshadowed by the Prime Minister.
