I will be paying particular attention to seeking early progress on the construction of the Badgerys Creek airport, and also to the issue of transport infrastructure within Macarthur, particularly in relation to the problems associated with the transportation of coal to Port Kembla. Coal mining is one of the largest industries in the Macarthur region and is also an important export industry. It is vital that the most efficient and cost-effective coal transport arrangements are put in place, with due regard for employment, environmental issues and the needs of local residents.

I would like to pay tribute to those who supported and assisted me in my election campaign. I thank my wife, Kerry, and my three children for the support they have given me and the sacrifices they have made as an inevitable part of my holding public office, both at the local government level and now as a Federal member. I thank my local party branch members, my federal electorate council, Young Labor members and my campaign committee, many of whom are well aware of the particular difficulties we experienced during the campaign. I thank the national and State offices of the Labor Party and all those who assisted during the campaign and on polling day; indeed, I thank all of the people in Macarthur who voted for me and the Labor Party. They have bestowed a great honour and a great responsibility upon me, and I will not let them down.

I must pay a special tribute to the role played by the trade union movement in the re-election of the Labor Government. No doubt motivated by the threat of the draconian industrial relations climate foreshadowed by the Opposition, the trade union movement mobilised as never before to support the Labor campaign. I am pleased to say that Macarthur was no exception. I received significant support for my campaign from officials and from rank and file members of a number of unions.

I express particular gratitude to the New South Wales branch of the miscellaneous workers division of the LHMU, and the New South Wales branch of the building workers division of the CFMEU. I am proud to have been associated with both of these organisations, as well as the other unions which contributed. The support I received from unions was all the more gratifying in view of my own background as an active trade unionist for many years in the public sector. It was my involvement in the union movement that originally gave expression and focus to my commitment to social justice, and led to my joining the ALP. It has also provided me with the background of experience which has played a large part in enabling me to achieve the honour of being elected to this House.

As a public sector worker, my union activities also taught me a lot about public administration and the workings of government at the federal level. However, my early years as a delegate in the former ACOA—now the Public Sector Union—coincided with an era of confrontation and Public Service bashing under the Fraser Government. Since 1983 the close, cooperative relationship between the Labor Government and the ACTU, together with the promotion of industrial democracy principles as government policy, has resulted in major changes in the industrial relations culture, both in the public and private sectors.

However, the 1980s brought with them other problems for Australian workers and unions, particularly in the public sector. The predominance of economic rationalists amongst the senior levels of the bureaucracy has been a source of continuing concern and frustration for many of us. Much has been said in recent times about the failure of these doctrinaire, market driven economic models, particularly with the spectacular failure of the Opposition's Fightback package to win electoral support. However, the economic rationalist bean counting mentality has dominated the bureaucracy for several years.

This has been true in most government agencies—even, I am sorry to say, in the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services, where I represented the Public Sector Union. I will not soon forget the despair and anger of many of my colleagues and myself during 1988 when more than 500 jobs were abolished, resulting in a bitter industrial dispute. It is a great tribute to the dedication, commitment and professionalism of program staff in that department that the Government's important social justice programs are still being delivered, despite the ongoing difficulties created by such restrictions as the efficiency dividend, endless rationalisation and restructuring and the obsession with the false premise that adopting private sector models automatically means greater efficiency.

However, I believe that this Government has learnt from the mistakes of the 1980s, both in Australia and overseas. Thankfully, economic rationalism is no longer the flavour of the month. As one who has always believed that governments should play a significant role in social and economic planning so that the economy is tailored to meet our social needs and objectives, rather than the reverse, I look forward to an even greater emphasis on the achievement of real equity and social justice, building on the many great reforms already achieved by Labor governments.

Over the past five years the Federal Labor Government has been working together with unions, employers and employer associations in the building industry to achieve improvements in productivity and efficiency, as well as to ensure opportunities for workers in terms of access to training, career paths and job satisfaction. Already this process is bearing fruit, with many key projects being completed well within budget and ahead of time. This approach will undoubtedly attract further investment, both Australian and international, and will ensure increased development and job creation.

The building unions have been, and continue to be, key participants and initiators in this reform process. Union amalgamations have proceeded rapidly, particularly over the past two years. The amalgamations, together with the unions' approach to cross skilling and career paths will, amongst other things, ensure a reduction in demarcation disputes.

As I have indicated previously, I have had many recent dealings with the officials of the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union, the CFMEU, in New South Wales. The responsible and far-sighted leadership of the CFMEU has ensured that it is playing a key role in the reform process so that maximum benefits will flow to its members.

The coalition policies on unions and micro-economic reform are diametrically opposed to this. It was the anti-union, anti-worker aspects of so many elements of Fightback which motivated many trade unionists, Labor Party members and supporters to put in extra effort to ensure a Labor victory in the election. This certainly happened in Macarthur.

One organisation which is out of step with current progressive reforms, and which seeks a confrontationalist and negative approach to the union movement is the Housing Industry Association. During the recent election campaign the HIA, under the stewardship of one Ron Silberberg, embarked on a campaign which would rival the captain of the Titanic, or perhaps the formulator of Fightback, in terms of judgment and skill. The HIA spent millions of dollars of its members' subscriptions on the most disgraceful misinformation campaign seen in this country for many years. The extent of this campaign seriously calls into question the credibility of the HIA and its future role in matters pertaining to the building industry.

The HIA's campaign followed this Government's amendments to the Industrial Relations Act concerning protection for subcontractor workers. After consultation with unions, employer associations, the Australian Democrats and other interested parties, modified proposals were legislated and came into effect in July 1992. All those who opposed the initial proposals were satisfied with the final amendments—that is, all except the HIA.

The final legislation simply gives the Industrial Relations Commission the power, upon application on behalf of the contract worker, to set aside and vary a contract if it is found to be harsh, unfair or unconscionable. This was simply designed to prevent exploitation of workers not protected by award prescription. It applies whether they are contractors, subcontractors or employees and whether or not they are members of a union. The provisions are, in many respects, much more conservative than provisions which have existed in New South Wales for decades and which were retained in the Greiner Government's harsh new industrial legislation.

Despite this, the HIA embarked on its massive scare campaign. It carried out an expensive radio, television and press campaign which blatantly misrepresented the content and effects of the new provisions of the Act. It then spent a reported $2 million on direct mail alone, targeting 13 marginal seats, including Macarthur which includes many new housing estates. The material presented in this vicious campaign contained many blatant untruths. In particular, the HIA falsely asserted that the new legislation would result in compulsory unionism and a blow-out in housing costs. By contrast, it was absolutely silent on the likely effects of the Opposition's GST on housing costs.

The campaign by the HIA was political and ideologically based. It was seeking a coalition victory and the imposition of New Right industrial relations policies. All it succeeded in doing was wasting millions of dollars of its members' money. Even since the election the HIA has persisted with its false and outrageous claims about the contractors legislation.

The Australian people have now clearly rejected the new right approach to industrial relations. It is now time for the Hewsons, Kennetts, Faheys and Silberbergs of this country to acknowledge this fact and adopt an approach of cooperation and reform, not confrontation and destruction. As long as I am a member of this House I will be a strong voice in support of the trade union movement, and a strong critic of those who seek to unfairly attack unions and their members.

One of the most laughable aspects of the HIA's propaganda was its claims in relation to compulsory unionism. Not only are the claims clearly untrue in relation to the contractor legislation, but it is a fact that I have never met anyone who has been unable to gain employment because they were not a member of a union. By contrast, I know dozens of people who have experienced victimisation, discrimination and harassment in the workplace because of their trade union activity. I know from my own experience in the public sector that active trade union delegates and members are often singled out for special attention by employers. This sometimes goes well beyond the normal robust political relationship one expects between unions and managements and can seriously disadvantage a worker's career. I have represented dozens of people who have suffered unfair discrimination of this nature.

I will continue to fight against victimisation, discrimination or harassment of unions or unionists by employers or managers, both in the public and private sectors. If necessary, I will expose in this House any instances that come to my attention.

Under Labor, Australia has had a fair and equitable industrial relations system. In the interests of continued fairness and equity, as well as greater efficiency, we can well do without the persecution of Australian workers who simply assert the right to organise and represent their colleagues in order to seek their legitimate industrial goals.

I conclude by offering my congratulations to the city of Campbelltown on the 25th anniversary this month of its proclamation as a city. In the past 25 years Campbelltown has grown from a country town into a bustling multicultural city of 150,000 people, half of whom are under the age of 20. I have been proud to live in Campbelltown for nearly 12 years, and to have served as an alderman of the city of Campbelltown for six years. I convey my best wishes to the people of Campbelltown and to their council, one of the most efficient and well managed councils in New South Wales.

I look forward to working together with Campbelltown Council, and indeed with all of the councils within my electorate, to advance the economic and social wellbeing of the people of Macarthur, to ensure that they reap the full benefits of their decision to elect me as a member of the Labor Government.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Before I call the honourable member for Pearce, I remind the House that this is the honourable member's first speech and I ask the House to extend to her the usual courtesies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Ms J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as this is the first opportunity I have had to address the House, I would like to congratulate you and the Speaker on your elevation to high honours of this House.

PARA.TAB: I stand here today as the member for Pearce, conscious of the honour conferred upon me by the electors of the division and by the Liberal Party of Australia. Ninety-two years ago, Senator Sir George Pearce made his maiden speech in the first Commonwealth Parliament. His words ring true today when he said:

I trust that we who represent this State will be able to convince the representatives of other States of the importance of this Parliament devoting some attention to that great tract of territory we are sent here to represent, because I believe that the future of Australia, to a large extent, will depend on the use we make of that portion of our continent.

SPEECH.PARA: Ninety-two years later, George Pearce's predictions as to the economic importance of Western Australia to the Commonwealth has been more than fulfilled. It remains the task of a new West Australian member to fight for my State, as George Pearce did in his long career, when in his maiden speech he demanded that this State was as much entitled to be defended as any other, and needed a rail link to the east.

PARA.TAB: George Pearce represented Western Australia in the Senate for 37 years and served in the Labor and Conservative cabinets for a total of 25 years, a record equalled only by Sir John McEwen. For much of his ministerial career he held the defence portfolio and his name is fittingly commemorated in the Pearce RAAF base as well as the electorate created in 1989.

A pioneer representative of the Labor movement, he followed his conscience across the floor in 1916 and became a popular and respected figure in the Nationalist Party. I am proud to be the second representative of the seat that bears his name.

I acknowledge also the contribution made to this Parliament by my predecessor, the first honourable member for Pearce, Fred Chaney. He has a distinguished record as a former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Minister for Social Security, Opposition leader in the Senate, and a frontbencher. Equally notable, is the respect that he rapidly earned as the honourable member for Pearce over the last three years. He was an exceptional representative. While acknowledging that Fred is a hard act to follow, his record I intend to maintain. I am sure that other honourable members will join me in wishing Fred Chaney all the best in his future endeavours.

This is also a time for me to reflect on the immense gift of a happy and stable family life and to thank my mother, who is now deceased, and my father for the nurturing environment they provided for me. To my children, Peter, who has been with me these past days, Jenny and Michael, go my love, my thanks and my commitment to passing the baton to them in as good or better shape than I received it.

The electorate of Pearce is in so many respects a microcosm of Western Australia. Its residential component includes such hills suburbs as Darlington, Kalamunda and Lesmurdie, together with the outer suburban housing in the foothills at Swan View, High Wycombe and Forrestfield. It borders the major industrial and service centre of Midland. Much of this suburban component proceeding along Great Eastern Highway blends into a rural lifestyle that the electors of Pearce are properly determined to preserve. The ambience of a country town combines with a sophistication of a metropolis.

The John Forrest National Park, the first in the State, preserves the heart of the escarpment with the Walyunga National Park in the north. Pearce contains the State's oldest wine growing area in the Swan Valley, where indeed my great-great-grandfather settled in 1835 as the colony's first engineer.

There are the long established family orchards in Pickering Brook and Karragullen. The rural component includes Gidgegannup, with its small farms, extending to the broadacre farms of the Northam Shire. Within the electorate is the major provincial town of Northam and the smaller rural towns of Toodyay and Bindoon. As I mentioned earlier, there is the significant defence establishment in the Pearce RAAF base together with a military training area near Bindoon.

People in Pearce and across Western Australia have voted for change. A change in direction. I have been given a strong mandate by the electors of Pearce and must act as part of a forceful Opposition. The people of Pearce demand that answers be provided to such continuing national problems as unemployment, health care, and the strengthening of rural and resource industries.

Drawing on my community involvement in the Pearce electorate, I firmly believe that those of us elected to parliament must work effectively for the deeper involvement and understanding of our fellow Australians in the political process. If we are honest, we cannot deny that there is a growing cynicism in the electorate. The healthy scepticism of our anarcho-conservative cultural tradition has been overtaken by a sullen alienation, a continued feeling of `us' against `them'.

Too many Australians consider that they are completely dissociated from government, that they have no means of influencing public policy, and that any major policy initiative is certain to contain a malign hidden agenda. Much of the responsibility must be borne, by not only publicly disgraced political leaders, but also all those in leadership roles who have sought to exploit and deepen this feeling for partisan gain. It is a fact that the cynicism that has been successfully mobilised to win an election may boomerang. When a re-elected government wishes to promote new solutions to deep-seated problems, it will find that it has created a monster.

I intend to do my utmost to assure the electors of Pearce that they matter, to give them a chance to have effective input into the political process and to take charge of their own destiny. Beyond representing my own views, it is therefore my role and my privilege to consider and represent those wishes of electors that are in the common interests of the people. Part of the process is to inform the public of the amount of constructive and bipartisan work achieved in this Parliament and its committees, an aspect of politics too little understood.

Equally, we need to strive toward consistent bipartisan solutions. The reduction of tariffs over the last two decades has been achieved in such a climate, and the temptation to arouse protectionist emotions for cheap political gain has to be resisted. Nor can a Government that may not rely electorally on the vote of wealth producers afford to delay and compromise on the need for tax reform that will cut the cost of transport and other burdens on the export industries and business and farming sectors, on which all of us ultimately depend.

While we have a duty to break down the barriers of cynicism and despair which cloud the political process and to act as popularisers rather than populists, I am always conscious of the fact that our national problems cannot be solved by political action alone. It is the great fallacy of the 20th century that mankind is somehow perfectible through politics. In furtherance of this Rousseauist lie, Lenin, Stalin, Hitler, and Mao Tse-tung, those apostles of social engineering, have slaughtered millions.

One common feature of those who believe that men and women exist to witness the validity of political theory rather than the liberal-democratic axiom that politics must serve people is their ultimate scorn of the individual. Hence the pre-war Japanese Ministry of Justice stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Individuals can only exist as links in an infinite and vast chain of life called the state; . . . Individuals participate in the highest and greatest value when they serve the state as part of it.

This blend of Western Hegelianism and bushido is the hallmark of any society where oligarchies take collective decisions in secret and thus avoid moral responsibility. Unfortunately, this exaltation of the state can also corrupt a democratic polity. It is to be found whenever some eager social engineer in our own society subscribes to the attitude, expressed by Labour intellectual Douglas Jay in 1937, that housewives could not be trusted to buy the right food for their families as:
. . . the gentleman in Whitehall really does know better what is good for people than the people know themselves.

This dangerous arrogance is at total variance with the philosophy of the Liberal Party that I am proud to represent. It is a core belief of liberalism that markets will better serve the needs of individuals than government controls, simply because they are less easily manipulated. The collectivist assumption that each additional state power will be used for the common good is a proven lie. However, it is equally our belief that markets depend on morals, on the property rights that are the only firm guarantee of personal freedom, on governments upholding firm laws expressing conventions of decent behaviour. Disregard of this truth has cost us dearly over the past decade.

PARA.TAB: Respect for individual worth and individual choice is essential as Australia goes forward into the next century, particularly given the current debate as to the continued validity of constitutional structures. Whether Australia continues as a monarchy or opts for a republican head of state, we need to discuss these alternatives without rancour. We must recognise that the role of head of state in a parliamentary liberal democracy must serve as a focus for national unity, and look to best achieving this purpose. Fidelity to national institutions should generally be regarded as a sign of a nation's maturity, but neither should all change be rejected. I respect the viewpoint of those for whom a Queen of Australia is not the same as an Australian Queen.

Those of us who, like the great majority of Australians, wish to preserve the basic form of government that we have today might consider the other possibilities. A head of state, elected perhaps by popular vote, by a two-thirds majority of the members of this Parliament, or an electoral college that also included State parliaments, may provide a stronger check on a malign and reckless executive than would a governor-general appointed by the Prime Minister. It is a time for members of parliament to be asking questions rather than decreeing solutions. We must avoid the shallow, closed progressivism that is based on vision rather than argument, and that instead attacks the bona fides of questioners. What is essential is an honest debate on the matter of an appropriate head of state for Australia.

Even at this early stage, however, it is becoming apparent that Australians may not be given this opportunity and choice. Rather, the debate will be hijacked by those eager to vandalise our Federal Constitution, proceeding on the totally unproven hypothesis that the Constitution is out of date. We will not build anything of value in Australia if it involves rejecting the past. That soon degenerates into the gravest form of dishonesty, the falsification of history. Whenever Sir Robert Menzies is mocked for the royalism he expressed in the 1950s and 1960s, the values of a whole generation, coalition and Labor voters alike, are taken out of context, trivialised and insulted. It is incumbent on the proponents of an Australian republic to ensure that, in the event of a successful referendum being carried, continued reverence for a monarch who has served us with dignity is not stigmatised as unpatriotic or subjected to any governmental pressure.

We can take the positive benefits of the past with us into our chosen future directions without rejecting and denying our heritage and the very foundation stones of this great nation. In fact, it is essential that more Australians are informed about the truth of our history, which is that of an essentially tolerant society shaped by the rule of law. The most salient feature of the history of convict settlement was the fact that assigned convicts enjoyed the protection of the law and were able to attain freedom. It is a fact that the Irish component of our nation in the previous century was blended successfully with its Anglo-Scottish strains. In 1836 Governor Bourke ensured equal treatment of Christian denominations, avoiding the divisiveness of an established church. In 1846 in Victoria the public commemoration of the Protestant triumphalism of the Battle of the Boyne was prohibited, preserving an emerging nation from displays of sectarian hatred.

In the last half century, Australia has successfully absorbed tens of thousands of immigrants who have learned to live together because they were joining a tolerant society and a culture that may not have encouraged public displays of difference but that set an immense value on civility in personal relations. The assimilation policy of the day was not perfect, but neither was it repressive. It is one of the great fallacies of the present time that the due recognition of non-Anglo-Celtic cultures should involve denial of the legitimacy and achievements of the host culture.

Certainly, rational debate on an Australian republic will be rapidly derailed once it becomes confused with a predictable and squalid assault on federalism, advocating the downgrading of the Senate and the removal of powers from the States. We must always recall the truism that republicanism need not equate with democracy, or the sovereignty of the people as opposed to the Executive. On four recent occasions Western Australians have voted consistently against centralising referenda, all of which have deservedly failed on a national basis. Proponents of centralism in Australia have to explain why Australians stubbornly refuse to entrust the Federal Government with greater powers. Centralism should be recognised as a discredited form of government, whose failure is most graphically illustrated in the debacle of the former Soviet Union, where centralised control destroyed initiative and resulted in a corrupt polity and economic ruin. Equally, it is no accident that the rebirth of postwar Germany as a liberal democracy and economic giant occurred in the framework of a federal system.

Australian Federal governments have only two realistic choices in regard to our federal system. They can choose to centralise by stealth, to let the system deteriorate, or they can put aside perceived self-interest, extend the hand of cooperation to elected State governments, and try to make the system work. To me, as a representative of Western Australia, the State which provides 24 per cent of Australian export revenue, it comes down to a fundamental question of equity. Western Australians want real solutions that involve States being sufficiently resourced to fulfil their responsibilities, and less bureaucracy rather than more at all levels of government.

The people of Pearce understand the need for responsible government, but these are people who have that rare capacity to go quietly about solving their own and their community's problems. They understand the dignity of work and appreciate that the privilege of individual rights also brings with it responsibility for others. In Pearce, evidence of this great spirit abounds. Whether it is tackling the problems of land care, attending to the broader issues of environment, or in the areas of social justice and care for the aged, the youth, the unemployed or the family, these people demonstrate what can be achieved when communities are allowed to get on with running their own lives.

These are people who do not deserve to have procrustean policies thrust upon them. Procrustes, as the Greek story goes, stretched the bodies or lopped the limbs off travellers to make them fit his beds. Policies and legislation should be adopted and passed for the people; people should not be shaped to fit policy. We must work assiduously in the interests of all Australians.

There are some others in our community who felt strongly enough about these and other concerns of the role of government that they gave countless hours of time, unselfish sharing of talent and were dedicated in their pursuit of policies to preserve human dignity. These are the men and women of the Liberal Party branches in the Pearce electorate with whom I am privileged to work and whom I now represent.I am now elected to represent all the people of Pearce and, in working with them, I am convinced that together we can contribute to the ultimate objective of building a better nation.
Opposition members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Pearce (Ms Moylan) and welcome her to the Parliament. She spoke the truth when she said that many Australians do not have a lot of faith in the political system; in fact, many Australians do not feel sovereign. This is partly because there is a lack of faith in parliamentarians. I think the honourable member feels it more in Western Australia, as would Queenslanders, because of the record of both of those States over the past 10 years.But there is also a problem with people not feeling sovereign. There is a lot of buck-passing between governments. I firmly believe Australia is over-governed, with too many levels of government.

PARA.TAB: Mr Deputy Speaker, I also welcome you and other honourable members back to the Parliament. I welcome the new Speaker and the Deputy Speaker. I welcome particularly the high calibre of new members on both sides of the House. I believe this will mean that we will have a better Australia.

Important commitments were made in the Governor-General's speech. He talked about some important innovations, such as the proposed seniors card, financial help to partners at home, and assisting older people who may not be eligible for a pension and people who may need medication. We will help those people to cope a little better. We will help those people who are just over the border of pension entitlement. Men who have just reached 60 and who cannot find a job can now join women, who are entitled to a pension at age 60, in receiving a benefit.

We have to tackle some very important issues, many of which were mentioned in the Governor-General's speech. The one I want to pick out concerns a commitment to look at the whole employment situation. I believe honourable members on both sides of the House have neglected to face the real truth about unemployment. They have failed to recognise that we have a different situation in Australia today. In 1961, for instance, the participation rate was much lower. Women, Aborigines and a whole lot of other people did not think they were entitled to register for jobs. It is now entirely different. The participation rate is much higher. This means that the unemployment rate of two or three per cent in 1961 was much tougher than the unemployment rate of about seven per cent we now have throughout much of my electorate. Today the participation rate is much higher and more families have both partners working.

It is true that in many cases both partners work because they need to. But it is also true that we have things today that we did not have before. For instance, in 1961 I did not have a television set, I certainly did not have a video and about five years prior to that I did not even own a car. The situation is very different today. Most families have two cars, a video, a refrigerator or two and sometimes two television sets. We have different requirements today and there is nothing wrong with two partners working to meet those requirements. Anyone who wants to turn back the clock is not facing the facts about participation. I believe that human beings have great flexibility and can adapt to any situation.

In our own region, we have important employment issues to face. The south-east region of New South Wales combines with the ACT to form a vast area of employment and some of the areas close to the ACT depend on jobs which are forthcoming. I remember talking to the Minister for the environment some years ago about how the creation of jobs should proceed in this region. We both felt that we should not rush into a whole lot of heavy construction works all at once and that the work should be spread out. The work which is coming up on the foreign affairs office and the Australian Museum is an important manifestation of our resolve.

We also have to think about other areas not so far away. In Cooma, for instance, the Government has decided to sell the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation. But we need to ensure that the corporation stays in Cooma. The Federal Government has made some important moves in seeking to sell to the staff and I believe that is one way we can guarantee that the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation will stay in Cooma. It is important that we complete the negotiations and come to terms with our responsibilities—both in terms of liabilities and management of the business—as soon as possible so that the people of Cooma and the workers in the corporation will know where they stand.

We also need to make sure that our rural industries are as strong as possible. We have a successful dairy industry in the area and we need to ensure that we do not repeat the mistakes which have been made in the past of allowing a lot of heavy growth with the prospect of people who have just come into the industry being hurt. We do not want to make the mistake of holding prices at an artificially high level, as happened in some instances in the wool industry.

The wool industry is absolutely vital to this region. Unlike many other areas, sheep farmers do not have a lot of alternatives. They can invest in cattle, but cattle are not suited to many areas of the Monaro where sheep are much more viable. We need to keep people on their farms so that they can become viable farmers and provide more wool when it is needed. We also need to ensure that we have wool which will sell: the wool that other countries want. Wool constitutes a pretty low percentage of total fibre sales when one includes man-made fibres and other fibre options, so the marketing of wool will be extremely important.

There are a lot of very good alternatives in this area. I have just been told that a south-eastern food cooperative is talking about the mulching of wool, for which I believe it may be prepared to pay up to 486c. It is looking at that proposition and I hope that it will be successful, because we need to look at all of the possibilities for wool.

The timber industries in the south-eastern forests, northern New South Wales, Queensland, Western Australia and Victoria are also extremely important. We need to get the balance right. We have had environmental studies in those areas over many years—indeed, decades. The Greens and the industry people can now work together. I talked to both sides before the federal election and they agreed to work with me to ensure that any restructuring which is necessary will take place.

In the south-eastern forests I believe restructuring should be based on a proposition that was put forward by the then Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, to the then Premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner. It ought to be brought into line with negotiations that are going on with the Victorian Government so that we can have an integrated south-eastern Australian timber industry which will proceed along the lines of the proposal which the Federal Government put to the New South Wales Government last year. This proposal may have approximately 50,000 to 60,000 hectares, which have already been set aside, declared as national park. That should be the basis of our action in relation to the timber industry.

The tourist industry is vital to our region. It is a growing industry and a very high income earner for Australia. Along with a whole range of other industries, it gives us a great balance of trade advantage with the countries of South-East Asia, China, Taiwan, South Korea, the Philippines and Japan.

Now I believe we have a surplus of trade with those countries of over $10 billion. There are a lot more opportunities available to increase that surplus, including through tourism. The number of tourists who have come from Singapore recently is approximately 150 per cent higher than a year ago. Tourists from those countries are now interested in Australia. They are interested in snow, and the Snowy Mountains in the electorate of Eden-Monaro will be a great attraction for them. These tourists are also interested in golf, and Australia has some beautiful golf courses. All who have played on our golf courses, such as the one at Narooma with beautiful, picturesque views over the sea, are attracted to them. They are a great attraction to tourists from Asia because of the relatively low cost.

There are plenty of jobs in the Public Service. We have the Public Service towns of Bega, Batemans Bay, Cooma and Queanbeyan working with Canberra so that we have decentralised services with people on the job locally. It is interesting to note that when a social security office was opened in Bega 10 or 11 years ago it was found that not only were a lot of people able to get better justice, better service and fairer treatment because the people were known locally, but those who were trying to defraud the system were found out much more quickly because local people know other local people.

My next suggestion is that we do need to look at our federal system come the turn of the century. We should look at local government because local government ought to be an arm of government which supplies far more services. It is all very well for us to do what we have been doing with State and local governments and say, `Here is a few bob. Here is some money. Why don't you have a go? Why don't you take up this federal or State responsibility? We will give you some money'. But the money is frittered away and they are told, `We can no longer afford to give it to you. Try to do it yourself'.

We need to have a local government system which has a rate raising or taxing system, preferably of its own. At least there needs to be a permanent link into the taxation system so that it can have access to funds, and preferably for it to determine the use of the funds. We should not get rid of the Senate. If we are getting rid of State governments we should keep the Senate and have a national house of parliament which represents local government. That would make the decisions and the House of Representatives would make sure those decisions were equitable across all of Australia and then ratify those decisions.

We need a different system, a national system which gets rid of the huge costs of duplication. This has been talked about by people as disparate as Sir Ninian Stephen and Ian Macphee, as well as a number of people in the Labor Party. They are some suggestions that ought to be looked at seriously. We would save many billions of dollars by having a change in our federal system. It would not only involve savings in taxes by cutting out duplication of jobs but also assist industry.

Just two or three days ago Santos said that it was not able to sell gas across State borders easily because of the different State regulations. Not being able to sell a commodity within Australia because of different State regulations is intolerable. A plumber who moved from one State to another said to me, `I have been here for a year and I still cannot get registered. Even though I am registered in Victoria they will not register me in New South Wales'. Then there are incompatible transport systems. Until recently the Victorian road rules were different. They are the same as the other States now but they could be made different again.

For instance, with gun laws, a State or Territory only needs to panic and say, `We have got to do something about it. We are entitled to do it. We will do it', and once again there will be enormous differences. People do not feel sovereign because they cannot be sure that a person, a member of parliament or a councillor will be the right person to see. How many times do federal members get queries from people about State housing? How many times do we get queries from people about hospitals? Do we turn them away and tell them to go to someone else or do we try to deal with them? Naturally people do not feel sovereign because they cannot be sure where they have to go.

The area of drugs is another example where Australia has different laws. I can recall dispensing amphetamines in the ACT when they were illegal in all other States and Territories. This meant that truckies could come to the ACT, get 100 or 200 tablets, and sell them in other States; that could happen again. Even now we have people in States and Territories saying, `Let's reform our own drug laws and not worry about the rest of the country or the World Health Organisation'. The World Health Organisation may be wrong, but as a country we need uniform laws.

The federal system is an inefficient one that does not recognise the natural geographical boundaries. I have moved a motion in this House before which proposes a different system, which recognises local government as an important seat of power but with a larger number of full-time people. Brisbane, the ACT and Tasmania are good examples of natural regional boundaries for the type of government that we need.

On the subject of drugs, I believe there should be drug law reform. I welcome the fact that Michael Moore, an MLA in the ACT, convened an all-party meeting in Canberra just a few weeks ago. People came from houses of parliament all over Australia prepared to talk about the need for drug law reform and to face the reality of the increasing problems in Australia because of the involvement of crime, not just organised crime but disorganised crime—petty crime, all sorts of crime. Women and old men are being knocked over and robbed of $1,500 so that those on drugs can get their week's supply of a drug which, even with a reasonable profit, should cost only $50.

They adopted a measure, which I have recommended in this Parliament, which would bring a lot of the hard drugs under strict prescription control, as they were in the 1950s in Australia, before we fell for the trap set by the World Health Organisation when it said that there should be a ban on these drugs. What happened after the ban? Instead of people being prescribed their drugs regularly by their doctors, with the pharmacists dispensing them and the addicts paying $50 in today's value and taking them home, knowing that they could come back again in a week, these addicts are now robbing pharmacies, robbing doctors, robbing doctors' bags and stealing so that they can find $1,500 to have their drugs for the week.

We have a different situation. We ought to face reality and bring these drugs under control because we now have a computerised system with doctors, pharmacists and clinics being prepared to be involved so that addicts can get what they are after. We have faced the facts on the prohibition of alcohol, and it does not work. Let us face the facts with other drugs and look at cannabis and its sale.

I mentioned before that the quality of the new members of this House is good and that we can build a better Australia. We can do things better. Debate needs to be strong. There is nothing wrong with the debate that we have had traditionally in this House, but it has to be constructive and we need to keep it that way.
Once again, I welcome the new members to the Parliament and look forward to a three-year term based on the address that the Governor-General gave on Tuesday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. J.D.M. Dobie)—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.

—Last night in his maiden speech in this House the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) attacked my maiden speech made in this House just over eight years ago. He claimed that I cast aspersions on the reputation of Dame Mary Gilmore. To highlight where I have been misrepresented, I will read an extract of the maiden speech made by the honourable member for Gilmore last night:

PARA.TAB: I represent the seat named after one of Australia's truly great politically motivated women of this century, Dame Mary Gilmore. I take the opportunity to right a sleight on her good name perpetrated by the former member for Gilmore, now the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), in his first speech. He questioned whether Mary Gilmore should be considered by some a great Australian because of her political views.

SPEECH.PARA: In my maiden speech delivered eight years ago I referred to Dame Mary Gilmore's reputation. I stated:

The electorate was named in honour of one of Australia's great citizens, Dame Mary Gilmore. Some would criticise me for calling Dame Mary Gilmore a great Australian. They would point out that the differences in political philosophies between her and me would make my declaration somewhat suspect. However, to evaluate a person's worth to the nation using political beliefs as a main criterion is, I believe, an injustice. Surely the best way to evaluate the worth of an Australian is to view the contribution that he or she has made to his or her country, and Dame Mary Gilmore made a great contribution to Australia. She was one of our most noted authors and poets. Indeed, it is my privilege and honour to represent the electorate which bears her name.

I hope that in comparing the quotation from my speech with the claims made by the honourable member for Gilmore last night, I will clear up the matter of misrepresentation. I just hope that in future the honourable member for Gilmore will not base his speeches on misrepresentations as he did last night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to offer my congratulations to my Western Australian colleagues the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) and the honourable member for Pearce (Ms Moylan) on their maiden speeches in this place today. They were indeed commendable first contributions and they can be proud of that very impressive start. I would also add that the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) and the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) made an important start, as have new members on the other side who have already spoken in this place.

PARA.TAB: The Governor-General's speech opening the 37th Parliament of Australia must rank as one of the most longwinded and certainly one of the most boring speeches of any kind heard in this Parliament for some considerable time. In that speech we heard the vision of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet for the future of this country—a dull litany of bureaucratic programs and policies that promise more of the same from this Government over the next three years.

It was a speech totally devoid of ideas or inspiration. Australians listening to that speech—and I suggest that they would not have stayed listening for very long—would have gained the impression that the Australian Government had been hijacked by Sir Humphrey Appleby and his cronies down at gratuithe club. Such an impression would not have been too far from the truth, as the pay TV debacle so amply demonstrates.

The problem is that the Government did not really expect to be re-elected, and so we have a tired Government, devoid of ideas, once again taking the helm but with no real idea of where it wants to go or what it wants to achieve during its coming term in office. Much of what was discussed in that speech merely reaffirmed the Government's intention to continue with programs commenced during the previous parliament and which have been such a resounding failure. Perhaps we should be thankful that the Government does not know what it is doing, lest it do even more damage than it has knowingly done in the past with its programs and policies. And I refer in particular to the deliberate engineering of the recession we `had to have'.

If one were a conspiracy theorist, one might come to the conclusion that the Government tried to force us into changing the arrangements for opening this Parliament by making the current arrangements so crushingly dull that we get down on our hands and knees and beg to be spared from another speech like the one we heard on Tuesday. Maybe the intention is to remove the vice-regal representation from this country by making the office so dull that people plead for it to be taken away. This, I might say, is intended as criticism of the content of the Government's speech rather than as a criticism of the traditions by which the Governor-General opens this Parliament.

But on this occasion one cannot help taking note of the massive irony under which the whole opening ceremony was forced upon us and the nation. We had a new government that was being sworn into office with the very oaths and traditions that the Government is committed to dismantling over the rest of the decade if given the green light to do so by the Australian people. Indeed, that process has already commenced with the Government removing references to the Crown from some oaths of allegiance and in other areas, and it has signalled its intention to continue to do that sort of thing.

Nothing could be more ironic than the spectacle of the Governor-General reading a speech in which he is obliged to reaffirm the Government's stated intention to examine the options for becoming a republic. The indignity of this spectacle was compounded by the fact that the real announcement of the Government's intentions in this regard was not made to the Parliament but in a speech given by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) before a left wing think tank in Sydney last month. That an announcement of this type should be made before such a partisan audience is, of course, entirely inappropriate.

Not only was the Prime Minister's speech given before a partisan audience; it also contained several paragraphs of thoroughly gratuitous criticisms of the Opposition—criticisms that bode ill for a non-partisan and constructive debate on the question of a republic in the years ahead. The Prime Minister was very careful in that speech, and in the terms of reference he set for the Republic Advisory Committee, to limit the debate to the question of the head of state and to avoid taking on board some of the broader constitutional questions that the republic issue inevitably raises.

The terms of reference of the committee require that any options it might come up with for a republic be such as to maintain `the effect of current conventions and principles of government as they apply in this country'. I will leave aside the question of whether we can, in fact, change the head of state and at the same time maintain those principles and conventions in their present form since that would raise enormously complicated legal issues, and they will be best addressed on another occasion or occasions.

Instead, I ask the fundamental question: what is achieved by changing the head of state while not otherwise changing the substance of our system of government? The answer must be, `Very little', unless one is particularly impressed by the symbolism that is said to reside in a change to the existing arrangements pertaining to our head of state. Of course, different people are impressed by different things, but I think that most Australians are not exactly feeling deprived of national symbols at present and can probably live without whatever symbolism might be thought to reside in a change to a republic.

For the Australian Government to be engaged in a major national debate on an issue which is of only symbolic importance would seem to be an expensive indulgence for a country that faces so many other important challenges in the years ahead. If nothing else, it suggests a lack of national maturity that we should be about to spend so much time debating who we are rather than actually getting on with the job of being Australian and achieving the things for which we have been notable in the past and can be notable for in the future.

Moreover, there is an inevitable conflict between the Government's desire to establish an Australian republic—via its so-called minimalist position—and some of the more important constitutional issues which are likely to come up for debate as we approach the centenary of Federation in the year 2001. The political imperative for Labor will be to minimise the extent of constitutional change in order to maximise the chances of a republic succeeding at a referendum of the Australian people. This could mean that a number of important issues in the area of constitutional reform are swept aside for the sake of a largely symbolic change in the arrangements pertaining to this country's head of state.

Indeed, we have already seen the Constitutional Centenary Foundation being pushed aside by the Prime Minister to make way for his Republic Advisory Committee, thereby sidelining serious consideration of constitutional reform by the foundation. There is scope for improvement in our Constitution, but the areas of the Constitution which are probably in least need of reform are those provisions dealing with the head of state. It would seem that the republican push will succeed only at the expense of genuine constitutional reform and the way in which this country is governed will be none the better for it.

The constitutional debate has now been well and truly hijacked by the Prime Minister and that can only mean that the debate will be used for his own political ends at the expense of genuine constitutional reform in matters of substance. The principal danger in this whole process is that we will open the way for the head of state to become politicised, which would seem to be the inevitable consequence of such a debate as it is shaping up at the present time.

Government in this country is likely to take a turn for the worse under a republic if we allow our head of state to become politicised contrary to the way in which our present head of state is notably above politics. For whatever may be said of our current head of state, perhaps her greatest virtue is that she minds her own business. If only the same could be said for the rest of government in this country. The risk we run with an elected President—be it through direct popular election or indirect election through this Parliament—is that we will end up with a highly politicised figure as head of state who will do everything but mind his or her own business.

Australians already have more politicians than we either need or want and there seems to be little to be gained by adding yet another public nuisance to the list of the ones that we already have. Australians fundamentally want to get on with their lives in their own way without being lorded over by public officials, and that includes republican heads of state. The people do not need yet another public busybody to tell them how they should live their lives, which is the likely result of having a politicised head of state with his or her own popular mandate to make a pest of themselves.

Our present head of state has the good sense and respect for her subjects to leave them in peace or, where necessary, to take the advice of the government of the day on those rare occasions when she is required to act. In short, there are some distinct advantages to the existing arrangements for this country's head of state that we would lose by becoming a republic. I quote what one political scientist had to say on the subject:

SPEECH.PARA: If we must have anything so distasteful as a `head of state', then it is just as well that she be half a globe away and not settled in our midst.
However, he went on to put the debate in its proper context when he said:

While it is important what rules and practices are adopted or prevail within the structure of a constitutional government, it is much less important what political form constitutional Government takes. By whom we are governed matters equally little: self-government is no substitute for good government.

Unfortunately, good government is not the principal concern of this Government in promoting the republic debate. The Government is more concerned with dividing the Liberal Party and the coalition than it is with genuine constitutional reform for the purposes of good government in this country. It would be a tragedy indeed if we marked the centenary of Federation by adopting an inferior form of government to the one with which we began the century all for the sake of some inconsequential symbolism and the partisan political purposes of Labor.

PARA.TAB: The Government's talent for politicising what should not be politicised, or does not need to be politicised, is amply demonstrated by some of the things said in the Governor-General's address delivered at the opening of this 37th Parliament. The Government's intentions in relation to the arts and cultural policy are particularly disturbing. The elevation of the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) to Cabinet level signals Labor's intention to further politicise the arts community for its own ends.

The extent to which the arts community has already been politicised by this Government was made painfully apparent during the election campaign when an unrepresentative group of artists jumped onto the ALP's campaign bandwagon and said that the re-election of a Labor government would be good for the arts. Of course, what they were really saying was that the re-election of Labor would be good for them, the artists, regardless of what it meant for the rest of the arts community.

Now they are to be rewarded with the Government's proposal to develop a cultural policy to be released by the end of this year which will no doubt supply certain individuals with some nice work at public expense. The very idea of a Commonwealth cultural policy should ring alarm bells with anyone concerned for the future of arts in this country. The view that the Commonwealth government should have primary responsibility for developing this country's cultural life is a dangerous one. The nation's culture should be the spontaneous product of its people's many and varied efforts in a variety of fields and not something that should be orchestrated by a government at a national level.

A national cultural policy means coaxing the arts community into a dependence on the Commonwealth government for guidance and funding to an even greater extent than prevails at the present time. This is a recipe for patronage and corruption in the arts that can only serve to stifle creativity. We could well end up with a cultural community so beholden to the cultural commissars in Canberra that the cultural life of this country suffers as a consequence.

It will also mean that many worthy cultural activities will suffer for lack of political influence in Canberra. Surely, it is for the Australian people themselves to decide which of the arts and which artists they wish to patronise and not for the Government to go around picking winners in the arts in the way that it tries to do in so many other areas. Nothing could be more damaging to the cultural development of our country than an arts community beholden to the Commonwealth Government in the way foreshadowed in the Governor-General's speech.
Among the more curious of the initiatives flagged by the Government was its intention to establish a `Foundation for Australian Cultural Development', the purpose of which will be to:

SPEECH.PARA: help all Australians locate themselves within their country's . . . cultural landscape.

I think that most Australians would be surprised to learn that they need locating in their cultural landscape, much less that they should be obliged to pay for the privilege. It is typical of the arrogance of the Government that it can take on itself the role of shepherding the Australian people towards an unspecified cultural identity and destiny. Most Australians are perfectly comfortable with where they stand in relation to their cultural heritage and the last thing they need is for the Government to be running around and telling them how they can find themselves in this context. The reference in the address to arts and culture is typical of how out of touch this Government really is with the needs and interests of ordinary Australians.

PARA.TAB: The Government's stated intentions in this area—as in so many others—reflect the interests of the Commonwealth bureaucracy at the expense of those of the rest of the population. The Government's program for the next three years is built around special interest groups. If they have a special interest, chances are there is something in the Government's address for them, however insignificant that something might be.

Not surprisingly, there is relatively little discussion of the general mainstream interest, or the national interest, probably because the Government simply has no conception of the national interest with which to govern this country. The Governor-General's speech on the opening of this, the 37th Parliament, does not bode well for this country's future over the next three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commence my remarks by congratulating you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your election to that post. As well, I convey my congratulations to Mr Speaker on his election.

PARA.TAB: In responding to the Governor-General's address, which marked the opening of this, the 37th Parliament, it is relevant to observe that the Government's policies for the next three years, outlined by the Governor-General in what was significantly great detail, evince a new and vigorous nation making a conscious decision, through the primacy of the ballot box, to go forward, both at home and abroad, with decency, equity and innovation.

This election has been hailed as yet another watershed election—a term which is only too commonly applied; in fact, it is somewhat passe. Undoubtedly, it was an election which more clearly than any other in over 20 years represented an opportunity for the electorate to choose between two starkly differing political parties with diametrically opposing beliefs right across the policy platforms. It was an election which, based on Australian political precedent and conventional political wisdom, the Opposition should have been able to win. There was record unemployment. At one stage leading into the election the Opposition was 15 per cent in front in the polls and we had an incumbent government seeking a fifth term following a bad recession. It is, of course, part of the living history of this place that those opposite are now doing much soul searching to find out what went wrong from their perspective.

The political scientist Malcolm Mackerras who is sometimes pilloried for his observations and predictions has—I believe most adeptly—identified the symptoms but not the cause of the electorate's decision. The Australian people, to paraphrase Mackerras, voted for the party of least change, as they saw it, and the party of greater certainty—a decision which should not surprise any of us in this place, given the traditional conservative nature of Australians. Of course, when I say conservative, I do not necessarily mean politically conservative; I mean conservative in their outlook.

That, however, does not explain the cause of the last election result. The answer is simple: for 10 hard, long years Labor governments have taken one difficult decision after another, only to be met at every turn with blatantly shallow attempts by those opposite to extract political mileage above all else. Those opposite—mostly by implication, but particularly in the fundamentals of Fightback—said that there was a better way; their way.

The Opposition's problem was that in the full and robust debate that was unleashed by a national election in this country over a full five-week period the nation decided for itself—as families, as individuals, as employers, as employees—that in fact there was no better way than what was being undertaken by the Government. They decided that the only alternative on offer to meet the national aspirations, to heal our problems, was a radically repugnant change to the fundamentals of their lives and their country. The crux in short is that given an alternative, they endorsed the realism of this Government's course.

For Labor it was politically a reward for courage and for vision displayed over 10 years. Not for a moment did the electorate reject the concept of change itself; it rejected the type of change on offer. I think that Australians, whether they be in suburban Sydney, in the outback of Queensland or anywhere else in this country now know that the only constant for this country in the foreseeable future is change itself.

This goes to the heart of the matter of the Governor-General's address, which is the manifestation of this Labor Government's mandate. Australians gave us a mandate, clearly and unequivocally. They voted for what they saw quite rightly as rational people making policy based on principles, not people with prejudices claiming rationality. If two policy areas can be singled out above all else, education and health were perhaps the most obvious examples of this choice and of our mandate. But let it be said very quickly that the economy, industrial relations, sport, social security and so much more—particularly, I might say, Aboriginal affairs and immigration—were not far behind as obvious examples of this choice, this mandate.

I think that the basic message that has to be understood, by those opposite in particular, is that we on this side of the House, individually and collectively, have shown on five occasions that we understand that ordinary Australians essentially want two things for their kids above all else, although not to the exclusion of all else. Above all else, ordinary Australians want two things for their kids. First, they want their kids' health. They want to know that they are well; they want to know that if they get sick they can make them well without breaking the family financially. Second, they want those kids educated. They want them to have a chance at what Australia's popular radio commentator John Laws repeatedly calls `keeping the dream alive'. They want that hope, that aspiration for their kids. I think all parents like to think that their children will do just that little bit better than their mum or dad; at least, if they cannot do that, they want to give their children the opportunity to do better than their mum or their dad. It is the Australian way; it is our version of the national dream. It is the aspiration of ordinary people. It is not an aspiration that any political party can or should have the right to assign only to those people with inherited wealth.

That was one of the symptoms. In the end it was only those people with inherited wealth who could bring themselves to identify with the Liberals. From the Liberals they got a health policy which they knew would endanger the basic right to health of themselves and their kids. The Liberals, it must be said, spent an awfully long time trying to woo the young in the lead-up to the election—as did the health funds for their own particular purposes. Over the last 12 months in particular the Liberal message on health was one that perhaps some of those young people have heard in a well-known rock song by the Irish band U2. It goes along these lines: `the rich stay healthy and the sick stay poor'. That was what the Liberals' health policy meant to young Australians.

In education Australians saw the right of access for their kids to university and to TAFE colleges on the basis of scholastic merit being threatened for the first time since 1972. If the honourable member opposite has any doubt about that, she should have come and stood on a few railway stations with me in Sydney. What was being proposed for education by those opposite went absolutely to the core of ordinary Australians' aims and aspirations, not only for themselves but for their kids. Of all the alternative Liberal and National Party policies that were on offer at the last election, the education plank of those opposite was by far the most elitist and the most repugnant.

What the Liberals and the Nationals, the Nationals tagging on behind like mules in a horse race, both managed to do was to create a new class divide, a new class consciousness not just based on wealth or income, as political scientists hitherto have so described it but more fundamentally on access and equity. Access and equity became issues. They came alive to the ordinary Australian. The Australian people rejected that divide as unethical and un-Australian. Our mandate, by contrast, is underpinned by a social consciousness that says that every Australian who needs help has a right to that help.

Nothing is more reflective for those opposite than an article in today's Australian Financial Review on the National Farmers Federation. Let me read just two short pieces from it. I quote from page 16 of the Australian Financial Review:

SPEECH.PARA: If the peak farming lobby group's open support for much of the Coalition's economic platform, particularly the GST, during the election campaign strained relations with Labor, two months later it would seem the NFF is back in business.
Further it says:

Today, amid the worst rural crisis in most farmers' memory, battered by drought and collapsing wool prices, the NFF appears more preoccupied with the political task of extracting better and bigger welfare payments from the Government for drought-stricken farmers than waging industrial war.

All Australians, even those who have their industrial representation by an organisation such as the National Farmers Federation are entitled to assistance from the Government, from the taxpayer's purse, when they need it; everyone, bar none.

PARA.TAB: Our mandate, and our underlying beliefs, are now more substantial, more popularly based and more rationally rooted in our society's consent than perhaps any other Government in the history of this place. We have got a mandate to touch the hitherto untouchable—constitutional change and indigenous rights. The Australian electorate does not see these as radical any longer; rather, I submit, people see them as overdue. They see them as a consistent plank with the notion of a new nation, realising its place in the new and growing part of the world, rather than being tied to the old world.

The Governor-General's address reflects a mandate that Australians have given to us to concentrate on policies that grow the national cake, rather than frantically and fanatically being preoccupied with trying to find a new way to divide it. I conclude by adding one further point: that is to thank the constituents of Barton, who on the last occasion gave me a vote of almost 60 per cent on a two-party preferred basis.

It seems a light year from previous results but to all my constituents, whether they voted for me or against me, I again pledge my full effort and the effort of my staff in the three years ahead. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I appreciate the call. I found out a little over 10 seconds ago that I was due to be in the chamber right now.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Government members may scoff but it is true and I say to the new ones among them, `Don't laugh, baby. It could happen to you too'—and with any luck it will.

PARA.TAB: There are so many things that one could speak about and should speak about in this address-in-reply debate but the first thing I should do is very publicly thank and congratulate all of my supporters in the electorate of Cowper who worked so very hard to help get me re-elected. I also thank those who voted for me because, without the support of people, honourable members cannot be here, and one needs to be here to achieve anything through the Federal Government. I would also like to pay tribute to my wife and staff who have been incredibly supportive and to the vast numbers of volunteer people who gave unstintingly of their time to help in that campaign.

The speech of the Government, presented by the Governor-General, took something like 57 minutes, by my count, to deliver. I do not know whether that was a record; I suspect it may be. I certainly think that it was a record for the number of people dozing, nodding or dropping off over in the other place. I say that not in any obnoxious way. Quite frankly, even though I believe that gentleman who runs the program called Hinch—he is occasionally described by people in my electorate as the talking armpit—in his program, accused the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of going to sleep during the Governor-General's speech, I personally do not believe that. I could not imagine that the Prime Minister would actually do that, but I must say that looking around the chamber I saw a lot of people actually nodding off. I think the reason for it was that all the senators were there, and all of us, and the galleries were full. It became rather hot and of course the speech was going on and on and on.

It would be appropriate initially to look back at the election we have just had because it has been a watershed election for Australia. I believe that there is one very significant loser from that election—a lot of people lost their seats on both sides—but the great losers are the people of Australia and the pursuit of honesty and integrity in election campaigns.

On this side of the House, our sin was the sin of honesty. We went before the people of Australia with our policies spelt out in hundreds of pages of policy statement and said exactly what we were going to do in almost every area of activity. We spelt it right out. We had no secrets, no hidden agenda. On the other hand, the Government's sin, quite frankly, was the sin of not telling the truth and of obfuscation. I congratulate the Government's advertising agency—John Singleton's, I think—on a very effective campaign. Its campaign of lies, distortions, half truths and deliberate falsehoods was very effective indeed.

For the interest of the House and those who might be listening, I will just give one little anecdote about my campaign to illustrate how effective the Government's campaign of misinformation and disinformation was. I am an old-fashioned sort of politician. I like to get out on street corners and footpaths with a microphone, stand up and let people see me, say what I think and, if they want to, they can have a go at me. In the last week of the election campaign I did that in 20 separate towns and centres around Cowper. One was a delightful village called Gladstone in the Macleay Valley. I set up my microphone and speakers in a little park alongside the river—

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't need a microphone.

—That is true, but it was a long way down the road. Across the road was a hotel. I started speaking and then I noticed—this is probably why I needed the microphone—a class of primary school children crocodiling up the road. They came and sat on the grass alongside me. Naturally, because of the presence of the kids, I abandoned my very partisan political speech and spoke to the kids about Australia, democracy, the Parliament and the value of the Australian democratic process. Afterwards, I was chatting with the kids and they were asking questions—remember that they were primary school children aged about 11—and one question was, `Why are you going to take away all the pensions?'. Another question was, `Why can't we have Medicare any more?'. This was a group of 11-year-old Australian children who believed the absolutely unbelievable because they had been virtually brainwashed by the television election campaign of this Government. There is a lesson there for everybody. As I said, the great sufferers will be the Australian people because we will never again have the same degree of honesty and openness in election campaigns around Australia.

PARA.TAB: We still have a situation where there are one million people unemployed. The Prime Minister and some others tend to get carried away about their desire for a republic. I still think that is a red herring. I still believe that what is important for those of us who have been privileged enough to be elected or re-elected to this Parliament, and what is important for all of us, is the economy. This should be the focus of our total attention when one million people still are unemployed—and, if we add in the number of people underemployed, the figure would probably be closer to two million. Then there is the balance of payments figure of $2.1 billion. It is only one month's figure but, when added to all the others, it makes an enormous number indeed.

Our concern has to be for the people that we represent right around Australia. So far this session this Parliament has improved in terms of Question Time behaviour by comparison with the last parliament. Mind you, it is early days yet. Who knows what will happen in the future? I, for one, very strongly believe that we all need to cooperate to have the Parliament work in a more harmonious and less rowdy way. Most people's exposure to parliament is through Question Time, which will always be vigorous. People do not realise that for most of the day there is very little—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is boring.

—Particularly when the honourable member interjecting is speaking, yes; I acknowledge what he said. For most of the day there is very little uproar. What people should realise is that in the parliamentary committee system there is an almost totally bipartisan approach, with members of the Labor Party, the Liberal Party, the National Party, the Australian Democrats and the Independents working together very closely for the benefit of Australia. This is a side of the Parliament that people do not see and of which they are not aware. It is our responsibility to help people understand just what goes on.

PARA.TAB: Having made those general remarks, I would like to deal with some specific matters. As I said when I came into the chamber, I was not expecting to speak until after the suspension of the sitting for dinner, so I am shuffling papers for the moment, trying to find, in the right order, some of the very many things about which I need to speak. First, I congratulate the Banana Growers Federation of New South Wales, the body organising the banana industry in that State as the COD does in Queensland. I am very pleased to announce to this Parliament that there has been a breakthrough in export development.
