In the past, there have been trial shipments of bananas to New Zealand, but there has always been some difficulty competing with bananas from Ecuador. Trevor Miller, the chairman of directors of the Banana Growers Federation, from Macksville in my electorate, has announced a trial shipment of two cartons of bananas to Greece.

I am very pleased to be able to report to the House that, although the Greek authorities tested our bananas for radiation and disease problems before considering New South Wales as a major source of supply, the fruit passed with flying colours. The next step is to send a 600-carton container load to Athens. If that goes as well as expected—I am sure this will be of interest to the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), who also represents some wonderful banana growers in the northern part of the State—Greece is looking at importing three or four containers of our bananas each week. Each container will return to growers a net $6,000. So we are therefore looking at a new market worth a million dollars a year. That is excellent. I am very pleased about it. There is even talk of marketing the fruit in Greece as Aussie Kanga bananas. That is very interesting.

The other interesting point is that we can compete with Greece's usual supplier, Ecuador, because the Greek Government has a 20 per cent tariff on bananas from South America. Our bananas get in tariff free. Perhaps there is a little lesson there for all of us looking at the level playing field. For once, that alleged level playing field—whatever it may be—is working in our favour.

I also want to mention the fact that, as a result of legislation coming up in the New South Wales Parliament later in the year, the University of New England's Coffs Harbour campus will combine with the Lismore campus of the University of New England to become the University of the North Coast. It will be a separate university college, probably under the parenthood of the University of New South Wales, or perhaps the University of Sydney, which actually parented the fledgling University of New England decades ago. I am very pleased that this is going to happen.

The honourable member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) is in the chamber, and I say particularly to him that in the long-term or even in the medium-term there should be a campus for the University of the North Coast at Port Macquarie. That would certainly complement the campuses at Lismore and Coffs Harbour. It is appropriate that the funding should be maintained specifically for each of those campuses. I am not throwing spears at anybody, but it is a fact that, in the past, federal funding earmarked for the university campus in Coffs Harbour was somehow siphoned off to the campus in Armidale. The rationale for that was that there were people from the coast being educated at Armidale anyway. I have written to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) and made it very clear that as far as I am concerned—and I believe this Parliament should endorse this—there should be some specific provision for earmarking funding for the Coffs Harbour campus of the University of the North Coast.

Another matter I want to mention in this debate is my concern about small abattoirs. There are two in my electorate: one at Repton, operated by the Perry family, and the other at South West Rocks, operated by Kevin Ball. There is another one at Murwillumbah in the seat of Richmond which had a very tough trot because of the funding of beef inspection. The cost has gone up substantially, making the situation totally unfair. The figures are not exact, but the cost of meat inspection has increased from something like $60 to over $336 a week. This should be looked at. These small abattoirs are important employers in local areas. We must bear in mind that the north coast of New South Wales has incredibly high unemployment.

Finally, I want to deal with my concerns for the armed services of this country. Most people are unaware of the frightful situation regarding funding in our defence forces. We see a lot of publicity about the wonderful job—and it is a wonderful job—that we are doing in Somalia and Cambodia, but it is absolutely true that our defence forces are underfunded. Defence spending has declined both in terms of outlays and as a percentage of government spending. The Australian Defence Force is short in a number of capabilities. Since the Government decided to reduce the number of infantry battalions from six to four, there has been a shortage of available troops, and United Nations commitments are overstretching the Australian Defence Force.

There is no money for bullets for training infantry, and there is no fuel for ships. Ships cannot be driven without fuel. Pilots and aircraft in the Royal Australian Air Force are not getting adequate flying hours because of the lack of funding. There is not enough money for the long advocated airborne early warning aircraft system. The lack of funding has meant that the option for an additional two submarines will not be taken up. Many other areas of ADF supply are very low and would present very severe problems if the Australian Defence Force were required to deploy a significant force at short notice.

Very often there is no funding available for travel and subsistence for members of the armed services undertaking activities. They can get a field allowance, but it is far less than the normal travel and subsistence allowance, and even that has been cut out. I invite honourable members to check this for themselves if they doubt me. We have Leopard tanks which are incredibly old: they are not regarded as a main battle tank anywhere else in the world.

In two years our armoured corps is going to be totally non-effective. We should have three sabre or front-line active squadrons. We had one with a reserve, with two regulars, but now one has gone to the Ready Reserve and we have only one regular squadron in the armoured corps. Anybody with any knowledge of the Australian Army—as the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) has—will agree that it is not a satisfactory situation. We still have many regulars in the Ready Reserve squadrons, but within two years they will be gone and we will be left with only one regular sabre squadron; and that is not enough to be operational in a battle situation.

The Ready Reserve trainees do 50 days a year. It is totally inadequate. One general reserve squadron is not enough; 6 RAR is under half strength; and our infantry battalions have platoons with a lieutenant as a platoon commander but with no soldiers to command. This is a dreadful indication of the future of our defence forces. In Sydney, 5/7 RAR would be lucky to fill two companies out of four; 3 RAR is understrength; and so it goes on. There are very strong rumours in the defence forces that promotion for junior officers will be frozen for the next 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rumour is better than rubbish.

—Maybe so, but it depends who is dealing it out. It becomes true if it is perceived that way by people. If we have junior officers of the Australian Defence Force believing that they will not get promotion for the next 18 months because all promotions will be frozen, it is extraordinarily bad for morale. I believe that the Australian defence forces are made up of excellent men and women—they have my total support—but I do not believe that this Government is doing the right thing by them.

PARA.TAB: If we look at the strategic considerations for supporting more defence spending, we have to remember that the United States is reducing its military power in our region. President Clinton is further cutting United States defence spending. The Philippines bases have gone. There are a number of intractable trouble spots in our region—Bougainville and Papua New Guinea with general instability, Timor, Cambodia, the Spratly Islands area where China is very interested, and Fiji where Rabuka is really sitting on an ethnic and social powder keg. With this environment in our backyard, it is vitally important that we continue to properly fund our defence forces. It is totally irresponsible if we continue to cut into defence outlays.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to have a chance to comment on those extraordinary claims of the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl). He does not seem to know the facts at all. In the last Budget, defence expenditure went up by $500 million. In conventional terms, it was a real increase of four per cent. The total defence outlays at $10 billion is 2 1/2 times more than the Government allocates for all universities and all post-secondary education in Australia. The level of defence funding is 2.4 per cent of GDP. As a proportion of national income, it is at the same level now as it was at the beginning of the 1980s.

PARA.TAB: We are about the only Western country which has not cut its defence outlays as a proportion of national income during the last few years. Every major Western country is cutting its defence outlays. The United States and Britain are cutting their outlays very strongly. British defence expenditure has gone down from 5 1/2 per cent of GDP to under 3.8 per cent. America's expenditure peaked at close to seven per cent and it is now down to less than five per cent. Germany is cutting strongly, and so are most of the other Western countries. Japan is not, but Japan spends only one per cent of its national income on defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ours is 2.4.

—That is what I said; ours is 2.4 per cent, and it has not fallen since the beginning of the 1980s. When the honourable member talks about cuts to defence outlays, he is simply misleading the House and misleading the community.
—Would you like to look at the figures?

—I have the figures. Defence outlays went up by $500 million in the last Budget, which is as much as the total outlays of the CSIRO. We spend more than four times as much on our defence as Indonesia, which is a country 10 times larger than us. We spend more on defence than all the ASEAN countries put together. We spend more than mainland China does on defence.
—No.

—That is true. I can show the honourable member the figures. China has 1.1 billion people compared with our 17 million people. The honourable member is absolutely deluded. His own coalition intended if it won government to cut outlays by $300 million. There was no truth in the parameters of what he said whatsoever. It was completely misleading. I suggest that he looks at the facts before he makes those quite misleading and false charges again.

—Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your election and wish you great success as an eminent, intelligent and fair Speaker. We were elected to parliament at the same time, and I am sure that you are likely to achieve those goals. I want to use this opportunity to speak about employment particularly because, as the Governor-General said in his speech on Tuesday:

SPEECH.PARA: Reducing unemployment remains the ultimate focus of all the government's economic policies.
Of course, it must be. He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Fundamental to progress on this front will be the continued application of policy settings that achieve the maximum sustainable rate of economic growth.
Above all else, growth holds the key to reducing unemployment to more acceptable levels.

SPEECH.PARA: That is certainly true. It is essential that we build up the rate of economic growth so as to maximise the rate of employment growth in normal ways. The question is, though, how do we do that? I think there is an issue about the macro-economic settings which have to be addressed. The Governor-General went on to say:
The Government's aim is to reduce the deficit to 1 per cent of GDP by 1996-97.

I think that that is making too much of a goal which really is an intermediate goal. If we want to reduce unemployment we have to maximise the level of economic activity through every means at the Government's disposal. Amongst those has to be its own expenditure and its own monetary policy. I think it is important to examine what we are talking about when we are talking about a Budget deficit.

PARA.TAB: It is conventional in Australia to regard the Budget deficit as the difference between total outlays and total revenue. That is really a very simplistic way of looking at it, because at the very least there are two very different types of outlays. There are recurrent outlays, such as salaries, transfer payments to the social security recipients, and so on, and there are capital outlays which are used for building infrastructure or hospitals or schools or whatever. It is quite legitimate to say that revenue should be equal to or greater than recurrent outlays, but that borrowing should be, by and large, used for funding investment.

We seem to have forgotten that important economic distinction. It is now being talked about a lot in the United States. President Clinton has been giving renewed emphasis to the building of infrastructure in the US. Robert Reich, one of his advisers, has published a very important book called, The Work of Nations and it makes this distinction. Other eminent economists in the US are doing so as well.

In fact, the New Zealand Government, with whom I am sure colleagues on my side would have many points of dispute, has introduced a system of public accounting which does distinguish between recurrent expenditure and capital expenditure, not least for this reason that the economic effects of those two forms of expenditure are quite different. Even the Economist, the conservative Economist—which is a very useful source of information but which has many very conservative views—in an editorial not long ago stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . borrowing for investment by governments is appropriate because `future generations who enjoy the benefits of that investment will pay for it through higher interest payments.' This `seems to give reflation a ring of prudence.'

If a conservative mainstream news magazine at that time—with a very intelligent approach to reporting the news, it must be said—can make that kind of comment, I think that we can seriously consider that sort of approach here as well. If we do that, then the kind of deficit fetishism which has characterised much debate about fiscal policy in Australia becomes far less important. We were even criticised for that by the Brooklands Institute team that came to Australia in the early 1980s. They talked about the Treasury `frightening of the bourgeoisie' with the Budget deficit.

PARA.TAB: There has been a tendency amongst the people who are called economic rationalists and the official advisers in a number of departments, to give a lot of attention to reducing outlays, to overemphasise the Budget deficit rather than looking more analytically at the various parts of outlays and the various forms of revenue, and seeing what the economic consequences are.

I suggest that we should give a bit less attention to the overall deficit, a bit more attention to recurrent outlays and matching revenue, and concentrate rather more on those policies which will lead to economic growth which depends principally on the level of investment and that is both public investment and private investment. It has to be predominantly private investment.

One of the elements of the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), Investing in the nation, which was released during the election, and which gave me greatest pleasure, was the announcement that an investment allowance would be introduced which would apply for just a couple of years. It would be at the rate of 10 per cent, and a 10 per cent reduction on tax paid, as long as the investment occurred in that period. That has the obvious advantage of encouraging enterprises to bring forward investment that they might have deferred indefinitely. Knowing that other firms are going to do the same thing will have the cumulative effect of increasing investment in the next couple of years when we need it most to get out of this severe recession which we have been in and from which we are starting to emerge.

One of the other pieces of information that was included in Investing in the nation was on the level of Government debt in Australia. Together with frightening people about the deficit, another way of arguing for reductions in outlays or restraint on outlays has been to point to the high level of overseas debt. It is true that we as a nation do have a high level of overseas debt, but it is predominantly private debt. It is not government debt. In fact, the level of government debt in Australia is very low indeed.

The Prime Minister showed in a table that was included in his statement that gross public debt in Australia in 1991 was only 26 per cent of gross domestic product of national income. That was the second lowest in the OECD, amongst Western industrialised countries. For Western countries the average level of government debt was 60 per cent of national GDP. In Australia, it is 26 per cent. The only country which has a smaller debt is Finland which has a debt of 21 per cent of its GDP. Every other country: the United States, for example, 60 per cent; the Netherlands, 77 per cent; Canada, 78 per cent; and so on, right up to Belgium which has a public debt of 132 per cent of its national income. These are much higher than that in Australia. The significance of that is that it gives us the freedom to borrow in order to invest when we need to do so. Now, more than ever, is the time that we need to do so. That was the central thrust of the One Nation statement. That was the rationale for the increase in outlays on public infrastructure, and that is what we can continue in the next Budget and even in the Budget after that, if the economy has still not picked up at that time.
I wanted to talk about a couple of other aspects of employment policy because it is quite clear, as the Governor-General said in his speech, that additional policies are required. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we also acknowledge that new policies and practices may have to be developed.

There is absolutely no doubt about that, and it is very good to know that work is going on within the Government to design new policies which will have the effect of building up employment. There are no panaceas, and no-one has all the answers. We should be looking for good ideas wherever they can be found. In fact, there were some very good ideas in the maiden speech made by the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) this morning, which I would strongly endorse and encourage the Government to look at very seriously.

PARA.TAB: I think the honourable member for Lowe (Mrs Easson) mentioned in her maiden speech this morning that most employment growth is likely to come from small business. I think she is right about that. The evidence is that that is what has been happening in recent years. What can the Government do to encourage employment growth in small business? The most important is to reduce interest rates, to keep interest rates as low as possible. The level at which interest rates have to be set is a question of judgment; it is a complex judgment. It depends on the impact on the exchange rate in particular, and on what is happening to the economy.

Despite what is likely to be a one-off high current account deficit, which was announced this week, I do think that there is some scope for some further fall in interest rates. They have come down a great deal in the last couple of years. But I think that, because the economy is still relatively recessed, because it would do no harm at all if the exchange rate were a little lower, and because countries which have a strong influence on our interest rate are also reducing their interest rates, there may well be scope for a further small reduction here—maybe another half a per cent, and possibly another one per cent in due course. That has to be looked at very seriously.

Another issue is the availability of capital. In the last two or three years there has been a problem: the banks, which were severely damaged by their excesses in the 1980s, have been too restrictive in their lending practices. Mr Speaker, you prepared a very interesting report for Parliament on the banking system. It made a number of recommendations which were very important. It is important for the Government to keep urging the banks to be as imaginative and as creative as they can be in their lending policies. It may be that additional institutional changes are required in order to ensure that capital is available for small business.

Last week I had a very useful discussion with a senior private banker. He said that, in his judgment, there is still a gap in the capital market for lending to smaller and medium businesses which do not have physical assets to offer as security on their borrowing. That is a major problem. Companies often depend principally on the intellectual capacities of their staff and, therefore, they do not own the buildings in which they work. For example, a computer software firm—one I am particularly familiar with in Canberra—does not own its building. It has a staff of 25 and has a good order book. One would think that the order book would be enough security to warrant additional lending, but it was not sufficient when the company went for an increase in its overdraft so as to expand its equipment base. That sort of restriction on the availability of working capital is a severe constraint on the expansion of some of the more dynamic smaller and medium businesses. We should be looking for every possible way to address that problem.

Yesterday it was interesting to hear the Vice-President of the World Bank speak to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. He said that most of the growth in Taiwan, which has had an enormously successful economic performance over the last three decades, has been through small business. In fact, the 60 largest companies in Taiwan are responsible for exporting only 5 per cent of its exports. Most of Taiwan's exports are from quite small companies, and that economy is very dispersed. In Korea, five companies are responsible for about 80 per cent of its exports. Korea has a totally different economic system. If we were to look for an example of a country which has successfully built up its exports, Taiwan is a good country to look to. Taiwan has larger reserves of foreign exchange than Japan. Part of the reason for its success has been the effectiveness of its small businesses.

There are many other aspects of policy. For the next year we will have to debate many additional policies in this House—frequently, I hope—in order to stimulate growth in employment. No person, no school of thought and probably no party has all the answers on this issue. It is extraordinarily difficult to deal not only with a million unemployed but with 400,000 long-term unemployed people. It must be our highest priority. I commend the Government for giving it that emphasis, and I hope that this debate and others like it will provide a forum for ideas to be presented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on attaining your high office. I am confident that you will do the job admirably and, I am sure, better than the last incumbent.

PARA.TAB: Last Tuesday we were subjected to what could only be described as a disgraceful, boring speech written by the Government for the Governor-General to deliver. I confess that I nodded off five times in the first half hour of the speech. It was 25 pages in length, went for about an hour, and has now become known as the alphabetical speech—going from A for Aborigines to W for women. As important as those two segments are, had they been taken out the speech could have been shortened to about 15 minutes.

Having reached W for women, I would have liked to have seen the speech go further to W for wheat and especially to W for wool. Those two great industries were not even mentioned, although wool is Australia's No. 1 industry and is in diabolical trouble at the moment. The theme of what I have to say this evening can be embodied in the words of the prominent poet Dame Edith Sitwell:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the public will believe anything—so long as it is not founded on truth.

In saying that, I am referring to Labor's election campaign. On 13 March, Labor scored a largely unexpected win. In the House of Representatives it scored the greatest proportion of votes and seats in both Territories: the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory; it polled most votes in three of the six States: New South Wales, Tasmania and Victoria; and it also won most seats in three States: New South Wales, Tasmania and Queensland. It won by a narrow margin and, for the first time since 1984, polled more primary votes than the coalition right across Australia.

PARA.TAB: Labor won 80 seats against the coalition's 65, made up of 49 Liberal and 16 National. There are two Independents who mostly vote with the Government, particularly on substantial matters. Although the Government has virtually doubled its majority in the House of Representatives, its uniform margin to lose has actually decreased markedly to between 0.5 and 0.6 per cent. I think that 1,550 votes across eight electorates would have changed the government. The margin the Government holds is considerably thinner than is generally realised, and I state that because the media has painted it as a 100 or a zero per cent situation. Had there been 1,500 votes the other way the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) would have been painted as a courageous visionary instead of being written off as a politically naive person for having told the Australian people the truth about what needed to be done before the election rather than after the election.

Nevertheless, having said that, we live in a democracy. The Labor Party has won and I congratulate it for that. Winners are grinners, so the saying goes, and the rest can please themselves. I guess there is another pertinent saying: all's fair in love, war and politics. But, regrettably, in the last election campaign the Labor Party stretched even a robust interpretation of that saying to its limits and well beyond. In short, it lied its way into government.

I am not talking about the orthodox scare campaign those opposite ran against the GST. In a democracy that is legitimate. One may think it is sad, wrong and regrettable, but it is legitimate and all political parties of all colours always exaggerate their good points and gloss over their bad. They sometimes stretch credibility past its limits by waxing lyrical about the consequences of their policies and try to scare the pants off the voting public about the perceived dire effects of their opponent's platform. It might not be what we would want in a perfect world—and I suppose it is no wonder the public sometimes holds us in such low regard and views us with cynicism.I freely confess that the coalition has indulged in all of these dubious but timehonoured tactics since the formation of our parties, as previous Labor members and governments have done. As Churchill said, democracy is the worst system in the world except for all the others.

But this election was different. The Labor Party and its cohorts smashed the bedrock of acceptability and plumbed depths that most people never knew existed. The major distortion Labor members mouthed—and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did it too—was that a 15 per cent GST would be slapped on everything. Leaving aside the fact that the tax certainly did not apply to everything, at best this was a half truth because it did not mention all the complicated taxes that were already applied and all of which would come off.

I can live with that sort of distortion; it is par for the course for the Labor Party and I have grown used to it. But I do take offence when a party goes beyond even that and resorts to a host of persistent and deliberate lies as part of its scare campaign. I, for one, have never seen anything like what the Labor Party resorted to at the last election. It is worth putting on record some of its shameful transgressions, from the simple to the more blatant.

I refer to one which was circulated by the Labor candidate who stood against me in the last election. In his literature he said, `Under the GST essentials like toothpaste will all cost more'. He did not mention the payroll tax, fuel tax and the 20 per cent sales tax components in the price of toothpaste which would come off. Once those taxes had come off, the price of toothpaste would have actually come down.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was misleading your constituents, wasn't he?

—Indeed, he was. Senator Michael Beahan, in a circular to his constituents, said, `Dr Hewson plans to make private health insurance compulsory'. Our policy was nothing of the sort. The honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford), whom I hold in high regard and who is a friend of mine, said in a `To the Householder' letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr Hewson . . . plans a new tax on motorists which would mean a huge jump in the cost of registering a car—by up to 160%.
In another sentence, he said:
Dr Hewson will add his 15% GST to . . . driver's licences, insurance . . .
Was that right or wrong? It was blatantly wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another lie.

—Indeed. What about some of the Labor cohorts? The Media, Entertainment and Arts Alliance handed out a pamphlet to 12,000 spectators who came to watch the pre-season rugby league final at Dubbo. Mr Speaker, you would perhaps have some interest in this. The pamphlet said that, under a coalition government, when people turned up to a rugby league match every soft drink they would buy would cost an extra 15 per cent. But a 20 per cent sales tax, plus all the other taxes, would have come off the price of soft drinks.
—Another Labor lie exposed.

—Indeed. It goes on to say `your car and its registration will cost an extra 15 per cent tax'. For heaven's sake! Martin Ferguson, the President of the ACTU, came to Broken Hill in my electorate for a couple of days and spread a lot of untruths around. He was reported on the front page of the Barrier Daily Truth as saying numerous things.
—Did he tell the truth?
—I do not believe he did. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Coalition is also talking about ripping up Medicare, proposing that people will pay a $32 up-front fee after a visit to the doctor.
We never said that at all. In fact, we believed that consultations would come down after the removal of taxes that doctors had to pay on their computers, furniture and so on. He went on to say:
Every worker would be forced to take out private health insurance, at an added cost of about $20 per week (for a family).
He warned that `a Coalition government would mean an end to redundancy payments '—which is something to do with the State Government. He said:
There would be no payments of accumulated sick leave or pro-rata long service leave.

And so he went on, preying on the fears of pensioners in Broken Hill and the 500 people who had just been so tragically sacked. I think that is not only despicable but also ironic. Pasminco lost $9 million last year on its Broken Hill operation and $6 million of that came out in payroll tax and another $3 million in the sales tax, fuel tax and freight tax that it paid. In other words, if a GST had come in, Pasminco would have lost nothing and would not have had to sack 500 workers. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Griffiths) said that beer would go up by nine per cent. He said:
Net of all deductions, the price of beer at a bar in a hotel (will be) an extra nine per cent, after taking into account all of the alleged fightback tax reductions.

The calculations clearly show that the price of the average middy would go up about 5c, which again, ironically, is about the amount that the price of a middy went up during the election campaign due to other factors. We would have taken the automatic indexation away after that. I have a letter from the Australian Workers Union which it sent to every union member in my electorate. It said:
Dr Hewson also wants to dismantle Medicare, forcing many people into paying for expensive private health insurance.
It goes on to say—and this is the daddy of them all:
In addition, Dr Hewson will impose a 15% Consumption Tax (GST) on . . . petrol.

I suppose, in a sense, that is right. We were going to put a 15 per cent GST on petrol which would have added 7c per litre to the price of petrol. But there is no mention of the 26c per litre which would have come off and would have meant cheaper petrol for the members of the Australian Workers Union. It would have helped those people driving from shearers shed to shearers shed because petrol would have come down by 19c per litre. Actually, because they were in business, the price of petrol would probably have come down by 26c per litre. John Della Bosca, in his pamphlet, said:
Mr Hewson would make private health insurance virtually compulsory.

He added that the losers in this would be the elderly. Medicare would have been left exactly as it was for the pensioners, bulk-billing would have stayed and, on top of that, we would have given $800 per couple towards taking out private health insurance plus a whole host of other benefits which I do not have time to mention. In a letter to its members in my electorate, the Metals and Engineering Workers Union said:
The Liberals would break up the Medicare System . . . a worker can be bankrupted if they are not insured . . .

Medicare would have stayed exactly as it was, apart from bulk-billing, and when people got the doctor's bill they could have taken it to Medicare as they do now with most doctors, received their rebate and paid the doctor with that. It also said:
Almost every purchase you would make will be 15% dearer.
Of course, not one purchase would be 15 per cent dearer because every item has some sort of tax built into it. In its letter the union also endorsed the local Labor Party candidate.

PARA.TAB: The Dubbo City Council workers—all 500 of them—were addressed by union officials and told that their accumulated sick leave would be retrospectively abolished. A council worker who used to vote for me rang me up and said that he would not vote for me this time because of that. I told him that it was a State matter—it had nothing to do with us—and that we were not abolishing it. He was horrified, but the damage was done—another lie was told.

I have another letter here authorised by Derek Cafferty, Secretary of the CFMEU, which states that houses will be unaffordable if the coalition is elected because 15 per cent will go on to the price of clay, and then on to the price of bricks, and then will be added again to the price of the contractor who buys the bricks, and then the bricklayer who lays the bricks. It goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . 15 per cent GST is added to the price when the builder sells you the house.

For goodness sake, the total construction industry was exempt from GST under a rebate system. The CFMEU knew that; it was just another blatant lie. In other glossy literature—so it was not top of the head stuff, it was contemplated—it also said:
The Liberal Party will abolish compulsory employer superannuation payments . . . the superannuation you get now will be gone.
We were retaining superannuation exactly as it was. Then it said:
. . . the Liberal Party will do a backflip on unemployment benefits as soon as it is elected—cutting benefits and forcing people to wait up to six months before they can claim.
The Opposition was doing no such thing; in fact, we were adding six per cent to unemployment benefits. In another glossy brochure the CFMEU said:
The goods and services tax will increase education costs by 15 per cent.

That is another lie. Education was going to be zero rated and, if anything, would have come down in cost. In an article put up in every office in my electorate where his union members work, Joe de Bruyn, the National Secretary of the Shop Distributive Association, said that the $3 an hour for young workers was a slave wage and that all 20-year-olds would suffer a wage cut of $205.90 a week. Leaving aside the fact that he supports a party which has delivered 35 per cent youth unemployment, he implies that all youth wages will be cut to between $3 and $3.50 an hour. This was the absolute minimum for those who were out of work and we believed that at least 100,000 of those people could have got new jobs.

PARA.TAB: If he thought that $3 was a slave wage, how does he defend—because he is a supporter of the ACTU—that the gas industry minimum award wage for a 15-year-old is now $2.78 an hour, after tax, for a 38-hour week. The minimum under the metal trades award is now $2.90 an hour and under the vehicle industry award it is now $3 an hour. The under 18-year-old, staying at home on the dole, is on $1.68 an hour and even the 20-year-old at home on the dole gets $2.03 an hour. As part of our policy at that time we were not only going to pay that, but we were going to give them free off-the-job training for two days per week for two years and allow them to retain all their social security concessions as well.

The March edition of the Metal Worker, which is published by the Automotive, Metals and Engineering Union, is interesting. It is full of glossy propaganda. It talks about the GST being charged on rents and mortgages and car registration and insurance. Again, they are absolutely deliberate lies, and that union knows it. The colour centrefold states:

SPEECH.PARA: This is an AMEU poster—please place on your notice board.
It is headed:
Hewson: Ripping the guts out of Australia.
The doctor is INsane.

It has the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), I presume, with knives chopping the intestines out of a patient; they are spilling out everywhere. The intestines are labelled `penalty rates', `hours of work',` public services', `awards', `education', et cetera.

PARA.TAB: This is what the trade union movement has been reduced to in its desperation to have the Labor Party returned. Just before I came into the chamber I heard that Bob Hogg had authorised a letter to go to pensioners in one marginal electorate saying that the eight per cent compensation for the two per cent that the GST was going to cost them was only going to apply for one year.

The election is over and the Labor Party has won; I acknowledge that. But since then the lies seem to have gone on. We have had the industrial relations backflip. The Prime Minister read out an almost word perfect document of the coalition's policy on industrial relations before Bill Kelty rang him up and got him to slip in a bit saying that the trade unions would still have their power. The Government has jettisoned the promise to establish a department of regional development, which was in its February launch. That is the second of the 153 promises made by the Prime Minister that has been broken.

The first one, of course, was the promise that he made that all age and service pensioners would be exempt from the tax system by 1995. When he was queried in the week after the election as to why he had broken that promise, he said, `Oh, that was something that was made quite some time ago; it wasn't brought up during the election campaign'. Well, it was in the papers that he handed out at his February launch. But he denied it. He said, `Nobody was using it. No Ministers were saying that'. I have here a brochure handed out by a very senior Minister in the Federal Government in the election campaign. It is headed:

SPEECH.PARA: Labor pledges new benefits for senior citizens.
Under the heading `Tax', it states:
Remove all age and service pensioners from Tax System by 1995
Further down it states:
Printed and authorised by Simon Crean 6 Atherton Road Oakleigh 3166.

So there is another Labor lie. This seems to be par for the course. I guess it is something we are going to have to get used to over the next three years. The Prime Minister seems to have set a new standard which I think will not only disappoint Australian people, but will divide Australia, particularly when the Prime Minister shows his prejudices on this monarchy-republican debate. When that is combined with the promises he has made in the past and the promises he is going to break in the future, I think we are going to have a pretty grim three years ahead. The Labor Party probably can take no joy at all from the way in which it has won the election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Speaker. At the outset, it is my pleasure to congratulate you on your appointment as Speaker of the Parliament. I know that you will do a wonderful job, and from our association over the last few years I know you bring to that high office the qualities of integrity and fair judgment that the position requires.

PARA.TAB: As this is the first occasion on which I have spoken in this Parliament, I would also like to take the opportunity to extend my congratulations to the Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees He is a person who is well regarded in the chamber and I think that the comments that were made on his election to that position a day or two ago stand testimony to his record in this place. I would also like to make some comment on the record about what I think has been seen quite rightly as a very high standard of contribution over the last couple of days by those members making their first speeches. I think all members would agree that those new members of the Parliament on both sides have contributed very significantly to the debates.

I would also take this opportunity to record my sadness that some of our colleagues from the previous Parliament, the 36th Parliament, are not with us here today. I wish to mention just a couple of them, the first being the former member for Stirling, Ron Edwards, who was one of the true gentlemen and human beings of this place. It is a loss to this Parliament that we no longer have Ron Edwards amongst us. I must say that as a Queenslander, I am particularly sad that Brian Courtice, the former member for Hinkler, and Rob Hulls, the former member for Kennedy, are not here. I will miss those occasions late in the evening when there seemed to be a spontaneous eruption of Queensland members in this House, usually on industrial relations debates. Queensland members, of course, have had to deal with some of the most draconian industrial legislation this country has seen in some 60 or 70 years. Regrettably, that record is now being matched by conservative governments in other States.

Over the last couple of days the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and members of the Opposition have continued to demonstrate that they have learnt very little from the decisions which the Australian people took in the election earlier this year. The Leader of the Opposition's speech on the opening of the Parliament and his comments on the appointment of the office-bearers in this place again demonstrated that he was the wrong person in the wrong place at the wrong time. The Leader of the Opposition seemed like a person about to embark on a campaign out in the electorate, rather than somebody reflecting on the decisions which the Australian people took.

Considering the decisions the Australian people took, what comes to mind first and foremost is the goods and services tax, although in many respects it was overrated. The goods and services tax was a regressive proposal designed with the inevitable outcome of injuring ordinary Australians, providing a benefit to those who are already better off, and it was seen by the Australian electorate in that way. Many people whom I spoke to during the campaign and in the year or so before were openly concerned about how they would make ends meet week to week if those things which they bought on a regular basis were subjected to an additional tax.

A lot of people at the outset understood that there would be some tax on the things they bought at the supermarket. But as it became clearer to Australians that it was not just the goods that were purchased on a regular basis but also the services that they used on a regular basis that would be affected by a goods and services tax, more and more Australians decided they would be worse off if the Liberal Party won the 1993 election.

But it was not without warning. There are enough people on the other side of the House who were told time and time again in this chamber and outside that the goods and services tax was both wrong and unpopular. It is interesting to see how many of yesterday's advocates are today's critics of the goods and services tax.

The way in which the Liberal and National parties have gone about their internal navel contemplation since their defeat does them little credit. It does the National Party in particular little credit, because, of all the interest groups represented by those opposite, the National Party stood to lose the greatest yet it tagged along with the Liberal Party policy for a goods and services tax and it paid the price.

Medicare was one of the issues which seldom rated front-page billing but which, in the minds of average Australians, weighed heavily. One of the points which seemed to have been lost on the Opposition prior to the election and, it would appear, after the election is that the Australian people place enormous weight on ensuring that their health and their children's health can be properly cared for.

In this country we have one of the best health systems available in the world—a health system which is being looked at by Canadian authorities, the new American Administration and the New Zealand conservative Government as a model from which they want to learn—yet the Opposition went to the people of Australia with a proposal to disband Medicare as we know it today and, as with its industrial relations policy, attempted to camouflage that by saying Medicare would be kept.

The people, though, knew that Medicare was not just the name; it was the service they relied on—the opportunity to know that if their children were ill they could go to a doctor without concern for meeting the bill. One of the things that seemed to elude the Leader of the Opposition and his shadow health spokesperson, the former honourable member for Lowe, Dr Bob Woods, when they discussed these things was that, if a person has a family and someone gets sick and that person has to pay up front, the Opposition's policy assumed that person paid for a single service.

With three young children myself and winter approaching, I know that when one of the kids gets the flu they all get it. We do not make one trip to the doctor; we make three. And that is three the first time around, hoping that the medication fixes the problem. Chances are a family probably ends up making somewhere between four and six visits to the doctor for three children with the common cold going through the house once.

So when the Opposition was talking about people paying up front and getting something back, albeit a reduced Medicare refund, the people out there in their homes, the people with children, the ordinary Australian families, knew that they would not have to make one up-front payment but half a dozen payments in the space of a fortnight. That is an impost the average Australian could ill afford to meet.

One of the things which a number of people said to me after the election that made the difference in their mind in that last week was neither the GST nor Medicare; it was industrial relations. Ordinary Australian working men and women were concerned that under a Hewson-Howard program they would be stripped of any rights in the workplace; denied the opportunity of award safety nets; denied the opportunity of union representation; and denied the opportunity of representation in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Each and every one of those things was in the Opposition's platform.

If the Opposition stands condemned for anything in that last election campaign, it stands condemned for its deceit for the way in which it portrayed its industrial relations policy. At first I was surprised and then just totally disenchanted with the way in which the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) carried the argument in this place prior to the last election and then publicly, claiming that people would still have the option of being in a union and going to the industrial commission when he at least and most Opposition members understood that they were denying the right of Australian workers to be in a union and have a union represent them.

The Opposition's legislation would have ensured that only individuals were eligible to sign employment contracts. Unions would have been forbidden, as they are under the legislation of the Victorian Liberal Party. Moreover, there would have been no recourse to an industrial commission. Workers would have had the opportunity to go to an industrial commission to settle a dispute only if the employer agreed. We do not have to know a great deal about industrial relations to realise that in the heat of an industrial dispute the average employer is not about to say, `Sure, let's go down to the commission and I'll accept what he says'. That is not the way in which those disputes are settled now. It is not the way in which they would have been settled under the Opposition's policy, and the Opposition knows that only too well.

Earlier an Opposition member spoke about scare campaigns and deceitful campaigning. If we are to be objective about it, we could all point to the odd bit of propaganda from every political party represented in this place, and a lot of the political parties that are not represented in this place, which would fail the test of the whole truth and nothing but the truth. But Opposition members should have a pretty careful look at themselves before deciding to throw too many stones in this debate, particularly on key issues like industrial relations, as occurred a few moments ago.

Prior to its election to government, the Kennett Liberal Party put out a brochure on industrial relations. It was entitled, `Your Employment Rights'. It was authorised by the Liberal Party's head office in Melbourne. Under a heading, `The real truth about your job', it states:

SPEECH.PARA: no person in employment will suffer any loss of award wages or conditions.

This is the same Jeff Kennett who, days after winning an election, produced legislation to do precisely the opposite—to ensure that all awards in fact were abolished in Victoria. Yet weeks before the Liberal Party was putting out propaganda saying:
no person in employment will suffer any loss of award wages or conditions.

When Kennett was producing and distributing that material he had in his possession the draft legislation to abolish every award in the Victorian jurisdiction. It is the height of hypocrisy for any honourable member on the opposition benches to hop up and talk about the truthfulness of campaign literature, particularly in relation to industrial relations. When the deceit which Kennett perpetrated on the people of Victoria last year is coupled with the deceit which those opposite peddled in their industrial relations policy at the last election, members of the Liberal and National parties in this place would be well advised to leave that issue alone.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, I want to mention quickly some of those programs which the Labor Government will be continuing in this the 37th Parliament. On a number of occasions, and in the opening of Parliament in the Governor-General's address, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made clear the Government's commitment to increasing employment as the focus of our activity. To that end for the last two years and into the next two years the Government has been committed to stimulating the economy through an injection of money in the Budget.

That stands in stark contrast to the sorts of policies that the Opposition took to the people of Australia and which were rejected. In the last Budget discussions the Opposition proposed a reduction in outlays of some $7,000 million. That goes not just to Medicare and some of the other items to which I have referred, but it goes to the very fabric of Australian society and the basis upon which social security benefits, pensions and education and health entitlements are all based. The proposal that the Leader of the Opposition took to the people a few months ago was for a $7,000 million cut this financial year.

I have yet to see the Opposition's revamped economic platform and I will be looking forward to the Budget session in a couple of months time when presumably the Opposition's new views as to how the Australian economy should be run will be unveiled.

The Government will continue its ongoing program of workplace reform; a program which has seen the most dramatic improvement in productivity in Australia's manufacturing sector that this country has ever witnessed. I might say that this increase in productivity in many industries now places us on a par with our European trading partners and in some cases our Asian trading partners.

This workplace reform process has seen our port handling facilities improve to the stage where the number of containers shifted per hour in ports such as Melbourne is better than the OECD average. The number of containers shifted per hour is now about twice what it was three or four years ago. In the merchant navy the number of sailors crewing ships with the same tonnage has been reduced by about half.

Those sorts of micro-economic and workplace reform changes have occurred with this Government working in partnership with the relevant unions, employers and the ACTU. They have occurred without a day's dispute. Today there are half the number of wharfies in this country that there were five years ago. Those wharfies are doing 100 per cent more work. That has occurred without the loss of a day's work. Yet the Opposition went to the people of Australia with a policy which said, `We want to reject this program of consultation and bipartisanship. We want to reintroduce the sort of confrontation and division which wreaked so much havoc on the Australian population and economy throughout the 1960s and 1970s'.

Not only has the Opposition learnt little from the events of earlier this year during the federal election, but also it would appear that it has learnt little from the events of the last three decades in respect of industrial relations and how one goes about getting cooperative reform for the benefit of all Australians.

There are a couple of other areas of policy that I quickly want to mention. I was pleased to note the comments in the Governor-General's address concerning arts policy and the Government's ongoing commitment to foster Australian arts. The arts are an important part of our national heritage and culture. In many respects they provide the outward public face of the different aspects of Australian society. The Government is to be commended for its commitment to the theatre and the arts and for ensuring that all Australians have a greater opportunity to participate in and enjoy the very skilled performances that Australian artists are able to provide. This Government will be judged very favourably over the years to come by its contribution to the arts community.

I also want to make some comment about the announcement in the Governor-General's address of the Government's intention to look at appointments to the judiciary with a view to making those appointments more representative of Australian society. That is a long overdue reform and I was pleased to hear the comments made by my good friend the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) on those matters today in Question Time. Today's Melbourne Age carries a front-page article which says:

SPEECH.PARA: A County Court judge has joined the debate over the law's treatment of rape victims, saying that in his legal experience, when women say no to sex, `no often subsequently means yes'.

When important people in the judiciary go on the record in a considered way and say that when people say no as a matter of law they really mean yes, and that that can be justification for an offence such as rape, is mind-boggling to me. For any member to stand in this place and say that there is no need for the Government—which I accept has final responsibility for these matters—to look at the issues behind such decisions and statements would be folly. I welcome the Government's initiative in that area and commend the Attorney-General for his willingness to address it. In the end it will be something that the Australian people will be well served by.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I want to thank that team of people in the Brisbane electorate who worked so hard for so long to ensure that Brisbane remained an important part of a Labor government. I was very fortunate to have a large and dedicated team. I want to place on record my thanks to them and to my campaign director, Liam McKay, in particular. Most importantly, I wish to thank my wife, Cathy, and family, without whose support I would not be here and who give up so much in order that I may contribute in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in commencing may I formally congratulate you on your election to the high office of Speaker and look forward to the parliamentary sittings during the life of this Parliament as you demonstrate your stewardship of this important chamber.

PARA.TAB: This has been an interesting day for honourable members who have had the opportunity to hear the maiden speeches of many of our new colleagues. In particular, I have been very happy to hear the first of many speeches by the new Liberal member for Stirling (Mr Cameron). In the very near future his speech will be joined by one from the new member for Cowan (Mr Evans).

My pleasure in being joined by the two new additions to our talented coalition team is enhanced by the realisation that we Liberals now dominate the political landscape of the north metropolitan corridor of Perth. It is particularly satisfying because when I started in public life in the north metropolitan area it was often hard to find a Liberal MP at public functions. In what I consider to have been those dark days, my State colleague the Hon. Jim Clarko, who is the member for Marmion in the Legislative Assembly of the Western Australian Parliament, was the most northerly Liberal presence in Perth. Now, with the addition of the honourable member for Stirling and the honourable member for Cowan respectively, and with the new State Liberal members for Wanneroo and Whitford in the State Parliament, we can provide the type of representation that reflects the great pressures of modern life in the mortgage belt area of Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sadly lacking before.

—Yes, and sadly lacking before. A few moments ago I mentioned my friend Jim Clarko. Jim is the new Speaker elect of the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia and I congratulate him also on achieving that high office. I am sure that he will provide the sort of unbiased chairmanship in the chamber of the Legislative Assembly of the Western Australian Parliament that has been missed in the House of Representatives in the past.

PARA.TAB: He will certainly be a very welcome change from Mr Barnett, the Speaker who will hold that office until the election for the new Speaker is held and who was the Speaker during those terrible days when Western Australia was under the administration of the Burke, Dowding and Lawrence governments—those terrible days of corrupt behaviour, mismanagement and economic sabotage that we heard so much about during the hearings of the WA Inc. royal commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit like the Cain Government
—It is very much like the Cain Government. I would like to congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on being elected to the high office of Deputy Speaker.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the real message from the northern suburbs in the recent federal election—and the State election, for that matter—was that Western Australia overwhelmingly rejects the disastrous State and Federal Labor governments. The message from the community in Western Australia was quite clear. In Western Australia we saw a two-party preferred vote of just under 54 per cent for the coalition—an overwhelming no vote for the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), for the Prime Minister's republican push and for the terrible damage wreaked on the economy by the Hawke and Keating administrations. In fact, around Western Australia today it is almost impossible to find anybody who will admit to having voted for the Labor Party. One just cannot find anybody. In fact, some people whom we suspect of having voted for the Labor Party look very sheepish and move away without really answering the question.

In my electorate a friend of mine, a businessman, put up a sign outside his business saying, `I voted Liberal; it must have been you!', because there are many people in Western Australia who just cannot understand how the Keating Government was re-elected. One can well understand the sentiments expressed by Western Australians in that context when we consider that 54 per cent of Western Australians voted for a Hewson coalition government.

The two Government members, the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Dr Theophanous), who are at the table, may well laugh, but if they were Western Australian Labor Party members, they would not be laughing; they would probably be working assidulously to stop themselves from being thrown out at the next opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —They must belong to the New South Wales Right.

—And the Victorian Left. If honourable members look at the booth by booth results in my electorate, they will see that the trend to the Liberal Party has become consistent and moved upwards over the past three Federal elections. This is in an area where we have seen phenomenal urban growth and where we will probably see the demographic mean for the Australian community. It is pleasing to see that the average Australian family—raising children, with a mortgage and struggling under all the pressures that the recession has brought on—absolutely rejected Labor and preferred instead, and still prefers, the vision and the opportunities presented through the principles and philosophies on which our party's policies are based.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to acknowledge those who have contributed to the excellent result we achieved in the Federal seat of Moore. I thank my campaign chairman, Mike Hill; the chairman of our finance committee, Frank Merry; our secretary, Bob Hales; and our treasurer and agent, Greg Ahern. Jason Raftos ensured our polling booth manning and presentation was second to none, and he was ably supported by Ben Grant.

I also thank the campaign workers and supporters who came out to give us such a terrific result in Moore. In particular, I would like to acknowledge Mick Nanovich, who was a popular and conscientious State member for the area during his career in the State Parliament. Glad York and Pat Court, Pam Grant, John and Dorothy King, Albert and Margaret Presland, Pat Healy, and Geoff and Dorothy Lobban all helped organise successful functions at their homes or at local halls to support our campaign effort. This is the grassroots type of political activity which ensures close and responsive representation on the part of its member. I salute the people who have come out time and time again to support the party, making the Liberal Party the only truly broadly representative party in Australian public affairs.

The area I represent is one steeped in history. It is at the furthest reaches of the urban spread. In my maiden speech back in 1990 I talked of the tongues of bitumen licking into the bushland as development pressed ahead. But from that point to now I little envisaged the incredible changes that have occurred in the area during that period.

In the city of Wanneroo, the largest municipality in my electorate, we are seeing growth at the rate of 9,000 people a year. The new city of Joondalup is starting to become a more discernible metropolis. Shops, offices, workshops, public amenities and the new sports facilities are all taking shape as the city becomes the focal point for the region. But at the same time it is important to recognise the tremendous background of the other focal point of the region—the Wanneroo town site. I have been very interested in the traditions of hardship and struggle on the part of the families that pioneered the area.

I was recently able to wish Santo Crisafulli a happy 80th birthday. He is one of the area's best known growers and part of a family that has contributed greatly to the fortunes of Wanneroo. With his brothers, Ned and John, Tony Martin, Bill Stevens and his family, the Conti family and many others, he has provided the colour and character of an area that is no longer a waterbag and cut lunch away from the Perth city area but is now part of the urban sprawl and a lot closer to the activities of Perth.

But it is an area that has been sadly neglected by the Federal Labor Government, particularly in the last Federal Budget. From the local capital works program it got absolutely zilch in the way of funding, which was in stark contrast to the next city, the city of Stirling, the largest proportion of which was of course in the area of the Federal seat of Stirling, one of the most marginal Labor seats. The then sitting Labor member, who was on a knife-edge margin, was able to relay the news that the city of Stirling received over $7 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't do him much good.

—It did not do him much good; I was going to come to that in a second. Both Stirling and Wanneroo have similar unemployment levels, and the bizarre method of distribution unfortunately smacked very heavily of pork-barrelling.

PARA.TAB: The city of Wanneroo is the fourth largest in population and has the second fastest growth rate in Australia. Our unemployment rate is a terrible 9.7 per cent, thanks to the havoc wreaked on the economy by the Keating Government. In fact, during the allocations of the local capital works program, we had the ludicrous situation where the town of Peppermint Grove, the wealthiest part of the Perth metropolitan area, received $75,000 to help its 75 unemployed people, yet Wanneroo with its huge unemployment rate received absolutely nothing.

Wanneroo's unemployment rate is considerably worse than that of the cities of Melville and Canning, which received $1.7 million and $1.6 million respectively. The basic inequity of these allocations in the case of the city of Wanneroo leads one to believe that the Government was nothing more than pork-barrelling on a grand scale. The pork-barrelling had, as the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) correctly observed, little effect on the electors who rejected the Federal Labor member for Stirling and, in the other area occupied by Stirling, the Labor member for Cowan.

The local people in my electorate realise that they have been short-changed in the Federal Budget by a government more intent on helping out its marginal seat candidates rather than properly planning its capital works expenditure to the areas where this is most in demand and most needed. A number of projects could have benefited from a fair application of the allocation. For example, the Quinns Rock senior citizens and community facilities are in dire need, in an area that is seeing the construction of one house being completed a day. It is an area of tremendous growth to the extent that we have to get bureaucrats from both the State and Federal governments to actually come up and have a look at it because they cannot believe the enormous growth that is happening in the northern suburbs of Perth, the second fastest growing area in the country after the Albert shire.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my electorate.

—In the electorate of the honourable member for Fadden. The Joondalup-Connolly-Iluka Community Hall and Youth Centre is another facility in dire need in the area—another area of enormous growth; a mushrooming area. We need toilets and change rooms at Whitford Beach. I have been a user of Whitford Beach for years and years. It is one of the most popular spots on the northern coastline, yet we still do not have those sorts of facilities.

PARA.TAB: The conservation of Lilburne Park in Duncraig, the foreshore management of Mullaloo, Hillarys and Whitford beaches and the construction of coastal paths and gateways are all badly required facilities in an area that is growing at the rate of a medium sized country town each year.

It is timely to remind honourable members of the important work conducted by local government councillors on behalf of their ratepayers, in that important third tier of our government system. As such, I would like to congratulate those elected at the recent city of Wanneroo and city of Stirling elections. In the city of Wanneroo councillors Rita Waters, Ewen-Chappell, Cooper, Maloney, MacLean, Wood, Rundle, Freame and Curtis are all to be congratulated for achieving election at the recent elections; and in the case of the city of Stirling councillors Carter, Rose, Scott, Maio, Willox, Spagnolo, Camilleri and Burkett.

The work of local government councillors—often unsung, performed at considerable personal sacrifice in money and time—deserves our recognition. I would like to thank the councillors in my local municipalities for their cooperation and for the tremendous dedication and efforts they make on behalf of the community.

Part of the development plans for the Joondalup city is the Joondalup sports complex. The West Perth Football Club will relocate to these premises in 1994. This will be a big plus with the residents of the city, who will have the opportunity to watch first class Western Australian football within their area. The move is an historic one and will require a huge investment on the part of the Western Australian Land Authority, Landcorp, and the West Perth Football Club.

Unfortunately, the club's application in 1992 for a grant under the community, cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program was unsuccessful. This was a blow to the aspirations of those responsible for this far-sighted project. The relocation of the West Perth Football Club from Leederville oval to Joondalup is a major step in the redevelopment of Australian rules football in Western Australia. The relocation will bring the club's headquarters to the geographic centre of the young and enthusiastic player and follower base.

The club has currently 66 junior teams within the district boundaries and will continue to progress the game through the junior development program. The complex will also become home to the Wanneroo Wolves ladies and men's basketball teams, which play in the State league, and the Wanneroo Basketball Association, which is very active in our region. I hope that, in the future, the sports Minister may look a little more kindly on the project, one which may well lead to the siting of the proposed second AFL team at Joondalup. To an area that is growing in such a fast way the full range of facilities found in older municipalities is something that we aspire to. With a large concentration of young families with children in my electorate this places additional demands on the very heavily used resources and I intend to pursue this matter until it is successfully concluded.

In this compendium speech about the Moore electorate I would like to discuss also the question of Telecom charges in the town sites of Yanchep and Two Rocks. The people in the northernmost pocket of the electorate are victims of a 10-year old zonal structure which sees them paying STD rates for calls to the central business district, although the growth in these suburbs has been absolutely prolific in the last ten years. It is absolutely ludicrous in this day and age that people who reside in what is effectively a suburb in the metropolitan area of Perth should be forced to pay STD charges for calls outside of their area. I will continue to lobby for the abolition of time charging in the area as development in the second fastest growing region in Australia continues.

I would also like to reflect briefly on the issue of Hepburn Heights. It is a local environmental matter. The State Labor governments of Dowding and Carmen Lawrence vandalised one of the last remaining stands of natural bushland in the northern suburban area, an area about which we, the Liberal Party, gave an absolute commitment to preserve. I am very pleased to say that the incoming Court Liberal coalition Government abided by that commitment. Although parts had already been developed in a rush by the outgoing Labor Government, it was able to stop the development at a reasonable level and still preserve important stands that I believe will be preserved in the interests of the local community.

We also have in the area very active recycling and environmental community groups. We have, I am very happy to say, the Glengarry primary school video project on recycling that was undertaken in the first instance by Robin Bigwood, the environmental teacher at the school. It has now achieved some national prominence, thanks to the promotional efforts of Robin and other teachers at the school and, of course, the parents and the children who also go there.

In the few remaining minutes, I want to refer to one particular event of today. I acknowledge the fact that the Parliamentary Secretary, the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous), also has a strong interest in the particular issue I wish to refer to; that is, the terribly disappointing news this evening that the Bosnian Serb Parliament, in Pale, has rejected the Vance-Owen peace plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina and has referred the matter to a referendum. At a time when we can see some of the worst fighting and most bitter bloodshed ever seen on the European mainland since the Second World War—bloodshed that I have personally witnessed in visits to Croatia and also to Sarajevo in September last year—the opportunity for creating a peaceful solution was seen to be something of optimism. Now, unfortunately we are faced with the prospect that the rest of the world will have to enforce peace through the use of force. That is something that none of us particularly aspire to or would particularly like to see but I think that under the circumstances of what has occurred today it is now almost inevitable.

A situation, which I think could have been more easily solved some time ago with a little more willpower on the part of the European Community and the United Nations, has now progressed to the point where we are going to see a lot more bloodshed, a lot more bitter fighting, a lot more dislocation, many more families split up and their homes destroyed as a result of what is effectively a very short-sighted decision by the members of that Parliament. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous The Hon A.C.

TALKER.NAME: Dr THEOPHANOUS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me also second the comments of the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) in relation to the terrible tragedy of Bosnia-Herzegovina. As someone who has been involved and concerned about this matter, I also am very disappointed by the news from the so-called Bosnian Serbian Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I hope that it will be forced to reconsider its position in the next few hours because time has certainly run out and the international community's patience has also run out in relation to this disaster. Let me also second his comments that the whole tragedy could have been avoided with better diplomacy. When I came back from my visit to Sarajevo, in December 1991, and issued a statement in Zagreb, Croatia, and in Australia warning of a bloodbath of this kind, a lot of people thought that was alarmist. The situation turned out to be even worse than I had envisaged in that statement. So I hope that we will be able to play our role constructively as a nation in supporting what needs to be done in order to stop the fighting, and hopefully achieve a just and peaceful solution.

I want to address my comments tonight to the whole general program of the Government and, naturally, to the Governor-General's speech, which outlined that program. Before doing so, I want to make some comments about the speech on the Address-in-Reply made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) earlier today. I was sitting at the table when the Leader of the Opposition made his comments. I must say that I was extremely disappointed. Here is a man who has just lost the federal election. The people of Australia have rejected him and his parties. He appears to have learnt nothing from that rejection, to have no humility about the fact that he was rejected. He ought to try to learn something from that exercise. Indeed, all he did for 20 minutes was make totally negative comments about the Government and, what is worse, about the country—we are in a doom and gloom situation; we are going to have a dreadful economic situation—the same stuff which we heard prior to the election.

Voters might have forgiven statements like that—statements running down the nation—prior to the election, regarding it as electioneering, but the election is over. There are three years of government to go. A responsible leader of the opposition ought to be saying positive things about the country, encouraging economic growth and investment, and encouraging people to put their faith in Australia. Anyone listening to that speech this morning would not have heard any of that.

It is completely wrong to approach the matter in that way. The Leader of the Opposition's whole analysis of the situation is wrong. He had the impertinence to suggest that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has no program, the Government has no program, no philosophy. He said that the Opposition offered something to the Australian people while the Government did not. In fact, the opposite is the case.

What the Opposition offered the Australian people was an intellectually unsupportable hotchpotch of policies which was eventually exposed for what it was. It was even exposed by the media, but that was only after the election, not before it. Most of the media did not pick up the problems and contradictions before the election but did so after the election. The reality is that the program was not supportable. The Australian people recognised that it was not supportable and did not support it. Yet we had the Leader of the Opposition getting up in this chamber today, making the same negative attacks on the Government without even thinking about the possibility of saying something constructive and positive about the nation, its problems and the way to go forward.

To refute what the Leader of the Opposition has said, I intend to say some things about the Government's philosophy and what it hopes to achieve in the next three years, as far as I understand it. I start by referring to what the Prime Minister said in his so-called True Believers speech, which was given one wonderful evening here in Canberra when so many people who supported the Labor Party came to celebrate.
