The Prime Minister said a number of things that evening, but I want to quote these particular words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think that, given the fact that we have been able to put these great building blocks of social and economic progress into place over the last 10 years, we truly have the option of being one of the great social democratic parties of the world.

PARA.TAB: I don't think that is an idle claim or an idle objective. I think that is something we can actually do because I don't think any government has, over such a prolonged period of time, so carefully threaded and weaved a social policy as this—

SPEECH.PARA: this party—

has changed Australia, but changed it co-operatively and together, put the two pieces together—economic policy and social policy—which gives us I think an option and the opportunity, the chance of truly becoming one of the great social democratic parties and for the great purpose of establishing a great Australian social democracy. Because it is that Australian social democracy I believe Australians voted for the other day; it is that Australian social democracy where Australians not only understand the values they should attach to themselves, but understand the identity that those values should have; the fact that this country will now be a country made in its own image where its identity is as clear as day and where the things we stand for will be universally accepted.

That does not sound like the words of a man who has no vision or no idea where things are going. On the contrary, the Prime Minister does have a philosophical approach, a clear conceptual approach, an approach which unites and gives force to the Government in relation to the whole gamut of policies. The social democratic philosophy of the Government is important because, as the Prime Minister said, the Australian Labor Party is one of the few social democratic parties in the world to have sustained itself in government for such a long time, with a coherent and evolving philosophy of which it can be proud, not only in Australia but also around the world where it serves as a model for other social democratic parties. There is no doubt that this has happened already. Inquiries have been made of the Australian Labor Party about the general thrust of its policy, the approach it has taken and the way in which it has been able to galvanise the nation.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of elements to this general social democratic philosophy, some of which were outlined in the Governor-General's speech. I will elaborate on some of them. Economic growth was one of the main features and is extremely important. It is fundamental not only to the creation of jobs but also to the creation of wealth. Economic growth means that a whole range of services can be provided to the Australian people. What have we heard from the Opposition about economic growth? We have heard that it is not going to occur. When the statistics say that it is occurring, we hear, `It's not occurring'. Members of the Opposition were saying that even after the election. We can understand why they might say that before the election: they did not want to make a political point of the fact that there was economic growth. But the same thing is being said after the election, in the face of statistics that show that Australia is achieving economic growth.

I admit that economic growth is not as great as we would like it to be. Who would not like more economic growth? We would all like more economic growth in order to get out of the recession more quickly. But the reality is that economic growth in modern circumstances, for a nation such as Australia, is not easy to achieve. I am talking about economic growth that makes sense. I am not talking about growth with inflation; I am talking about growth without inflation—genuine growth. And in that sense—in terms of growth without inflation—Australia is moving.

There is a long way to go to get out of the recession, but we are doing well. Instead of running the nation down, we should be looking at policies which will help us achieve that economic growth. These policies include a range of complicated policies on industry development, the development of tourism, the development of the services industries, the development of a range of other industries, and the export of all those services and goods. To achieve that export orientation, we need to work at it; we need to develop incentives for export. Those complicated policies cannot be solved by being the kind of simple-minded, economic rationalist that the Leader of the Opposition and his colleagues have been for the last few years.
The former Liberal Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Fraser, said it all after the election when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Liberal Party will never be elected while it is so extreme in its policies and while it is so stuck on such an ideological agenda in relation to the economy.

The Australian people have rejected that ideological agenda. Economic growth is not a goal in itself. A central feature of it is the fact that we need it to create jobs. Can there be anything more important than the emphasis the Government has placed on creating jobs, especially for the long-term unemployed? While there has been a significant restructuring of the Australian economy, it is very important that we help the people who have lost their jobs during the restructuring process and are having difficulty finding jobs—not just for a few days, weeks or months, but for a year or more. We have to help those people.

PARA.TAB: That leads me to the next element of the strategy: the training and retraining of the work force. That is a very important aspect. In the area of training and retraining the record of the Government has been amazing with respect to the number of people that have been placed in training and retraining programs of various kinds.

There are a very large number of programs in the TAFE colleges, in the universities and in a whole range of other institutions of learning. There is on-the-job training, cooperation between the union movement and the Government in order to achieve retraining, and restructuring of the roles of the workers in their places of employment. All this has been taking place. There has been a revolution in this training area. But that does not mean that we have finished. There is much more to do in this area, as there is in the whole general area of education.

The Government is not committed to cutting the resources in this area, as would have been the case had the coalition been elected to government. On the contrary, the Government will in fact sustain, and in some areas increase, the resources in this area. Had the coalition been elected, this area of education and training would have been one of the first areas to be drastically cut, because I remind the House that the Opposition was going to cut $10 billion from the federal Budget in the middle of a recession.

What would that have done? That would have got rid of a large number of jobs immediately, as we have seen in Victoria where in six months 32,000 people have lost their jobs from the State public sector. Imagine what would have happened if the conservative forces had won the election. How many people would have lost their jobs at a federal level? We would have had not only that immediate loss of jobs but also the loss of the opportunities for those people, especially young people, to get the education and training that is required for them to really achieve a worthwhile job and a worthwhile future in this country.

The next element in the social democratic strategy and policy of the Prime Minister and the Government is the social justice strategy. I want to talk about this social justice strategy at greater length because it is an area of direct concern to my portfolio responsibilities. As the Prime Minister said in the True Believers speech, if there was one element that differentiated the conservative parties from the Labor Party in this election it was the perception of the community that there was a very big difference in values.

What was this difference? Essentially, it was that the Australian Labor Party, irrespective of economic difficulties, would look after people and continue to look after people; that it had a human face; that it was concerned to protect the poor, the disadvantaged, the people who were in a difficult situation, very often through no fault of their own; that the individual would not be thrown out to care for himself, alone, especially if that person was disadvantaged, poor or sick. In the whole gamut of policies, the Australian people perceived that the Australian Labor Party had a social justice strategy concerned with welfare and that the conservative parties did not.

Prior to the election, the Leader of the Opposition went out of his way to actually offend a number of the key welfare groups in this country, groups whose whole raison d'etre is to look after the poor and the needy. He went out of his way to offend them, and in so doing gave the impression to the Australian people that his would be a heartless government. Some might say that is an unfair description, but that is certainly the perception which the Australian community was given because of the policies that were adopted. That is not merely my own personal view; it has actually been said by a number of people, including some people closely associated with the Liberal and National parties. Belatedly, the Leader of the Opposition has recognised that this was a problem because he has now put into place a number of shadow Ministers to try to deal with some of these human areas which the Opposition totally ignored prior to the election.

The Australian Labor Party's social justice commitments go back some considerable time to the development of a social justice strategy which began from the very election of the Labor Government, and they have continued over that time. Let me read from the social justice strategy document that was put out from the office of the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) before the election. The document says:

SPEECH.PARA: Social justice is about quality of life. It is about choices and opportunities as different points in a person's life are reached. It is about entitlement to education, health care, and affordable housing; about the right of families to receive assistance and the aged to receive services; and about the right for people in crisis or facing difficult periods such as marriage breakup or unemployment or homelessness to receive special support.

As the Prime Minister has said, there can be no doubt that in the 10 years of the Labor Government it has managed to introduce a range of social justice policies while maintaining a focus on economic development and growth. There has not been a contradiction between economic development and social justice; there has been a marrying of those two approaches. Essentially, that is what social democracy is all about. The document talks about the way in which Australia is leading the world in many of these areas of social policy. I give a couple of examples. Between March 1983 and June 1992 payments targeted to low income families increased in real terms by 75 per cent for a family with children under 13 years of age, and by 147 per cent for a family with teenage children—that is, children of 13 to 15 years. Government subsidised child-care places increased from 46,000 in 1983 to 193,000 in 1992. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I congratulate you on an excellent campaign to become the Speaker of this House, and I congratulate you on being returned as a deputy speaker. In my view, the House made a serious error of judgment when it failed to elevate you to the ultimate position. I congratulate you on being returned once again to this great Parliament of the people of Australia and for your long association with your electorate and the good job that you do there.

PARA.TAB: I heard the last few minutes of the speech by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). He concentrated his remarks on what Australia would have been like had the coalition won the last federal election. I would like to right a couple of mistruths that I think I heard. The first thing I say to the honourable member for Calwell is that I do not think the Australian people rejected the coalition on the matter of social justice. I would point out to him that in my electorate of La Trobe the electors—including the elderly, the pensioners, the self-funded retirees and those who have lost their jobs and who now live by benefit of the State because they can no longer find work—returned me with an increased majority through a 70 per cent vote. It seems to me that that gives the lie to any sort of statement that we had heartless policies that would hurt the already disadvantaged. In my view, nothing could be further from the truth.

I take this opportunity to thank the electors of La Trobe. I did thank them at the declaration of the poll, but I would like to thank them in this place properly. It was with some degree of satisfaction that we increased our absolute majority and we increased our majority on preferences.

We are horribly disappointed that overall the coalition was not able to win enough seats so that we in fact could form government. I think the agenda that the Labor Party has tried to run for a number of years is not what the Government is doing but what the Opposition might do. I think that argument has got a bit old, a bit stale and a bit out of touch, I say to the honourable member for Calwell. The agenda now is on this Government and what is this Government going to do to get us out of this horrible mess that we are in.

We are here tonight to talk about the Governor-General's speech. I have the greatest respect for him, and I think that he is a fine Australian and has upheld the greatest traditions of that office in a most proper manner over the lifetime of his appointment. I have to say that it was a long and boring speech. I mean no disrespect to the Governor-General because he only parroted the words given to him by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Now we have on record this Prime Minister's agenda for this country. The honourable member for Calwell will sit to be judged for the next three years or two years or 18 months, however long it is until we go to the people for their judgment again. We, day by day, every day, will judge the Government on the record of what it says in this document.

Let those who are listening examine just exactly what it is that the Government intends to happen to Australians and for Australians over the life of this Parliament. The Prime Minister, through the Governor-General, says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government sees as its primary task the encouragement of a strong and durable recovery from recession, assistance to those who have suffered as a consequence of the recession and a search for solutions to the increasing problem of long-term unemployment.

Somewhere along the line the Prime Minister forgot to apologise to the Australian people for the devastation that he has caused to Australia's economy. It is true that the rest of the world is now in recession and we are trapped in that recession. It appears that we are unlikely in the short term to exit it. It is not true to say that our recession was caused by the rest of the world. We did a bloody good job of bringing it on all by ourselves. The man who is now Prime Minister, who was Treasurer, was the arch architect of the policies that brought that devastation to our economy.

PARA.TAB: I remind the honourable member for Calwell that today Australia is in debt to the rest of the world by some $170,000 million net of what the rest of the world owes us. That is growing now at what? Is it $2.1 billion a month? We have a real problem with our current account. The problem is that we are still buying more than we are selling. We are sucking in imports as we barely creep to come out of the recession, if in fact that is what we are doing. We are sucking in the imports and, at the same time, it costs us some $1.2 billion every month to service our existing debt, which is growing. So it snowballs.

The higher our debt grows, the further the rest of the world devalues our currency. As they devalue our currency, so rises inflation. As inflation rises, so increases the cost to Australians buying overseas goods and services, so extends the current account deficit, and so our net debt to the rest of the world continues to increase day by day, week by week, month by month, and year by year. I see nothing in the longwinded, boring speech, in this document, which was delivered so well by the Governor-General, which points to a way out of this catch-22 situation that we are in. I note in the document that the Government intends to continue with its election promise to cut company taxes. That is an interesting scenario. We are going to cut taxes for corporations, and what is the effect?

The first effect is that we will repatriate more dollars overseas in dividends for profit earned to the major companies in this country, which are the only ones making a profit. Small and medium sized businesses are not making much money. The real money is being made by major corporations, and the majority of those are owned by overseas companies, by multinationals and by conglomerates, and the profits will be expatriated. That is not going to do us much good, is it? It certainly is not going to help us increase investment in plant and equipment, the productive capacity which we so desperately need today.

The second effect is that we have gradually convinced the Australian public that participating in the share market, that mums and dads being owners of Australian business, is a good idea. What is going to happen? Imputation is going to fall, so the return on their investment will fall. The incentive for them to buy shares in the stock market will decrease and investment in productive capacity will fall.

At the same time, the Government last year passed legislation which will come into effect this coming September. In effect, it taxes pensioners for unrealised capital gains. So they are now going to lose pension entitlements because of a so-called nominal increase in share value unrealised. The effect of that will be to tell the pensioners to get out of the share market. Where are they going to put their money? I do not know where they are going to put it, but one thing is for sure, it will not add to purchasing new plant and equipment, to buy new jobs, or new investment and to attack the unemployment problem in Australia.

We really do have a problem with unemployment, which is still over 11 per cent. Our youth still have this terrible problem of either finding places in universities or TAFE or finding a job when they exit year 12—and increasing numbers of them are staying on at school until year 12, and some now are going back for year 13, because what else are they going to do? Increasingly, we are finding graduates from universities unable to fulfil their destiny, unable to utilise their qualifications, with their hopes and aspirations dashed by an economy that is as flat as the proverbial pancake.

We have a lot of schemes to help retrain people and to relieve the unemployment problem. There are more or less, plus or minus, 150 employment schemes today to try to help those who are unemployed. There are so many and it is so confusing that even the personnel in CES are confused about where to place an individual, or on what program, and I should think so. It is a terrible confusion, and no-one really knows which programs are working, which are not working, and whether our taxpayers' money is being used to proper effect. I have to say that it is not just taxpayers' money because we now are really borrowing money to run the Federal Treasury. What will the deficit be this year? Will it be $16 billion or $17 billion? It will not be as low as $15 billion, that is for sure. What is it going to be next year? We have got tax decreases coming and not tax increases.

In this document, I really see very little hope for the financial future of our country. I see very little hope for the short or long term unemployed. I really do not know what the outcome will be. Another issue that is raised in this document which I think is going to increasingly take our time in this place—and I think it is a shame because the economic and social issues are more pressing—is talk about constitutional reform. By any other name, it is the issue of republicanism. The Governor-General, on behalf of the Prime Minister, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government intends to continue the process of promoting discussion and debate on the appropriateness of having an Australian Head of State, chosen by Australians.

Let us have a brief look at that issue. Let us try to see what it is all about. Why are we today discussing changing a system that has made Australia the sixth longest serving parliamentary democratic system in the world? Of those six, four are monarchical forms of parliamentary democracy. They have been big failures, have they not? Australia is sixth—uninterrupted by military dictatorship or war. So we must have done something pretty well. In my view, it has worked very well.

PARA.TAB: This nation has absorbed millions of people from countries all over the world. I am a product of that immigration. When I changed my citizenship I swore allegiance to the Queen of Australia, and I was proud to do so. I have to say that I think my uncle who some seven generations ago signed the Declaration of Independence might have rolled over in his grave; nevertheless, I was pleased to swear allegiance to the Queen.

Yesterday I saw the Prime Minister swear allegiance to the Queen, yet he is running the agenda on republicanism. One has to ask oneself the question: why is it that we are brought to this debate? What is the agenda? Why are we today discussing changing the nature and the power structure of our system of parliamentary democracy? For what reason? Are we under attack? Is some other country about to take us over? Is some other country telling us what to do? Is some other country driving our agenda? Do we have the issue, as did the country of my birth, of taxation without representation? I say no, that no such issue exists. There is no such problem, even on the horizon.

We have to look behind the issue. There are probably three reasons why our Prime Minister is now supporting a republic. The first of those reasons undoubtedly is that he sees that it offers him a place in history—perhaps a permanent place in history; perhaps as president for life; perhaps not; perhaps emperor. Who knows? I think that the issue offers him an opportunity to see his name go down in history as the individual who led the debate that saw Australia change its system from a parliamentary democracy, based on a monarch as nominal head of state, to a so-called republic.

The second part of the agenda is all about power. This minimalist position severely understates the real case. The issue is about power; it is about further centralising the power of the executive in federal government. If one thinks carefully about that, one comes very quickly to the conclusion that the Executive in this Government already has excessive amounts of power.

The executive is constrained in only three ways, the first of which is by the Senate. But, if the Australian public at a general election returns a Senate which is of the same party as the party in dominance in the House of Representatives, the check is gone. The second check on executive power is the High Court, but that takes a very long time and is very unpredictable; it involves very detailed legalities. The third check on the power of executive government is the States. Frequently I read about members of the Labor Party supporting the abolition of the States and promoting regional governments around Australia. There was a time when I thought that that might not be a bad idea, that some of this overlap in the provision of services by the federal government and by State governments was a bit nonsensical, a waste of money and inefficient. But the States form a real check against abuse of executive power by the federal executive.

I suspect that in my lifetime I will never support the abolition of the States or the rescission of our federalist system. The federalist system has worked well. The checks and balances work reasonably well and, whilst the executive has too much power, I believe that there are things we can do in terms of the operation of this House of Representatives to help diffuse part of that power and to help make the House of Representatives, and parliament, more relevant today. I will pursue that agenda with vigour over the coming three years.

But in my mind there is no question that the third reason for this debate has to do with sectarianism. We have seen evidence of that in the last few days from members of the Labor Party who just happen to be Irish Catholics, who just happen to say that the method of selection of the monarch who looks over us all is both sexist and sectarian. For heaven's sake; the history and the tradition of the monarchy goes back for centuries. I note that it has given us that well-known Australian republican, our current Governor-General, who has done a magnificent job. I would also say that it is the office and the history, heritage and tradition of that office that has made the man. He has been an excellent Governor-General for Australia. I note that Robert Manne in the Age on 4 May said:

SPEECH.PARA: Irish Australians are instinctively both anti-British and anti-monarchy.

It is no accident that the first Australian Prime Minister who raised the issue of republicanism seriously was a Keating, that the leader of the movement was a Keneally, the editor of the conservative newspaper which supported the cause a Kelly, and the first Liberal Party leader who broke ranks on the issue a Fahey. For the first time in our history the Australian elite is generously (and rightly) peopled by descendants of the Irish. In part at least, republicanism is their revenge.

The Prime Minister's agenda on the one hand is economic, but it is an agenda which shows us no hope for the unemployed in this country. On the other hand the agenda—the republic—is a furphy. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to make my first speech in this 37th Parliament, I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on being elected to your position as Deputy Chairman of Committees, and ask you to pass on to the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker my congratulations on election to their positions.

PARA.TAB: I have had time to reflect over the last three years on what it means to be a member of parliament. I made my maiden speech in this Parliament in 1980, and I had the privilege of serving the Parliament for 10 years. I have also had the experience of spending three years out of the Parliament, and I now have the honour of being re-elected. I can assure anybody who has been through the experience that no matter what one does in politics it is a great learning curve.

While I was out of the Parliament I had the opportunity and privilege to serve the Australian administration as the Administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. For that opportunity and privilege I have to thank the former Minister for Territories, the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons), who is sitting here behind me. One thing which can assist a member of parliament is the experience of being an administrator, particularly if that administration is based upon a very old, colonial, Queen Victoria rule of law. I was interested to hear the last speaker, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), talk about the republican issue, but I will come back to that later.

During my two-year term as the Administrator of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, one of my major responsibilities was to see through the final introduction of modern Australian law in that outpost of Australia 3,280 kilometres north-west of Perth—the farthest point west one can go and still be in Australia. When I arrived we were in the final stages of introducing modern law—a process which commenced in the 1970s during the Whitlam Government when the United Nations took a great interest in the colonies around the world, of which Cocos was one.

In 1983 the first real moves were made in this Parliament to introduce Australian law to that Territory. At that time, the laws of Cocos were based very much on the colonial English law of 1905 out of Singapore—and they were still that way when I arrived at the end of 1990. The administrator had total power by law—an anachronism which was in the process of being changed. It is interesting to listen to the debate about a republic and think that it is only very recently that an outpost of Australia actually reached the stage where, at the end of last June, this Parliament passed the laws which brought it up to date and into modern Australian law. This law is based upon Commonwealth law which mirrors West Australian State law. It is a unique situation.

During that period my role was to see those laws introduced onto the islands and to assist the community in their introduction. Under the old law, the administrator was the commissioner of police and also the policeman. He was the director of education, the director of health, the harbour master and the director of the harbours department. Under the old British law, everything went through administrators. We now have on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands a modern law situation where the Federal Police report to the commissioner in Canberra; the chief of the education department and the full-time school principal reports to the education department of Western Australia; and the chief medical officer, who is also the medical officer for the local government, reports back to Western Australia.

Last Saturday the local government held its first full council elections under Western Australian law. I suppose it is hard to believe that, in 1993, a local government was formed in Australia. My friend and colleague the honourable member for Calare was Minister for Local Government when this system of law was introduced and it has also been a very interesting time for me to be a part of these legal changes. We now have Commonwealth law mirrored on Western Australian law and the people now have their own local government. They elected that Government in the election held on 1 May and I would like to put on the record those who were successful in that election. Seven councillors were elected. Ibram bin Not, Haji Zaitol bin Wallie, Woren bin Dedian, Balmut bin Pirus, Ronald James Grant, Haji Wahin bin Bynie and Amatnoor bin Anthoney were the successful councillors elected to that council which is now part of Australian government.

The people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands are the descendants of those who first came to the islands as workers for the Clunies-Ross family who settled there in the last century. It is only 13 years ago that the people began to receive a full education by Western Australian standards and only last year that the Clunies-Ross family finally put its last piece of land up for sale.

It has been a very interesting time for me. If people are interested in visiting an Australian outpost which nobody knows too much about and wants to have a magnificent holiday away from it all, they should look at the Cocos (Keeling) Islands because they are certainly well worth going to see. They will not find a prettier place in Australia or better people to mix with than those on the islands.

To make it even more attractive, I can report that the weather conditions there are the greatest anywhere in the world. Every day it is 28 degrees and every night it is 25 degrees. The hottest day on record is 30 degrees and the coldest is 21.9 degrees. As honourable members can see, with that climate all people need to take is a pair of shorts, some sandals and a couple of T-shirts and they can have a great holiday there without any difficulty at all. I have been very privileged, as a former member of this House, to have had the opportunity of working there. I will not forget it and it provided great experience in administration.

I arrived back in Australia in early December 1992 at the end of my contract. Whilst I had been following the newspapers fairly closely on Cocos when they arrived a week late, I was absolutely dismayed to see that we had elected in Victoria a government which was virtually dismantling much of what we had just introduced to the people of the Cocos Islands: Commonwealth laws on awards for workers which had introduced equality for the first time on Cocos where, under an award, people could get the same wage no matter where they worked in Australia. I was horrified to see what was occurring here.

About three weeks before I arrived back in Australia one of the biggest demonstrations that had ever been seen in the Latrobe Valley took place. Ten thousand people tried to enter the Kernot Hall in Morwell, which holds a capacity of about 5,000 people, to protest at what was going on in Victoria. This really amazed me. Having been endorsed previously to run for the seat of McMillan, at that stage I felt there was a chance that perhaps the swing would be on in Victoria which eventually did come through on election day.

I would like to thank the Labor Party which once before afforded me the opportunity to represent for 10 years the electorate of McMillan. People do not very often get the opportunity to serve in this House and it was a great honour for me to have 10 years here. Very few people can enter this place as Independents—we have two sitting in the chamber at the moment; but it happens very rarely. Most who are given the privilege to serve in this Parliament are reliant upon all of those people who go to branch meetings and work diligently for nothing at all by way of remuneration to make it possible for us to sit in this chamber and have the honour of serving an electorate. I take this opportunity to thank those in the Labor Party and the party itself, firstly, for the opportunity to serve for 10 years and, secondly, for the endorsement which enabled me to come back again. I will not forget that.

I would like to say a few things about the electorate of McMillan. As I said in my maiden speech in the old House 13 years ago, the electorate is based upon the rural sector and has a traditional Labor base situated around the Latrobe Valley where we generate all the power for industry and homes in Victoria. In the future, we expect to send it interstate in a very competitive way.

The electorate is unique. It has now developed to the point where it is virtually in three sections. The western end of the electorate—the Pakenham region—is now being built up at the very outskirts of Melbourne. It has the unique problems of a city which is growing extensively as part of the outer corridors of Melbourne.

The economy of the electorate's central region is based on the dairy industry. I had the honour of serving in this Parliament with the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) as the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and working through the restructuring that took place in the dairy industry in 1984, 1985 and 1986. Whilst we are still talking about restructuring and the problems we are having with it in many industries, that is one industry which is benefiting today from the restructure that was put in place—at times in the face of strong opposition from some conservative forces. I remember attending a meeting in my electorate with the honourable member for Werriwa where a Commonwealth car was badly damaged when 1,500 angry farmers opposed what the Government was introducing. I can assure honourable members that in my electorate in this election the swing to the Labor Party in the rural sector was as strong as it was anywhere else because that section of my electorate is now very prosperous and the dairy industry is going from strength to strength.

The eastern end of the electorate now is based upon the power industry and is very much dominated by the State Electricity Commission. Over the years there had been a steady restructuring of that operation, which is the basis of the economy in that area, by the former Labor Government. By a steady operation, I mean one based upon consultation with the unions, one based upon the realities of how restructuring can take place without totally disrupting the community. Today I am afraid we are facing a situation where consultation has gone out the window and things are moving at a pace which is really frightening. People are not being consulted, the unions are being ignored, and people are being asked to accept that decisions can be made without appropriate information being given to them. We are suffering in that area because people are very concerned and worried about what the future holds for them. It is very difficult for families who know that cuts are coming but do not know which families the chop is going to come down on. It is causing grave concern to the community.

Another great concern at the moment is that the Victorian Government is going down a path of privatisation. I am not one who totally opposes restructuring. The word `privatisation' puts fear into some people but perhaps not others. It is restructuring that has to take place. In Victoria at present the Government is experimenting with people's lives. In New South Wales the Government has brought private enterprise into the power industry. The company is known as Pacific Power and it is an integrated operation in New South Wales. The Victorian Government is talking about selling three of the power stations to three different companies, with no integration and movement from one power station to another, and breaking the system up into transmission and distribution, again on the same basis. It has never been tried anywhere in the world. It has never worked anywhere around the world; it is an experiment which is fraught with danger. Whilst in New South Wales drastic changes were made with Pacific Power, it still has the integrated operated operation which gives it strength.

If Victoria continues on the path it is going—and there are three different companies running three different power stations—one of them could be closed overnight by private enterprise. This is causing grave concern. It is really experimentation. Many of those who have been charged with the responsibility of delivering this system are expressing these concerns to the Victorian State Government. Tonight, in this Parliament, I would make a plea that it is time the Victorian Government started to listen and consult. The decisions it is taking and the way it is taking them are so drastic that when it finds perhaps that it has made a major mistake, it will be too late to reverse the situation, and that would be an absolute tragedy for our region.

The electorate is a very diverse one, as I have pointed out tonight. The three distinct areas of the electorate are totally different and need to be treated in that way. At the Commonwealth level we need to take an active interest in what is happening in this restructuring.

That brings me to comment on the republic debate that is going on at the moment. At the end of my electorate are the large towns—the people in them call cities—of Moe, Morwell and Traralgon. Some 90,000 people live in those combined cities. There are three cities, three local government operations. It is my belief—and it is something that I am going to work very hard to achieve—that we will not prosper in that area until such time as we have a single regional city administration covering that city base where there is a community of interest. It should be established in such a way that we have a proper, modern administration—the sort of administration that is needed in a republican debate. This type of administration has been proposed before in regional areas and has been defeated for political reasons, because it is called the amalgamation of shires.

Those interests need to be considered, but we need to put them aside when they need to be put aside. We need to come to a real understanding that almost every sector of the Australian economy has been restructuring. Those sectors that got into it, got on with it and were led through it are prospering; those areas which are still resisting are struggling. One of the areas that is still resisting is local government. At the regional level in Victoria it is as bad as anywhere in Australia. I am not being critical of the people who are in local government at the moment in my region, but I am sure, because of the moves that have taken place in the last two months and meetings that are now being held in Victoria amongst local government people, that they are coming to realise that an area as big as the electorate of McMillan does not require 10 CEOs of local government, or 15 or 16 chief engineers, or assistant clerks to administer the population and that these things are holding back development.

I am raising this matter in the Parliament because I think the Commonwealth has to be involved. I think some of these regional cities have to prosper as cities. They have to develop a base where a region such as ours can have performing community arts centres big enough that one would say that it is a city; where we can have the major stores come in to the area because there is a catchment of 200,000 or 300,000 people within that region who need to be catered for. It will not happen while we have cities of 20,000 to 25,000 people with separate administrations trying to do what one administration can do in a city of 80,000 or 90,000 people because we are not efficiently using the public services that we have in that area.

Whilst we are discussing the republican issue, we also need to discuss that issue, because it is a States issue; it is a local government issue; it is an issue that we need to discuss going into this next century. Our regional areas in Australia cannot wait any longer for those in power at all levels to consider that the people there have problems which will not go away if the administration looking after those areas is still thinking in last century terms. We have to move with the times and move away those obstacles which are holding our areas back. That area, which is one third of the electorate of McMillan in size but with the greatest population area, needs to move into the next century and it needs to move into the debate that I am pleased the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has started. But I hope we do not have to wait until the year 2001 to see the changes come in our area; and that our local people will move with it and move quickly and deliver to our local region the services, the programs and the potential employment through new industry that is required. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly listened with great interest to the reports of the idyllic lifestyle on Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands. It is interesting that the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) made such a worthwhile contribution while he filled that position. Perhaps some of those journalists and others who were so unkind about his appointment may be reassured after learning of the progress that occurred during his time as administrator. I hope he also took care of the million dollar cruise vessel, the R.J. Hawke, while he was there, so that the taxpayers are assured of having got good value for that investment as well.
—You've got it wrong. It is a search and rescue vessel and was approved as such.

—I hope it also was able to convey him to the best of the scenic spots in the area. I turn now to the business at hand, the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's speech. As I sat and listened for an extended period during the Governor-General's speech, I could not help but wonder how different that speech would have been if about 1,500 Australians in the right places had voted differently on 13 March. Instead of long and often empty rhetoric, alphabetically and repetitively covering the topics of the agenda, we would have had the announcement of an exciting program of legislative change, a real opportunity for Australia to break free from the recession that it has endured for such a long time.

PARA.TAB: This program would have given Australians hope for the future—a program of slashing taxes, reducing the size of government and so much of the waste that occurs in government processes these days, a revitalised health system, justice for self-funded retirees, encouragement for Australian industry by removing some of the penalties that are so grievously holding back Australian producers and exporters at the present time, reward for effort, encouragement for those prepared to invest and to save, and support for Australian families in these difficult times. That kind of program would have given Australia an opportunity to fight back and to build a real and new beginning.

We will never go ahead as a nation whilst we impose penalties on Australians who put in that little extra effort, while we tax our exporters and put obstacles in the way of those who want to achieve. The agenda the coalition took to the Australian people offered an opportunity for a sea change: a new way of doing things in this country; an opportunity to build a better Australia that once again we could be proud of.

So Labor comes back and begins a new term just as tired as it was before the election, still out of ideas, with no enthusiasm and no prospect of building a better future for our country. That is a sad way to begin this Parliament. That was a sad way to go into the opening ceremony, and it was sad to sit through the Governor-General's speech. The Governor-General was forced to read out such a tired and empty program which would have no doubt filled many Australians with despair that there would be nothing better to offer, no new hope or no new opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —It exhausted him and it exhausted us.

—Yes, exhaustion. We have lived through a long period of exhaustion and it seems more of that is ahead of us. Thinking back over the election, for many people the result seems to have been a shock. In fact, when I walk around my electorate I have trouble finding anybody who is prepared to confess that they actually voted for the Labor Party. I wonder where those people are that returned Labor to office. Perhaps it is because I come from a country area.

PARA.TAB: The country parts of Australia certainly did not return Labor to office. Indeed, Labor lost a big swipe of the small number of rural electorates that it actually held. I am very proud to say that electorates such as Wide Bay showed a good degree more wisdom than that reflected in some of the capital cities and other parts of the country. I am very proud of the 4.2 per cent swing the coalition parties achieved in Wide Bay. I should like to express my gratitude to all of those people who assisted in our campaign to achieve that result. It was the best result the National Party has had in Wide Bay since 1985, and the second best ever, and I can assure honourable members that we will do a lot better in the future.

There is no doubt that this election will be a part of the political science textbooks for all time. It has always been a tenet of political science that governments lose elections, oppositions do not win them. The coalition did not want to just win this last election because the ALP was so bad. Everyone knew that Labor had been a failure in government. Labor had created shameful records in this country: record unemployment, record debt, record Budget deficits and record social despair. Labor created the recipe to guarantee that it would lose the election.

Everyone said to us, `All you have to do is stand up and you will be elected'. But we did not want to go to the Australian people covering up the difficulties of the past and the magnitude of the problem. We wanted to be honest with the Australian people, to level with them, because they would have to be a part of our agenda. Because there would be some pain in getting Australia working profitably again, it was important that in proposing such a massive program of change we were honest and up-front with the Australian people by telling them the story in advance. We did not play dead and wait for the victor's robes to be draped over our shoulders. We went out there to win. We went out there to be honest with the Australian people and to put in place and to put before them the sort of program that was necessary to change Australia. So for two years we had set the political agenda.

Usually it is governments that supposedly put up all the ideas and propose the program of change and oppositions that do the criticising. That did not happen in Australia. The Liberal and National parties were composed of the people who put forward the proposals and who had the exciting agenda. All the Government could do was criticise. It never had any ideas of its own. All it could do was knock the ideas that we put forward.

Former Prime Minister Hawke was not seen to be sufficiently effective in criticising, so he was knifed in the back for somebody else who had a louder mouth and who was a bigger critic—not somebody with more positive ideas but somebody who could criticise louder. The Government's campaign was negative and bereft of ideas. One of the lessons of this election was that it proved the power of negativity. It proved that it is so much easier to criticise than it is to be constructive. It proved how much easier it is to knock down than it is to create.

This election also proved the great power of fear in elections. Labor built its campaign around fear: the fear that we might end Medicare, that we would add to living costs, cut wages and close services. They were all groundless fears but, nonetheless, the basis of the ALP campaign. This election also proved the power of the big lie. The Government's campaign was built on dishonesty. Its television advertisements told nothing of the truth but were built on fear: for example, the pregnant lady advertisement that lied about the impact of a coalition health care program on the cost of having children.

In my electorate the Government conducted a mailing campaign. The Labor Party candidate actually distributed a brochure in which she claimed that petrol tax had fallen under Labor. That was the ultimate lie. There is no way that one could interpret history to lead one to the view that under Labor petrol taxes declined. The petrol tax has gone from 7c to 28c a litre and the excise collection has risen from $900 million to about $7 1/2 billion. The proportion of income derived from petrol tax has also increased. Yet in my electorate and in other electorates Labor distributed a pamphlet in which it claimed that under Labor petrol tax had declined. That is the kind of big lie that Labor built its campaign around.

The involvement of the unions in the campaign was devastating. The Queensland Police Union, normally a more rational union, in the last edition of its journal before the election, published an article claiming that under a coalition government police superannuation benefits would be slashed fivefold. The truth was that we would increase police superannuation benefits something like sixfold.

I went to the trouble of writing to all the police officers in my electorate to point out the error—or the dishonesty, to be frank—in this particular union article. But I had just got that one out of the way when the nurses union wrote off to all the nurses telling them that under a coalition government they would all lose their jobs, they would have to apply for their jobs and there would be huge cuts in their salaries. Of course, under the Goss Government many of them are losing their jobs now.

That one was just out of the way when the shop assistants were told that a coalition government would cut all shop assistants' wages to $3 an hour. Again, that was rank dishonesty. It ignored the fact that after this whole youth wages debate Labor is currently employing thousands of young Australians for precisely the same wages that we spoke about in our youth wages program. That was part of the dishonesty.

Then there was the $5 note which I think the Seamen's Union distributed in Western Australia. It was even the old design $5 that did not survive Labor's economic mismanagement. It was a note that the union turned into a $4.25 note. The Government claimed that GST would add 15 per cent to the cost of a whole lot of items. It got the list all wrong. It should have been a $5.50 note because of the extra benefit that we would have packed into everybody's pay packet under the Fightback program. But, sadly for Australians, sadly for our democracy, the campaign of lies succeeded. Evil triumphed over good. That is a really sad message for the Australian people.

We are always told that people want honesty in politics but it seems they are not prepared to vote for it. It is a real threat to our democratic system if we cannot go into an election campaign with candidates and parties telling the truth—criticising each other's policies is quite legitimate, but that ought to be done on the basis of honesty and fact, pointing out the merits of one side as distinct from another—rather than relying on the big lie, fear and dishonesty, to win an election.

Why should any Opposition ever be honest again? Why should anyone ever tell the truth? Are there no rewards for honesty? Do Australians not want to know the truth? Do they want us to keep spending what we do not have? Do they want an unsustainable welfare system and overburdened bureaucracy to continue? That is, sadly, what we are left with. People did not vote for the Keating Government, they did not give the Prime Minister any kind of a mandate at all. Sadly, on the basis of fear and concern, they rejected an opportunity for new hope and a new start.

There can be no doubt that 10 years of Labor has significantly changed Australia. But can we ever recover from those changes? The odd Labor term may be sustained by a country or a state for a while, but what has gone wrong in Australia over recent years is that, for the first time in our history, States and now the Commonwealth have had successive terms of Labor governments. It has always been known that Labor cannot manage money. Labor governments are good spenders; they can think of lots of things to throw the money away on—and maybe a vigorous, productive and wealthy country like Australia can afford such spending policies once every lifetime. But we have had a succession of Labor governments and our country has reached the stage where the economy is on its knees. We have massive debt and there is no real possibility of that being turned around under the sort of program that was announced for us this week in the Governor-General's speech.

Australia is no longer a country dominated by workers and producers—the contributors to our society. Now we are dominated by public servants and welfare recipients. Labor has in fact bought for itself a constituency. I was impressed by an article by Fia Cumming which appeared in a recent edition of the Sunday Mail entitled, `How your tax elected Labor'. I think it quoted some very telling statistics.

Under the headline, `Half a nation on the public payroll', Fia Cumming cited some statistics. There are now 1.73 million Australian people employed by federal, state and local governments. There are nearly one million people on unemployment benefits, nearly half a million on invalid and wife and carer pensions, 68,000 on widows pensions, 290,000 on sole parent pensions, 16,000 rehabilitation allowance recipients, 607,000 on family allowance supplements, 1.5 million on age pensions and 53,000 on double orphans pensions. These figures amount to a total of almost four million Australians on welfare benefits.

Then there are another 450,000 students on Austudy and the families of 3.8 million children get family allowances. What it basically means is that the number of Australians receiving wages or benefits from the Government totalled 8,094,818 but there were only 7,808,000 full-time or part-time workers in Australia. For every part-time or full-time worker in Australia now, we have more than one on welfare. So in fact Labor has so encouraged dependence upon the welfare system that it has bought for itself a constituency.

But that is not the end of it. Many millions of dollars in taxpayers' money is now devoted to lobby organisations. I am told that $57 million goes to the trade union movement. The Australian Council of Social Service gets 90 per cent of its income from the taxpayers, as do many conservation and other organisations, the arts and the Australia Council, many consultative groups and the like. All of these depend for their existence on taxpayers' money.

Is it any surprise then that they crank up their computers at election time and beef out pro-ALP material? Is it any shock that ACOSS or the consumer organisations back whatever ALP rubbish comes out in the election campaign? It does not matter what the Labor Party proposes on election night, it can count on all of these groups devoting their resources to support it. In addition, the resources provided to the union movement are then turned around to provide massive on-the-ground support to Labor Party candidates wherever they are.

So we have this situation where the election campaign is now heavily loaded in favour of the Labor Party. It is able to use the trappings of office to resource a mass of groups across the countryside to ensure that its candidates have an advantage that no-one else can possibly hope to match. If we want a fair and balanced democratic system it is essential that checks and balances be put in place to ensure that the Government uses the resources at its disposal fairly, particularly in the lead-up to an election campaign.

I was interested to read in the Courier-Mail this week how EARC in Queensland had commented on the fact that the Queensland Government was unable—or, in truth, unwilling—to disclose the extent of its own expenditure on public relations and publicity activities. But, from its own endeavours, it uncovered the fact that something like $37 million was spent by the Queensland Government on its own publicity and promotion during the previous year. I read reports a year or so ago that the Commonwealth Government spends $252 million a year on self-promotion and publicity. Of that money, something like $50 million is spent in the environment, recreation and the arts portfolio alone.

That kind of expenditure can really be put down to expenditure on the ALP. Most of these publications have the Minister's picture on them. Some beautiful environmental material is put out by the environment department that I would love to distribute to schools in my electorate, but there is no way I am distributing brochures that have the picture of the Minister for the environment on them and contain all sorts of pro-ALP comments. That is a gross abuse of the public treasury and these sorts of things really ought to be brought to account.

In the Governor-General's concluding remarks, he said that the Labor Government is aiming to create a richer and more rewarding Australia; a fairer one. That is a worthy objective. What is fair about one million unemployed? What is fair about 100,000 on the hospital waiting queues? What is fair about 700,000 children in poverty? What is fair about drought-stricken farmers? What is fair about the program of this Labor Government? Sadly, in all of the pages that preceded those comments from the Governor-General, there was nothing to indicate that this Government has learnt from its experience and intends to do something more positive in its current term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, at the outset, I congratulate you on your appointment and also ask that you pass on my congratulations to the Speaker on his elevation to that high office. The election on 13 March was an historic one. It saw the re-election of the Keating Labor Government and, in the electorate of Parramatta, was the culmination of three years of hard work by many people in the local area who were determined that we were going to retain the seat of Parramatta for the Labor Party in Federal Parliament, despite a difficult redistribution.

PARA.TAB: At the beginning of my speech, I want to pay tribute to the campaign team that helped ensure the victory for us in that election: in particular, my campaign manager, Mr Don Hansford; all the Labor Party branch members in the electorate; my staff; the great support we had from the trade union movement; and the wonderful contribution from Young Labor members who were delighted to be part of ensuring the continuity of Labor government throughout Australia.

I also pay tribute to the many other people who came out in support—some perhaps in fear of the Opposition's policies and many concerned that the sort of vision that the Labor Party had established over the years, the sense of fairness and purpose that had been part of our agenda, was retained. All of those things came together to create a very great victory for us on 13 March.

I pay particular tribute to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for his very strong leadership from the time he was elected Prime Minister right through to the election. Throughout that period, I think there was a strong sense of purpose, vision and creativity in everything that was undertaken by the Government, and the Prime Minister deserves special mention.

I also want to pay tribute to the New South Wales branch and national office of the Labor Party which gave us such sterling help. In particular, I want to pay tribute to my family who played a big part throughout, ensuring our success at the local level.

I believe that the election demonstrated the good faith and good sense that the people of Australia have in making judgments about who they want to run the country. I think it demonstrated that the people of Australia are not really interested in the sort of social laboratory and social experiment that Fightback and all it stood for represented. They did not want to throw away the things that they had grown up with, the important issues such as a comprehensive and universal health care system; they did not want to throw away the sense of decency that goes with having comprehensive child-care policies; they did not want to throw away the sense of equity that comes with giving all people a chance to have access to educational opportunity; and they did not want to throw away the broader sense of having a socially cohesive community in which policies are directed not for the benefit of the few at the expense of the majority but rather to include the majority in the various decisions that are made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too smart for that.

—I think the electorate showed that they were far too smart, as the Parliamentary Secretary rightly points out. Various members of the Opposition have said that they understood what the policies meant after the election, but the people of Australia had the good sense to realise what they would wreak on Australia well before the election. That is exactly the reason why, on 13 March, the Government was returned with an increased majority.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that, in the few days after the election, members of the Opposition were blaming the GST. Now we find that they are blaming the people of Australia and the interest groups. They are blaming everybody else rather than their own incompetence and their own hopeless policies that they put to the people which were so soundly rejected.

When we look at the ramifications of the election results of 13 March, we see that what really counts is that the people of Australia said they want fairness and equity. They do not want division and dislocation. The community wanted policies of inclusion, where cohesion and the benefits that flow from developing a socially cohesive society are retained, rather than policies of fragmentation and the slavish pursuit and blind faith in markets at all costs.

In looking at the result of this election it is clear that the people of Australia were concerned that there was a strength of vision and courage in what the Government delivered, but that had to be developed in a way in which all people would be part of that sense of vision and purpose. It did not matter whether they were concerned at the community level, the workplace level or in the business decisions that were being made. They wanted to ensure that the policies that were adopted by the national government adequately addressed the different challenges that the community faced. It was no good the Government creating a set of policies that benefited a few people. The Government needed to create a set of policies that over time would create economic growth that all would be the beneficiaries of. The Address-in-Reply and the Governor-General's speech focused on the need to pursue economic growth and ensure that growth occurs more quickly, but at the same time we cannot do that in a way that destroys the embracing nature of the social fabric policy framework that the Labor Government has been about creating.

The Government went to the election making a number of fundamental points. The first was that the economy was not growing quickly enough. It certainly was growing, despite the protestations of the Opposition that we were in this double-dip recession. Nothing that has occurred since suggests that that is the case. It is clear that the economy needs to grow more quickly and that we are headed in the right direction. When we do comparisons with other countries, it is clear that our economy is growing more quickly than comparable countries at this time.

We also made it clear in the election that the level of unemployment was unacceptably high, that the Government's clear priority would be to tackle unemployment, and that it would be the agenda item that needed most focus in this term of government. The address from the Governor-General made it clear that that is the Government's continuing fundamental policy derivative over this term.

The next point the Government made clear was that it deeply regretted the pain of the recession, that it understood its severity and impact and was determined to overcome it. In the process, while economic growth and development of policies to overcome the recession occurred, we were going to ensure that people were not left behind, and we were going to give people the social and income support they needed.

I now turn to the more socially directed policies which we were concerned about. We were concerned that Medicare was not thrown out the window, which is what the Opposition tried to do in its policy pronouncements prior to the election. We were determined that Medicare would be a universal health care system from which all would benefit. In my electorate the vast majority of doctors bulk-bill. The Opposition was basically saying that the people who had the benefit of bulk-billing were going to lose it. What were they going to gain in its place? They were not going to gain anything in improved health care or more affordable health care; in fact, they were going to have more costly health care and probably a diminution of services as a result of the policies that the Opposition was pursuing.

When we look at the period since the election it is clear that, in trying to promote sustainable and more vigorous economic growth, our policies will start to come through. That has been the position of the Government. Let us look back over the period of announcements and economic statements that we have made since the Prime Minister was elected. We have had the development of initiatives in One Nation to build economic growth; we have had the Budget of 1992 with the fiscal stimulus that contained; and we have had the Investment in the nation statement, which also contained many important measures to promote private investment. They are, quite clearly, important provisions.

It is important that we have competitive company tax regimes with our trading partners and competitors, that we have the lowest interest rates in over 20 years, that we encourage investment allowances which will ensure that we rebuild the private investment sector of the economy, and that we take steps to ensure our banks make finance available for new business projects. All these issues have been covered in initiatives undertaken by the Government over the last 12 months. The challenge now is to build on the initiatives

SPEECH.PARA: that have been taken, to ensure that the benefits of those decisions flow through the economy, and to move further than the initiatives that have been taken already. The Governor-General's speech makes it clear that the Government is precisely about ensuring those things happen.

PARA.TAB: It is also important to recognise—this is something that is made clear in the Governor-General's speech—that the world economy continues to be very fragile; no-one can dispute that. The impact that has on Australia is there for all to see. We know that world commodity prices continue to be a difficult issue and that we need to get fair outcomes to the GATT round of trade talks if we are really going to build effectively on those issues. In the meantime, we will enhance the rate of domestic economic growth and take steps to enhance the rate of private investment.

Quite clearly, there is a role for government in this process: it must ensure that it does something about the long-term unemployed. It has been made clear in the Governor-General's speech, and in the policy speech of the Prime Minister, that we need to focus on issues relating to regional manifestations of economic growth. We need to take a structured regional approach and look at areas in which the Government can play a part: creating the environment for private sector growth and enhancing infrastructure to facilitate that growth.

Blind, slavish faith in the markets and in the economic ideology of Reagan, Thatcher and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) will not achieve that. It was not achieved for Reagan and Thatcher—they have been dispatched into the pages of political history. I think it is fairly likely that the Leader of the Opposition does not have too long before he is similarly dispatched into those pages of political history.

We need to ensure that export growth and export opportunities are improved and that we recognise the strength and capacity of small and medium sized companies to play a part in that export growth. Strategic industry development is a key element of that. Promotion of efficient trade movement and reform in those areas is also a very relevant issue. Maintaining a fair and balanced industrial relations system is pivotal to that process. Surely we can achieve results only if there is a spirit of industrial cooperation, seeking out the collective wisdom of both management and labour and utilising their skills and talents cooperatively to produce and achieve more effective productivity. Ensuring that we maintain low levels of inflation through the developing and evolving accord process is clearly another fundamental part of that arrangement.

These measures continue to bear the value that has been part of the accord, and part of the relationship that we have tried to structure with labour organisations throughout the period of the Labor Government. Industries like tourism, industries that were not recognised as industries prior to the Labor Government, offer more potential as time goes on. We can do more in those areas. The integration more closely with the Asia-Pacific region offers tremendous opportunities in tourism and services. Clearly, the Government recognises the importance of those and the Governor-General's speech makes clear that we are determined to enhance those opportunities over the next few years.

We can look at some of the measures we took in industry development in the last term of the Government, in the pharmaceutical industry, the telecommunications industry, in food processing and in educational and financial services—all areas where there are growth opportunities. Prior to the election, the Opposition basically said that those sorts of industry plans were irrelevant. They were meaningless. The results were there. Companies in my electorate, as in many other electorates, were talking about the benefits of those policies, and were concerned about the continuity of the sorts of measures that those industry arrangements provided. The Opposition's policies were designed at that time to tear them to bits.

It is suggested that the Opposition may have changed its tune on some of those issues since the election. I hope that is the case because, clearly, continuity in those industry development arrangements, in areas like the pharmaceutical industry, one of Australia's great exporters at this time, can be achieved only if the community is confident about policy continuity. The only way people can have policy continuity is to continue to re-elect Labor governments that will be committed to policy certainty in those areas. Those small and medium sized businesses also will now have the benefit of lower company tax rates, clearly an important opportunity for them. Many were advocating more access to investment allowance provisions. Those measures were contained in the Investment in the nation statement and will flow through and be of direct benefit to them.

The impact of these practical industry initiatives is shown in electorates like Parramatta. We have seen a major growth in the importance of tourism to our region. Further promotion of the regional strategic nature of tourism can only make that effort even greater. Improved marketing, and an orientation towards the service excellence that goes with it, will give us more opportunities both for the growth of the industry and more jobs in the industry. In the area of export enhancement, I am very pleased that, just prior to the last election, the Government made a commitment about developing an export access centre in Parramatta.

It is a very important initiative, not just a Government initiative. It is a joint initiative between Austrade and the Chamber of Manufactures of New South Wales. It is a public-private sector project, designed to encourage companies in the region looking at export opportunities to have a one-stop shop they can go to, to have the expertise on tap to encourage them to move into those new export markets. I am very pleased to see the encouraging response that has been achieved from the business community in the region. It offers great opportunities for them to become major exporters.

Export facilitation and the opportunities that provides for growth is clearly very significant for Australia. When we turn to the further steps that we can take in educational services for instance, I am very pleased to note that the University of Western Sydney, which has a campus in my electorate, is very much focused on the capacity to export educational services and what that offers to the Australian community. Those sorts of opportunities, that sort of stimulus, and the get up and go that goes with it, from educators and the business sector will over time reap benefits for Australian export opportunities and in building our relationship with the region that we are part of.

The Governor-General's speech also highlighted a number of other policy initiatives. The policy speech of the Prime Minister very definitely identified child-care as now firmly on the national political landscape. We had a clear commitment from the Government to expand the number of places, to make more flexible options about child-care and to recognise the role of child-care, both in the home and in the broader community, as an occupational issue. All of the measures that were taken in the national child-care policy announced by the Labor Government go to the very heart of giving more opportunities to women, but at the same time recognising the changing nature of our community. I believe it is important that those initiatives be pursued with vigour, and I look forward to many of the projects initiating more child-care places in areas like western Sydney where clearly the population growth demands those new services. It is one of the great regrets that over the last two years or so we have not been able to get the Government in New South Wales to cooperate in funding arrangements for these sorts of programs. Before and after school care is desperately needed; yet we are finding increasingly delays and procrastination by the State Government in meeting its responsibilities to be part of that program.

Turning to the area of aged care, we have clear initiatives taken by the Government which are very much directed at providing increased support to the aged in the community. The extension of fringe benefits to all part rate pensioners is a very timely initiative; the seniors card that has been developed by the Government is again a very important step in recognising the broader needs of older Australians in the area of health and aged care services.

Our program is clearly focused on building on the strengths of regions like the Parramatta-western Sydney region. I was very pleased that in last year's Budget the local capital works program recognised the important contribution local government can make to building national economic recovery. In Parramatta's case, the program ensured work on major heritage buildings and, of course, our region is one of the most historic parts of Australia. Also, we had the building of new tourist centres and more sporting, cultural and recreational facilities. The big issue that we have had in our area, over the last 10 years or so, relates to urban flooding and the Government has made major contributions and further commitments to that as well. The better cities program again has ensured a major initiative in the Parramatta region with the transit west scheme. That scheme, designed to improve public transport, improve urban infrastructure, and ensure enhanced quality of life for the region is something that I warmly welcome and I will ensure that it is developed and delivered in this term of parliament. The support the Government has given to Sydney's 2000 Olympic bid is also an important initiative for my region. I think the other initiatives that we have taken to improve the urban quality of life are equally going to reap real benefits for the people of Parramatta over the next three years.

I am delighted to be part of the Government for this term of parliament. The Governor-General's speech sets a vigorous agenda for economic growth, new opportunities for young people and for women, a new era in our relations with the Aboriginal population, a new vision for Australia in this decade and beyond. It is pleasing to be able to be part of that very exciting agenda for the people of Australia. I am delighted that the people of Parramatta chose to return me to Federal Parliament and I look forward to being part of the Federal Labor Government in its building of Australia, creating a new national identity and ensuring strong economic growth for Australia over the next three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.
