TALK.START.PARA: —The Governor-General's speech about the Government's program for the next parliamentary term was an A to Z of plagiarism. In the important areas of industrial relations and tariffs, the Keating Government adopted the Opposition's policy positions. Cleverly, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has attempted to create the diversion of the republic, but this will prove to be ultimately his Waterloo. Before I look at these issues, I would like to look back a few years and see what this Government has done over the 10 years it has been in power.Back in 1986, when the present Prime Minister made his famous remark about Australia being in danger of becoming a banana republic, the Australian economy was in much better shape than is the case today.

PARA.TAB: Seven years ago, seasonally adjusted unemployment was at only 7.8 per cent; today's figure is 11.1 per cent. If we talk in real numbers of people affected by the scourge of unemployment rather than just percentages, we find that in February 1986 there were 608,000 Australians unemployed. Today that figure is 956,000, after seasonal adjustment. What an indictment on the unemployment situation here in Australia. The impact of the Government's recession, `the recession we had to have', which is so well-known by all Australians, has been experienced by ordinary Australians in many other ways. In the four years between 1984-85 and 1987-88, Australia's gross domestic product rose by an average each year of about 4 per cent, after allowing for inflation. In the last four years, the average annual rise has been 0.8 per cent. In other words, we are doing about a quarter as well as we were doing five years ago. These figures give a clear indication of how people feel out there, how badly they are going, and how they fully understand the decline in their own living standards.

The April current account deficit of $2.1 billion will put more pressure on the Government and is further evidence that the fiscal policy cannot be eased. We cannot afford to go on the sort of mindless, irresponsible spending binge that the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary) might advocate in this House from time to time.

Australia is heading for a current account deficit of $16 billion this year, with the Government having a similar deficit in its own spending programs. This is the greatest challenge for the returned Labor Government. It can hardly be complacent about the recent suggestions of a supposedly lower than expected Budget deficit. The deficit forecast was constantly amended last year. In the 1992 Budget the figure was only $13.4 billion. The amended figure rose to $15.9 billion, and that might yet be exceeded when the final figures come in at the end of June. Only half of the planned $1.6 billion in revenue from privatisation has been collected, so little more cash will flow in from this area this year.

Social security spending is up two per cent on the budgeted figures. Social security and welfare accounts for a third of the Budget spending. All honourable members of this House and all Australians should be aware of that very important feature of the current Budget. It will probably be a feature of future Budgets as they come to be framed. The need to take into account the welfare cost of the long-term unemployed has very serious implications for future Budgets. There are about 340,000 long-term unemployed, and all honourable members would be aware of the great cost involved in keeping them on unemployment benefits. Professor Judy Sloan of Flinders University has predicted that by the year 1996 there will be almost half a million long-term unemployed. That is an indictment of the present Government's policies and represents a huge human problem facing Australia, particularly those people who are unlucky enough not to find a job.

Apparently, the Cabinet recently decided that there will be no net increase in any government spending on any new policy proposals for the next three or four years. That is a far cry from the $1.2 billion figure included in the One Nation statement, where there seemed to be funds emerging from everywhere to pump prime the economy. One also cannot overlook all the extravagant promises of the Prime Minister during the election campaign, which showed little regard for fiscal responsibility. The razor gang will no doubt come out of hiding because there are three years to go before the next election.

We have been told that Senator Richardson, the Minister for Health, will not offset the cost of election commitments because he believes that the political advantage of such a move would be dubious. Senator Richardson will stick to his high spending arrangements no matter what, because he is a politician through and through. However, I commend Senator Richardson for being more cautious in adopting our key health policy, suggesting that there should be tax incentives to encourage people to take out private health insurance. The coalition has been advocating that for a number of years, and it is encouraging to see Senator Richardson looking at it. So all those Australians who are presently waiting for hospital beds might have a chance of receiving hospital care. In the Governor-General's speech at the opening of Parliament, the Government said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . reducing unemployment remains the ultimate focus of all the Government's economic policies . . .
The Government has not done too well with that key issue during its term of office, but it is pleasing to know that at least it is looking at it. It goes on to say:
. . . above all else, growth holds the key to restoring unemployment to more acceptable levels.
That shows that the Prime Minister and the Government agree with the message that the Opposition was pushing during the campaign; that employment was the fundamental issue concerning Australians.

PARA.TAB: Turning to industrial relations, I note that the Labor Party is now mouthing the words `enterprise bargaining'—the rhetoric of the coalition. The coalition has been advocating equal treatment for all Australians in industrial relations, but the Labor Party has said that it will bring the non-unionised workers into the fold and that unions should represent workers in the enterprise bargaining arrangements.

This is a very subtle change and people out there in the marketplace do not fully understand the impact of the difference in the policies. In philosophical terms, I am pleased that this trade union based Government is now coming around to the view that enterprise bargaining is the way for Australia to go in the future and that individual firms should be able to negotiate the terms and conditions of the workers who are employed in those firms.

However, page 17 of the Governor-General's speech gives the game away. The ALP is involving unions and management in these arrangements but the individual workers will not get much say because the trade union movement will represent them in the bargaining arrangements. Why is the Labor Party suddenly saying it has done so well in industrial relations? It has had six previous failed accords to bring about these changes and, because so many people in the Labor Party now fully understand that, inevitably, the union movement does not have a monopoly on the way in which wages are determined in Australia and the way in which people will go about work in the workplace.

Seventy per cent of Australians who work in the private sector choose not to belong to a trade union and will not take up a ticket. That figure is not understood by a lot of people out there in the electorate; there is a bit of a feeling that the trade unions dominate proceedings. One only has to go down to Melbourne and listen to John Halfpenny; people in that city would get the impression that he dominates the work force. The fact is that 70 per cent of the work force do not want to join a trade union and they are very happy to work within their current arrangements, to work with management, and keep their job, even in these very difficult circumstances.

As most economists and most intelligent commentators would agree, it is the small to medium sized business in Australia that will hold the key to the restoration of economic growth. The employers and employees of those smaller businesses have not been consulted by the Prime Minister or Mr Kelty or Mr Ferguson about the way in which they might organise their industrial relations arrangements. At a time when these smaller businessmen are struggling to make a profit, struggling to make sales in these recessed times, they have never been consulted about compulsory employer funded superannuation. Employers were forced by legislation passed by the Parliament to pay more and more superannuation, whether or not they had the money. The 800,000 small businessmen are struggling to find the funds to make the payments for that compulsory superannuation.

I agree with the recent comments of Mr Steve Dowrick of the Australian National University who very much agrees with the problems I have set out before the House. He believes that, under the Keating Government, use of the term `enterprise bargaining' will just mean that bargaining strategies are drawn up by the traditional, partially centralised blocs of craft based trade unions and industrially based employer associations. Mr Dowrick believes that these cosy, neither wholly centralised nor decentralised arrangements will lead to the deterioration of Australia's economic performance over the next 10 years. He has hit the nail on the head; he sees this unlikely arrangement where the Labor Party has agreed with the thesis we have put forward but is not able to put it into practice because of its commitment to the trade union movement.

Australia must abandon this approach of the ALP; it must properly deregulate the labour market and not keep the trade union movement as the favoured sons of the industrial relations arrangements. All the Government can say is that it will review the success of the national employment and training plan to ensure it is delivering to young people a number of these training programs. That is the Government's answer to the difficulties associated with industrial relations and the difficulty of creating jobs.

Australia does not need another review of the 23, 24, 25 or 20—it is hard to keep up—labour market programs the Government has put forward as a camouflage for the jobs that are not there. We need policies that will encourage investment in Australia to create real jobs—and long-term jobs at that. These training programs are a short term panacea for the problem of the one million unemployed here in Australia; they will never solve our long term problems.

The Government's speech allots a mere two paragraphs to the discussion of the question of constitutional reform—the debate we have here in the Parliament and the debate that is out and about in the electorate. Whilst we have not seen the report of the advisory committee recently set up by the Prime Minister, it seems to me that there is a hidden agenda behind the Government's moves. The whole exercise started with the misleading claim by the Government that it is really about minimalist change. The Government is also hoping that there will be sufficient consensus on constitutional change to hold a referendum and presumably, according to the ALP, install a President, if that was passed, by the year 2001. There were just two paragraphs in the Governor-General's speech, despite the important debate that we have here today. They are just slipped in there and they indicate a very minimalist approach to the whole program.

Let me raise the issues. What will be the future role of the Senate? Who will hold the reserve powers of which the Governor-General is now custodian on behalf of the people? Would a President be elected by the Parliament or in a general election, or would he be appointed by the Prime Minister? Would the methods of changing the Constitution be altered to delete the present requirement that a proposal has to be carried by a majority of electors in a majority of the States? Will it be possible for the States that disagreed with any push for a republic to retain a constitutional monarchy? Will the recently announced Republican Advisory Committee be permitted to come to the same conclusion as the constitutional commission did back in 1988 when it found that Australia should remain a constitutional monarchy?

The wording of the Prime Minister's terms of reference seem to prevent the eminent persons Republican Advisory Committee from reaching a similar conclusion. It would appear to me that the Prime Minister has hand-picked the committee. It is not a genuine committee. It has a preconceived position. From the way in which the Prime Minister has drafted the terms of reference, he is hoping to get a result that would suit him.

If and when the committee recommends a change to a republic, will it be altering many of the other mechanisms of Australian government, such as the balance of power between a suddenly more powerful Commonwealth of Australia and the States? What would be the attitude of Tasmania, Western Australia and South Australia to the enlarged powers that the Federal Government held under a republic?

The most important question is whether there is such a sudden need for change. Opinion polls showing a gradual shift in favour of a republic merely reflect the almost universal lack of understanding in our schools, through the media and in the public debates about the merits of the Westminster system of government, a constitutional monarchy and a Federal arrangement of government. Reform from a constitutional monarchy to a republic is the real debate. The real agenda of the Labor Party could be to install a Prime Minister with even greater unfettered powers than he now enjoys.

Labor's hatred of the Senate and the office of Governor-General is based on the events of 1975. Labor Party members forget that in 1975 all the Governor-General did was resolve a major crisis by allowing a vote of the people—not holding secret meetings in Kirribilli House which is—

TALK.START.PARA: —What thorough garbage. You are rewriting history yet again.

—That is absolutely the case. The Governor-General allowed a vote of the people to take place, and nobody can argue with that. That is a matter of fact. One might argue about the earlier procedures, but that is exactly what took place. It is a little bit different from what happened at Kirribilli House where the Labor Party had a little meeting to decide who might be the future Prime Minister. That was not a very open arrangement.

PARA.TAB: On the matter of protection, on page 18 of the statement the Government pledges that it will continue `steadily increasing the exposure of industry to international competition through reduction in tariffs and bounties'. I agree with this move by the Government, even though it is failing in the urgent need to reduce industry costs whilst tariffs are coming down. I remind the House that on 14 March 1991 the then Treasurer said this:

SPEECH.PARA: If the textiles, clothing and footwear industries are non-competitive and can never be competitive frankly, we're better off without them.

That was said by the Treasurer of the day, the current Prime Minister. The Prime Minister had convenient memory lapses during the election campaign when he attempted to attack the Opposition's negligible tariff level and omitted to remind the electorate of his own strongly held views. I agree with him on that issue of lower tariff protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should have been grateful for the Opposition's support.

—That is right; we supported him in those early years, in 1988, when it would have been easy to run with the tariff debate, which is fairly vigorous in certain parts of Australia. For political purposes, the Prime Minister was very keen in the seat of Wills to make great play of the fact that he was almost a high tariff man—not clear in his position, not wanting to go back to the very clear quote, but giving the impression that he was a man of the higher tariff position.

PARA.TAB: The car industry in Geelong—where I am very close to these arguments—through firms such as Ford, Paratus Industries, the TCF sector, Candy Footwear, Godfrey Hirst and Brintons Carpets, are all becoming truly world competitive. Tariffs are no longer the issue, despite the pathetic attempts of Ken Davidson of the Age and the Australian Democrats with their inquiry to keep the issue of tariffs alive.

Let me put the whole issue in perspective once and for all. There are about 150,000 people employed in the highly protected industries where all this debate takes place in a total work force in Australia of about 7.7 million people. I think we should let the issue rest by saying that most of the Australian work force is open to world competition. It has to compete on the world market and it is not protected, so why should that small section of the work force enjoy levels of protection that have not increased its job opportunities?

Time is running short. One of the real problems facing businesses in Australia, one which the present Government has done nothing about, is the associated on-costs of running businesses. Whether these costs be the imposition of the superannuation guarantee charge, the raising of the training guarantee levy, the failure to abolish payroll tax, which we had in our program, and the inability to abolish the confusing and costly sales tax, they have meant that the Government has not been a facilitator for business growth; in fact, they have been an adversary to the growth of businesses. The on-wage costs of about 37 per cent in the clothing and footwear industry and an on-cost of about 47 per cent in the transport industry indicate the tremendous costs that businesses are facing.

The Government owes many favours to its friends in the trade union movement who have perpetrated lies during the election campaign such as the misrepresentations about the coalition's industrial relations and health policies. For once I hope that this Government will govern in the interests of all Australians and deal urgently with the three crises of unemployment, foreign debt and the problems in the rural sector that so urgently need resolution in the short term.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to see you back in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I am very pleased to be back here as well. I also congratulate the new Speaker on his election. I note that you came back with a very large majority. For myself, it was a very small majority; nevertheless, I am very pleased to be here.
—It will get smaller, Harry.

—I also congratulate the honourable member for Ballarat; he probably thought he had a bit of a hard run. I offer my congratulations to all honourable members on both sides. I am particularly disappointed by the loss of a couple of members on my side. I would like to mention the former member for Hinkler, with whom I worked very closely in a number of areas. I found him to be a very hard working member for parliament and for his own electorate. It is genuinely a great loss to this Parliament to lose people of his calibre.

PARA.TAB: I have listened to a number of the speeches here today. I want to commend many honourable members for the way they have presented those speeches and the standard of those speeches. That standard reflects the sort of commitment that most people here have. However, I was quite astounded by the lack of direction that some speeches seemed to have. In particular, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) demonstrated a clear inability to comprehend any view that was in any way different to his long held views.

I think he is incapable of understanding that the Liberal and National parties have been beaten in this election, that the electorate of Australia actually voted us in with a clear majority. He was beaten because of the policies that he, in missionary-like fashion, enforced on the members of the Opposition, and because the Government's policies were seen as better.

He was unable to bend at all from his philosophy. He had policies which were seen as divisive—in industrial relations, in health care and, because of the regressive nature of his proposals, in the tax system he was proposing. He did not consult with his own party or with the National Party. When he changed that policy and cut food from the GST, and when that was relayed to the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) who was in England at the time, he did not know anything about it. There was no consultation; it was purely the initiative of the Leader of the Opposition.

I remember listening to the comments of the Leader of the National Party when he was asked about it, and he was astounded, or surprised, that things had changed. I almost thought he would fall off the deck of the Britannia at that time. His policy was produced because he did not consult. He looked to the past for initiative and, with no imagination of his own, he looked to other countries, even word for word for some of the wording for that policy. He cannot accept that he got it wrong. He now says that the electorate got it wrong.

It was sad to hear such pessimism and negativeness from a leader of a political party when he spoke today in this House. There was no view to the future, no view that he might be able to make a commitment that might be better for Australia. He had nothing whatsoever to offer us and he had absolutely no hope for Australia. If one listens to him, one would think it is true that we are all doomed. It was in a `we are all doomed' fashion that he presented himself. His lack of imagination and his lack of faith and confidence in the Australian people were really there for all to see.

On the other hand, the address by the Governor-General held out hope for the future, and we on this side of the Parliament do hold that hope. We recognise the problems and we will identify them. We identify the problem of unemployment in this country, particularly the problem faced by the long-term unemployed.

Solutions are achievable, and with the recognition that we can achieve those solutions, we can look forward with hope and optimism for Australia and all Australians. The thrust of that address by the Governor-General is directed to those problems. It establishes the Government's primary task of achieving a recovery from recession, assisting those who have suffered, and finding solutions, particularly for those long-term unemployed.

In my electorate, the number of long-term unemployed and unemployed generally is an ongoing problem. It is not something which has developed in the last few years as a result of this recession. In 1986, unemployment on the north coast of New South Wales was around 16 or 17 per cent. It is still around that figure and is still far too high. But the point is that that figure has not developed as a result of the recession and it will not disappear when the recession ends. The long-term unemployed are of greatest concern.

Of course, in many of those electorates—mine in particular and I dare say the electorate of the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne)—where the National Party had been in control for many years, unemployment was never produced as being an issue. It was only produced as an issue when national unemployment figures rose and members of the National Party could say that it was the Labor Party's fault. But the long-term unemployment problem in those country electorates, particularly on the north coast of New South Wales, has lasted many years and only this Government is starting to take steps to address it.

As we came out of the 1982 recession, national unemployment fell. But unemployment did not fall on the north coast of New South Wales. Employment rose and national unemployment fell, but on the north coast of New South Wales unemployment rose, if anything. The reason was that the people there were not able to take the jobs that became available. They did not take the jobs because they did not have the skills and training.

The sorts of programs that were denigrated by the previous speaker are the ones that will give the long-term unemployed a chance to get back into the work force. They are the sorts of programs that, as we come out of this recession and employment rises, will give the people on the north coast—the long-term unemployed who have taken advantage of the training schemes brought in by this Government—the opportunity of taking the jobs that become available.

That did not happen after the 1982 recession as we recovered in 1985-88. I see the programs that have been put in place, such as jobstart and jobskills, working on a personal basis all the time. There is a lot of opposition to them and many attitudes in the general community need to be changed. The attitude that seems to be so rife on the other side of the House is that these are mickey mouse programs. But I see them working in my electorate. I see people obtaining skills and training that will get them into jobs in the future.

Only last week I was out with the Richmond Landcare group, which has a jobskills brokerage. About 20 people are working in Richmond learning a whole range of farm and building skills that will be of enormous value to their getting jobs. I have met them personally and seen the work that they are doing. They are not unemployable people by any means. They are unemployed because they do not have the skills and training that are necessary for the jobs that will become available in the future.

The old idea, particularly in rural areas, of rural work being unskilled, low paid and without worth is gone. Those jobs do not exist any more. If people want jobs, they need the training and skills and the sorts of programs that this Government has initiated. The Governor-General's address stated that the national employment and training plan, with funding of $770 million, will provide that sort of training and the programs needed for developing skills for the future.

There is another side to the issue. There ain't no jobs if there ain't no industry. There has to be industry and business in areas such as mine if there are to be jobs. One has to look at the impediments to industry and regional development that exist if one is to encourage industry and business to come to rural areas. The problem is really caught up with infrastructure, because distance is the greatest impediment for people in setting up. The programs of road building and rail building will provide that infrastructure into the future.

I am particularly pleased about the spending on the National Rail Freight Corporation as a result of the program initiated by this Labor Government. If we look at Australia's history, we see that one of the greatest impediments to goods moving throughout this country has been the rail system with the changes in the gauges between States. This has existed for 100 years, and people have been talking for 100 years about fixing it, but no government has ever taken the initiative. Last term this Government took the initiative. The money was set aside and the work is happening now. A standard gauge rail system will be of enormous benefit. Although it was talked about, it was never acted upon. The problem was recognised but never addressed. But this Government has taken the step; it has put the money aside to do something about it. In my view, this has been one of the biggest steps in the transport and communications area in the last century.

The previous speaker also commented that government spending in this time of recession and low economic activity should not occur. It is completely appropriate that spending should take place at this time when private spending has dropped off to keep economic growth going. It is appropriate for the Government to step in to accelerate that economic activity.

Let me remind honourable members that in the 1980s this Government had consecutive surpluses over a number of Budgets. Historically, that had not been done before. That enabled us to have the sort of deficit we now have for the benefit of Australia. It is aimed to have that Budget deficit down to one per cent of GDP in 1995-96. I believe that is achievable, but these estimates do depend on what happens in the rest of the world. We are very dependent on world commodity prices and on trade in resources and primary products. We cannot act alone and we cannot achieve these estimates simply on Australia's performance when we depend so much on what is happening in the rest of the world.

One of this Government's greatest achievements has been to turn around Australia's trade performance from a state of almost total dependence on commodities and primary products to a greater dependence on manufactures, on value added goods. Our exports of manufactured goods have doubled in the last five years. Our exports of manufactured goods to the Asia-Pacific region where so much of our future lies have trebled.

Much of my area of Australia depends on primary products. It has been tough for people in my area in the sugar, beef and dairy industries. The achievements of this Government in the dairy industry have been remarkable. If it is properly marketed, if we obtain the markets in that great growth area of Asia, I believe the dairy industry will be a very good primary industry for Australia.

This Government has worked hard at, put a lot of work into, and not walked out of, the GATT talks—as one of the previous members for Richmond did—without any achievement. Achievement in those GATT talks will be by degrees. But even a small degree of achievement has potentially great benefit and increased profitability for our primary industries. The action of this Government on tariffs has also been remarkable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Supported by the Opposition.

—But the Opposition did not do it, and it would not have done it, because it has the National Party with it. We did it. We do not claim, as the Opposition does, that we will go to zero tariffs, but we do claim that we have broken the tariff wall. It is no longer the same as when old Black Jack McEwen used to run around the place. All one did was go and see him and say, `My costs have gone up, I need a bit more tariff protection'. That happened through those years and those enormous walls of tariff protection were built.

PARA.TAB: By the way, congratulations, Mr Speaker. I did congratulate you before you came in. It is good to see your smiling face. The previous Speaker was in the chamber just before I started my speech and if he had come back I would have said what a wonderful job he did too.

The Opposition has no imagination when it comes to constitutional reform. The previous speaker said that the reserve powers of the Governor-General are held on behalf of the people of Australia. That is the sort of rubbish that this lot opposite is going to run around the place. Those powers are not held on behalf of the people of Australia; they are held on behalf of the Queen of England. Those opposite talk about scare campaigns. I can imagine the real scare campaign they will run on this issue, for no better reason than lack of imagination and lack of forward thinking.

I hope that the rank and file in the coalition parties—I think this might happen—realise that the way ahead for Australia is by taking part in the issues; by having a bit of imagination, a bit of initiative and a bit of leadership. They will not find it with the leadership they have now. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights was adopted by national governments at the United Nations in 1948. It was conceived when the Second World War and the human tragedies in Europe and Asia were fresh in people's minds. Framed as it was in the shadow of momentous events, the declaration of human rights is one of the great idealistic pronouncements on human affairs. The opening lines of the declaration are:

SPEECH.PARA: Recognition of the inherent dignity and of the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family is the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world.
In June 1993 the governments of the world will meet in Vienna for the United Nations world conference on human rights to attempt to devise methods to bring these ideals into practical effect.

PARA.TAB: Australia's contribution to the Vienna conference has the potential to be an important one and I hope the Government will take full advantage of the opportunities. However, there is a huge difference between the rhetoric of human rights to which most governments ascribe and the grim reality. In recent years we have seen the Chinese military massacre students in Tiananmen Square and we have seen Indonesian forces kill a large number of East Timorese mourners at a funeral in Dili. There has also been a savage but thankfully brief repression in Bangkok. In Burma the popularly elected leader is beginning her fifth year under house arrest.

Closer to home we have Papua New Guinea's Bougainville blockade which, with the assistance of the Australian Government, is denying basic medical supplies to the population. It would be unfair not to mention in this context the treatment of Australia's Aboriginal people, aspects of which have brought into question our commitment to ensuring the dignity and equality of all members of our society.

Nevertheless, the differences in this area between Australia and our neighbouring Asian societies are very significant. This was underlined last March at the United Nations regional conference on human rights held in Bangkok. That meeting was called to prepare an agreed position for the Vienna conference. Although Australia sought to participate and vote at the Bangkok meeting, several Asian nations were successful in excluding us and New Zealand. We were allowed to attend as observers only. Burma, although accused by the United Nations of widespread executions, torture, disappearances, unfair imprisonments and forced labour, was accorded full status at the Bangkok conference. Indonesia, smarting from world disapproval of the Dili massacre, seemed especially anxious to exclude Australia.

There seems little doubt that some governments of South-East Asia will attempt to use the Vienna conference to undermine the concept of the ideal of universal human rights using the arguments of the primacy of economic development and cultural and national sovereignty. This view was recently indicated by an Indonesian government official on Australian television when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Economic development facilitates the overall enjoyment of human rights.

This seems to accord a greater priority and value to `economic rights' and to that extent it is a departure from the traditional western view. The Indonesian government official went on to make what I think was a case for some sort of cultural adjustment for human rights. He said:
We have to talk cross culturally. We have different backgrounds, culture and so on. It is not just a matter of pointing fingers.

Conscious of this push for a change in the ground rules, non-government organisations, such as Amnesty International, have become alarmed. They are urging a reaffirmation by world governments of the indivisibility of economic, social, cultural, civil and political rights.

PARA.TAB: Over 180 of these human rights organisations based in the Asia-Pacific region have recently signed a statement asserting the indivisibility and independence of all human rights. Australia should support this position in Vienna. Economic and cultural considerations or concepts of national sovereignty cannot be permitted to override the right of individuals to enjoy equality, freedom and dignity in any country.

Australia should at least adopt the program put forward by Amnesty International of the creation of a high level position of United Nations special commissioner on human rights. We should seek adequate funding for the upholding of human rights by the United Nations but, most importantly, we should reject categorically the concept that collective and economic rights are more important than individual, civil and political rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Thursday 22 April 1993 I had the great honour and privilege to attend a very special ceremony held at the RSL Riverside function centre at New Farm in Brisbane. This ceremony was the presentation to some 200 Queenslanders of the Malta George Cross 50th anniversary commemorative medal. This was a very special occasion for me and, of course, for the 200 Queenslanders who were recipients of that medal, but it was of special significance to one of the men present; that gentleman was Mr Don Mogg.

PARA.TAB: Three years ago, when I was first elected as the member for Moreton, I had only just started to feel comfortable in my seat in my office when Don Mogg came to see me. That was in April 1990. Don asked for my assistance to finally receive some recognition for the many thousands of allied personnel who had participated in the defence of Malta during the 3 1/2 years of the siege of the island by German forces.

It may come as some surprise to honourable members that the thousands and thousands of allied personnel and the many thousands of residents of Malta have never actually received any official recognition of the outstanding efforts they made to defend Malta. Anyone who is a student of the history of the Second World War appreciates that the defence of Malta was crucial to the result of the Second World War and to the allied victory in Europe. Don Mogg, having been one of the survivors of the siege of Malta, felt it was time we paid some recognition to these people, and he sought my assistance. Don was, and is still, a member of the George Cross Island Association. That association gets its name from the fact that Malta was awarded the George Cross in 1942 by his Majesty King George VI.

It was the only combat area in World War II awarded the George Cross. It was in recognition of the fact that the island had participated in an important event, but none of the individual participants has ever actually received any recognition. To mark the 50th anniversary of the siege and defence of Malta, the Maltese Government decided to strike a special medal, and it took some 2 1/2 years to convince it to do so. I am pleased I was able to take some small part in convincing the Government of Malta to participate in that process, along with the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), who also supported this plea and wrote to the President of Malta seeking his support for the medal.

I was delighted to see, after so many years of effort, those 200 Queenslanders, who are part of a contingent of more than 2,000 Australians, finally receive that recognition. All of those Australians owe a special tribute to Don Mogg, because without his efforts I do not believe any of the Australians would have received the medal, and I do not believe that the Maltese Government would have been convinced of the importance of this occasion.

The defence of Malta and the participation of so many thousands of allied personnel demonstrated the qualities of courage, determination and enormous fortitude in the face of overwhelming odds that Australians have come to appreciate, recognise and commemorate each Anzac Day. It was fitting that the ceremony occurred so close to Anzac Day and gave us an opportunity to reflect upon the courage of those many thousands of men and women who participated in the defence of Malta. None of them were happy to be there; none of them were particularly happy to face intense bombing and warfare every day just to survive; they were there because they knew their role was very important.

I am delighted to have been present when Don Mogg and the other 199 Queenslanders received their award. I wish to pay special tribute to the George Cross Island Association, to Don Mogg, and to all the thousands of Australians who played such an important part in the defence of Malta and, ultimately, in the victory in the Second World War.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
